CHAPTER 13
FINANCE, PURCHASES AND CONTRACTS
SECTION:
1-13-1: City Comptroller
1-13-2: Maintenance Of Accounts
1-13-3: City Bonds; Ownership Evidence And Endorsement
1-13-4: Accounting Procedures
1-13-5: Financial Reports
1-13-6: Payment Of Claims; Liability For Unauthorized Payments
1-13-7: Audits
1-13-8: Annual Budget
1-13-9: Purchasing And Contracts
1-13-9-1: Purchasing Agent
1-13-9-2: Purchases
1-13-9-3: Exemptions From Bidding Requirements
1-13-9-4: Bidding Procedures
1-13-9-5: Cooperative Purchasing
1-13-9-6: Storerooms
1-13-9-7: Purchasing Or Contracts Contrary To Chapter
1-13-9-8: Contract Compliance
1-13-9-9: Rules And Regulations
1-13-10: Petty Cash Fund
1-13-11: Surplus Personal Property
1-13-1: CITY COMPTROLLER:
   A.   Appointment: The city comptroller shall be appointed by the mayor by
and with the consent of the city council.
   B.   Director Of Finance: The city comptroller shall be the director of the
department of finance.
   C.   Duties: In addition to the performance of duties vested in the city
comptroller by state law 1 , he shall:
      1.   Establish, organize and keep all accounts of the city government.
      2.   Prepare and submit to the mayor such financial statements and
reports as the mayor may require.
      3.   Preaudit:
         a.   All revenues in order to assure the receipt and deposit of all
sums due the city.
         b.   All expenditures in order to prevent expenditures in excess of
budget appropriations, and in order to prevent irregular and illegal
expenditures.
      4.   Conduct special studies and investigations into the financial
affairs of the city departments whenever he deems it advisable.
      5.   Assist the mayor:
         a.   In the preparation of the annual budget.
         b.   In the purchase of all contractual services, supplies, materials
and equipment required by the various departments and agencies of the city,
subject to the ordinances relating thereto and the directions of the mayor.
      6.   Sell such personal property of the city as will not be needed for
further public use, subject to the requirements of state law.
      7.   Have charge of the storage of supplies and materials purchased by
the city and not delivered directly to the various departments and agencies,
and keep proper records thereof. (Ord. 3171, 4-10-1963)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-115.
1-13-2: MAINTENANCE OF ACCOUNTS:
   A.   Department Of Finance To Keep: All accounts of the city shall be kept
by the department of finance. Any accounts kept elsewhere pertaining to city
business shall be maintained in strict accordance with orders of the city
comptroller. (Ord. 6756, 8-27-2003)
1-13-3: CITY BONDS; OWNERSHIP EVIDENCE AND ENDORSEMENT:
By the endorsement of the city comptroller upon any bonds of the city, payable
to bearer, when presented for that purpose by the owner, such bonds shall
become payable only to the person named in such endorsement, his assignees or
legal representatives, anything on the face of such bonds to the contrary
notwithstanding. The affidavit of the person presenting any such bonds, or his
authorized agent or attorney, that he is the owner thereof, shall be sufficient
evidence to the city comptroller of such ownership.
The endorsement of the city comptroller may be in the following form:
By virtue of the act of the General Assembly of Illinois, the ordinances of the
City of Alton, and the consent of  (name) , the owner of this bond, this bond
is made payable only to said  (name) , his assignees or legal representatives,
anything on the face hereof to the contrary notwithstanding.  (Signature) ,
City Comptroller. 
(1961 Code, §§ 11-3, 11-5; amd. Ord. 3171, 4-10-1963)
1-13-4: ACCOUNTING PROCEDURES:
   A.   Establishment Of Accounting Procedures: The city comptroller shall
establish the city's accounting procedures in such manner that the accounts
will show all financial transactions of every branch of the city government,
and all financial transactions relating to all appropriations and funds; all
revenue accrued and liabilities incurred; all cash receipts and disbursements;
and, all transactions affecting the acquisition, custody and disposition of
assets. (1961 Code, § 11-6)
   B.   Appropriation Accounts: Accounts shall be kept by the city comptroller
for each appropriation made by the city council, together with a record of each
allotment of the appropriation by the mayor, if any. The city comptroller's
accounts shall show for each appropriation, and allotment if any, the amount of
obligations incurred against the same and the unencumbered balance remaining to
the credit thereof. (Ord. 3171, 4-10-1963)
   C.   Unencumbered Monies:
      1.   Certification Of Unencumbered Balance Prerequisite To Expenditures:
No contract or purchase order involving the expenditure of tax or bond money
shall be issued or entered into, nor shall any such be valid, unless the city
comptroller shall first certify thereon that there is in the treasury to the
credit of the appropriation from which it is to be paid an unencumbered balance
sufficient to meet the obligation. Notwithstanding the foregoing requirements,
stores and services requisitions and emergency purchase orders issued in
accordance with the rules promulgated by the mayor may be certified and
encumbered not later than three (3) days after their issuance. (1961 Code, §
11-8)
      2.   Sources Of Unencumbered Money Deemed In Treasury: All actual
unencumbered monies in the treasury to the credit of the fund from which they
may be drawn, all monies anticipated to be received from taxes or other sources
to the amounts stated in the annual budget and all monies to be derived from
bonds, notes and certificates of indebtedness, either then or previously
authorized, and either sold or authorized to be sold, shall for the purpose of
the city comptroller's certification be deemed in the treasury to the credit of
the appropriate fund and subject to certification. (1961 Code, § 11-9)
   D.   Liability Of Uncertified Obligations: If an official or employee of the
city shall authorize or incur an obligation against the city, without first
securing the city comptroller's certification required by this chapter, he and
his sureties shall be individually liable for the amount of such obligation.
(1961 Code, § 11-10)
   E.   Reserve Account: The city comptroller shall maintain a special account
to be designated as the "reserve account" of the city of Alton. Funds shall be
deposited into said account from time to time at the direction of the city
council or pursuant to the approved budget of the city of Alton. No transfers
from the reserve account may be authorized or completed unless and until
expressly approved by a resolution of the city council approved by a vote of
not less than two- thirds (2/3) of the members of the city council present at
the time of the vote on the resolution. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the
event of a bona fide emergency as determined by the mayor and the comptroller
funds may be transferred from the reserve account limited to the amount
necessary to address the emergency; in which case, the mayor shall report the
nature and circumstances of the emergency and the amount of funds transferred
from the reserve account to the city council at their next regular meeting.
(Ord. 7478, 9-9-2015, eff. 10-1-2015)
1-13-5: FINANCIAL REPORTS:
At the close of each month, and at any other time if so ordered, the city
comptroller shall prepare and submit to the mayor a statement of the condition
of each appropriation and fund and such other reports as may be required of
him. At the close of the year he shall submit to the mayor a complete report of
the financial transactions of the year and the condition of the city's
finances, including a balance sheet for each fund, and such other reports as
are required by law. (Ord. 3171, 4-10-1963)
1-13-6: PAYMENT OF CLAIMS; LIABILITY FOR UNAUTHORIZED PAYMENTS:
The City Comptroller shall examine all payrolls, requisitions, bills and other
claims and demands against the City and shall not issue a warrant for payment
thereof unless he has found, by diligent investigation, that the claim is in
proper form, correctly computed and duly approved as required by State law;
that it is justly and legally due and payable; and, that it is accompanied by
the certification of a responsible official of the department concerned that
the goods and services listed therein were actually received. If he finds a
claim to be fraudulent, erroneous or otherwise invalid, he shall refuse to
authorize the payment of the same and shall make immediate report of the
circumstances to the Mayor.
If the City Comptroller issues a warrant on the City Treasurer authorizing the
payment of any item for which no appropriation has been made, or for the
payment of which there is not a sufficient unencumbered balance in the proper
appropriation, or which is otherwise contrary to law, he and his sureties shall
be individually liable to the City for the full amount thereof.
The City Council shall approve for payment all expenses and liabilities of the
City. The Committee of the Whole shall act as an auditing committee to review
such proposed expenses and payments. (1961 Code, § 11-12)
1-13-7: AUDITS:
   A.   Internal Audit:
      1.   The City Comptroller shall conduct a thorough and continuous
internal audit of all receipts, payments, assets and liabilities of all funds
handled by the City, or any agency thereof, in order to protect the City from
loss through accident, negligence or dishonesty. It shall be his responsibility
to see that all amounts legally due the City are correctly computed, and when
collected are deposited in the treasury to the credit of the proper fund and
account. He shall verify the City Treasurer's daily cash transactions and
certify to the correctness of the City Treasurer's cash report.
      2.   At least once a year, he shall audit the securities, insurance
policies and bonds of the City, and shall determine whether the City is
properly and adequately insured and whether City employees are properly and
adequately bonded, reporting his findings to the Mayor.
      3.   He shall maintain an inventory of all real property owned by the
City and of all other property of the City having a useful life of one year or
more.
      4.   No money shall be received by any department of the City except by
means of a numbered receipt or other controlled numbering system prescribed and
controlled by the City Comptroller. A copy of each receipt issued shall be
maintained for the City Comptroller. No money shall be paid out of the treasury
except by means of a warrant issued by the City Comptroller. (1961 Code, § 11-
13; amd. 1999 Code)
   B.   Special Audits: The City Comptroller shall, when so ordered by the
Mayor, and may upon his own initiative, make special audits and investigations
into the financial affairs of any department of the City government. (Ord.
3171, 4-10-1963)
   C.   Independent Audit: As soon as practicable at the close of each fiscal
year, and no later than six (6) months thereafter, there shall be an audit of
all accounts of the City made by a certified public accountant designated by
the City Council. Copies of each audit report shall be filed with the City
Clerk and the State Department of Revenue and in such other places as may be
required by law. (1961 Code, § 11-15)
1-13-8: ANNUAL BUDGET:
   A.   Fiscal Year Designated: The fiscal year of the City shall commence on
April 1 and end on March 31. (1961 Code, § 11-17)
   B.   Submission Of Proposed Budget To City Council:
      1.   Proposed Budget: On or before the fourth Wednesday of April in each
year, the Mayor shall submit to the City Council a proposed budget covering all
municipal activities for the ensuing fiscal year, based upon a careful
consideration of departmental needs and fund resources, as presented to the
Mayor by department heads.
      2.   Budget Allocations To Private Organizations:
         a.   A private organization is defined as any entity not created by or
directly under the control of the City as a municipal corporation.
         b.   Any private organization requesting funding or which is proposed
to receive funding from the City must submit an application for funding to the
City Comptroller, on forms available from the City Comptroller, during the
months of January and February prior to the commencement of the City's fiscal
year, that being April 1. The City shall not provide any funding to any private
organization except in response to an application timely filed with the City
Comptroller as aforesaid and shall in no event provide funding in excess of the
amount requested in said application, unless approved by an affirmative vote of
five (5) Aldermen. If any private organization requests funding or is proposed
to receive funding from the City as part of the proposed budget submitted to
the City Council, it is recommended that such a private organization have at
least two (2) representatives present at any hearings scheduled by the City
Council to consider the funding of such a private organization in the
consideration of the proposed budget submitted to the City Council. The two (2)
representatives should be officers of the private organization, if possible,
and should be fully familiar with the purpose of the proposed funding from the
City and able to respond to any questions or concerns as presented by the
members of the City Council at said hearings. (Ord. 6355, 12-16-1998)
   C.   Information Shown For Each Fund: The proposed budget referred to in the
preceding subsection shall set forth for each fund all proposed expenditures
for the administration, operation and maintenance of all departments and
agencies for which appropriations are to be made or taxes levied by the City
Council, all expenditures for capital projects to be financed by tax levies,
miscellaneous revenue or other similar means during the fiscal year, all
interest and debt redemption charges during the fiscal year and the actual or
estimated operating deficits from previous fiscal years. In addition thereto,
the proposed budget shall set forth for each fund the anticipated income from
all sources, available surpluses and other means of financing such expenditures
for the ensuing fiscal year, the total of which shall not be less than the
total proposed expenditures from each fund. (1961 Code § 11-19)
1-13-9: PURCHASING AND CONTRACTS:
1-13-9-1: PURCHASING AGENT:
The Deputy Comptroller shall be designated the responsibilities of purchasing.
The Deputy Comptroller shall make all purchases and contracts for purchases for
all the departments, commissions and agencies of the City, except as otherwise
provided, of contractual services, supplies, materials and equipment in
accordance with procedures and policies to be promulgated by the Deputy
Comptroller and approved by the Mayor. The Deputy Comptroller may solicit bids
and award term contracts for contractual services, supplies, materials or
equipment which are required by more than one office, department, agency or
other unit of the City government. (Ord. 6961, 7-12-2006)
1-13-9-2: PURCHASES:
   A.   Each department head is hereby authorized to purchase on the open
market, contractual services, supplies, materials and equipment costing not
more than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00).
   B.   All purchases of and contracts for contractual services, supplies,
materials and equipment wherein it is anticipated that the cost thereof will
exceed three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) during one fiscal year shall be
awarded on written purchase orders or contracts, based on competitive bids
submitted, subject to the provisions of this section.
Sealed bids shall be requested for all purchases of three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) or more. For all purchases in excess of three thousand dollars
($3,000.00), the Deputy Comptroller shall post in the City Hall notice of such
bid requests at least five (5) days prior to the opening of such bids and shall
publish notice of bid requests in a newspaper published or generally circulated
within the City.
After said bids are received, they should be tabulated by the Deputy
Comptroller who shall report the results thereof to the Committee of the Whole
except as stated in subsection
1-13-9-4B of this section
1-13-9 and they shall thereafter make their recommendation to the City Council
who shall approve a bid or reject all bids.
   C.   Notwithstanding the preceding subsections, Public Works Department
purchases of and contracts for supplies, materials, and equipment directly
related to the construction, maintenance, improvement or repair of city
roadways, storm sewers, parks and adjacent improvements, Public Works
Department contracts for the demolition and removal of buildings or other
structures, the amount of which does not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000.00), may be awarded on written purchase orders or contracts, based
upon not less than three (3) competitive and informal bids solicited by the
Public Works Director or the Deputy Comptroller.
   D.   Contracts which by their nature are not adapted to awards by
competitive bidding, such as contracts for utility services, contracts for the
services of individuals possessing a high degree of professional skill where
the ability and fitness of the individual plays an important part, contracts
for printing bonds and evidences of indebtedness, contracts for purchase of
magazines, books, periodicals, films and records of an educational or
instructional nature, and the binding of such magazines, books, periodicals,
reports and similar articles, and contracts for publication of ordinances and
financial reports, shall not be subject to the competitive bidding requirements
of this chapter.
   E.   The City Council may elect to purchase goods or enter into contracts
for service, supplies, materials or equipment without competitive bids if
approved by a vote of not less than two-thirds (2/3) of the City Council. (Ord.
6595, 7-25-2001; amd. Ord. 6961, 7-12-2006; Ord. 7682, 2-13-2019; Ord. 7789,
12-17-2020)
1-13-9-3: EXEMPTIONS FROM BIDDING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Emergency Purchases: In the event of disaster or other emergency, if
purchases of supplies, materials, or equipment must be made immediately without
an opportunity for the procedures established by this Code or without City
Council approval, the Mayor is authorized to make necessary purchases to
protect the public health, safety and welfare without complying with the
procedures outlined in this chapter. In the event of such emergency purchases,
the Mayor shall report the details of the purchases to the City Council at the
next regular meeting thereof.
   B.   Joint Purchases: All purchases made jointly with the United States
government, State of Illinois, or other authorized unit of government are
exempted from the formal and informal bid requirements of this chapter.
   C.   Articles Purchased For Resale To The Public: All purchases intended
solely for resale to the public are exempted from the formal and informal bid
requirements of this chapter.
   D.   Used Materials Or Equipment Not Adapted To Competitive Bidding:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section
1-13-9, in the event a department head deems it advantageous to purchase used
materials or equipment, the department head, acting in conjunction with and
advice of the Deputy Comptroller, and with the approval of the Mayor, may
purchase said materials or equipment. At the next regular City Council meeting
following the purchase of used materials or equipment, the department head and
Deputy Comptroller shall make a full report to the City Council.
   E.   Unanticipated Loss: In the case of the occurrence of any breakage or
loss of equipment, or in other circumstances which could not reasonably be
anticipated, whereby in a necessary regular service of the City is, or is about
to be, interrupted, or whereby the City will suffer any great or continuing
loss, the Deputy Comptroller, upon the approval of the Mayor or the Chairman of
the Committee of the Whole, may negotiate an emergency purchase to restore or
maintain such service or to terminate such loss, without advertising for bids
and in such amount as may be necessary in the circumstances. In the case of
such an emergency purchase involving more than three thousand dollars
($3,000.00), the Mayor shall at the next regular meeting of the City Council
thereafter, render a full report of the case and circumstances. (Ord. 6961, 7-
12-2006)
1-13-9-4: BIDDING PROCEDURES:
   A.   Qualifications Of Bidders: All contracts or open market orders made by
the City shall be awarded to the bidder whose bid is determined by the Deputy
Comptroller to serve the best interest of the City, taking into consideration
the quality of the goods or services to be supplied, their conformity with the
specifications, the price, delivery, terms and the service reputation of the
vendor.
   B.   Rejection Of Bids: The Deputy Comptroller may reject all bids for any
contract or purchase or for any one or more commodities included in such a bid
when the public interest will be served thereby. If all the bids so rejected
are for the same unit price or total amount, or if the public interest will not
permit the delay of soliciting or readvertising for bids, the Deputy
Comptroller shall have the authority to purchase the required contractual
services, supplies, materials and equipment in the open market, provided that
the price paid on the open market shall not exceed the lowest bid price. (Ord.
6961, 7-12-2006)
   C.   Local Bidders: The city shall accept the lowest qualified bidder unless
that bid is from a nonlocal bidder and a local qualified bidder submits a bid
which is within two percent (2%) of the lowest bid, then in that event, the bid
may be awarded to the lowest qualified local bidder. "Nonlocal" bidder shall be
defined as a bidder who does not reside in Alton or have a legitimate business
enterprise lawfully operating in Alton. In the event federal or state statutes
or regulations pertaining to the particular expenditures involved prohibit
acceptance of any bid other than the lowest qualified bid, the foregoing
provision shall not apply. (Ord. 5665, 6-10-1992)
1-13-9-5: COOPERATIVE PURCHASING:
The deputy comptroller shall have the authority to join with other units of
government and agencies in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interests
of the city would be served thereby. All purchases made through cooperative
purchasing plans are exempted from the formal and informal bid requirements.
(Ord. 6961, 7-12-2006)
1-13-9-6: STOREROOMS:
Whenever the interests of the city will be thus promoted, the purchasing agent
may purchase goods, supplies, materials and equipment at wholesale and in bulk
and the same shall be paid for out of funds appropriated for this purpose.
Whenever any such goods, supplies, materials or equipment shall be required by
any department or other agency of the city government, the same may be
supplied, so far as possible, out of the general store thus created, and when
so supplied they shall be charged to the department or agency using them and
the appropriate store's account credited with the amounts so charged. (1961
Code, § 11-29)
1-13-9-7: PURCHASING OR CONTRACTS CONTRARY TO CHAPTER:
Whenever any official or employee of the city government shall purchase or
contract for any supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services
contrary to the provisions of this chapter or the rules and regulations made
thereunder, such order or contract shall be void and of no effect. (1961 Code,
§ 11-30)
1-13-9-8: CONTRACT COMPLIANCE:
   A.   Signature: The mayor shall examine all contracts, except purchase
orders to which the city may be a party and shall sign on behalf of the city
any contract authorized by the city council, except where the city council
directs some other officer or officers to do so.
   B.   Compliance: It shall be the duty of the mayor to see that all terms of
any contract to which the city is a party are faithfully performed by all
parties thereto.
   C.   Female And Minority Participation: The city hereby determines that it
is the policy of this city that in all construction projects funded in whole or
in part by city funds or awarded or supervised by the city, its agents, or
employees, all persons participating in any such construction projects shall be
encouraged to strive toward a goal of integration of racial minorities and
women as participants in the economic benefits derived by the private sector in
connection with such public construction projects.
Specifically, it is hereby determined to be the policy of this city that, on
any such construction projects, the city will encourage minority participation
in accordance with duly established federal guidelines. (Ord. 5511, 1-9-1991)
1-13-9-9: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The deputy comptroller, with the approval of the mayor, may adopt, promulgate
and from time to time amend rules and regulations not inconsistent with law for
the following purposes: (Ord. 6961, 7-12-2006)
   A.   To prescribe the manner in which supplies, materials and equipment
shall be delivered, stored and distributed.
   B.   To prescribe the dates for submitting advance requisitions or estimates
of future purchase requirements, the future period which they shall cover, the
form in which they shall be submitted and their revision by the mayor.
   C.   To prescribe the manner of inspecting all deliveries of supplies,
materials and equipment.
   D.   To provide for the transfer between departments of surplus supplies,
materials and equipment.
   E.   To prescribe the amount of deposit or bond to be submitted with the bid
on a contract and the amount of deposit or bond to be given for the faithful
performance of a contract.
   F.   To provide for emergency purchases on the open market for immediate
delivery in emergencies, to define such emergencies and prescribe the manner in
which such purchases shall be made.
   G.   To provide for such other matters as may be necessary to give effect to
the foregoing rules and provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 3171, 4-10-1963)
1-13-10: PETTY CASH FUND:
   A.   Established: There is hereby established in the office of the city
comptroller a petty cash fund in an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars
($500.00). (Ord. 5188, 11-25-1987)
   B.   Custody Of Fund: The city comptroller shall be personally charged with
the custody of the petty cash fund. The mayor shall be alternate custodian for
the petty cash fund in the absence of the city comptroller. (Ord. 3171, 4-10-
1963)
   C.   Expenditures Not To Exceed Seventy Five Dollars: Expenditures of not
more than seventy five dollars ($75.00) for any one item may be made from the
petty cash fund. A petty cash voucher must be filled out to substantiate each
expenditure from the petty cash fund. (Ord. 6507, 7-12-2000)
   D.   Audit: Upon termination of employment or transfer of either custodian
of the petty cash fund, a check out audit of such fund shall be made before a
final paycheck is issued to such custodian. (1961 Code § 11-38)
   E.   Mayor To Prescribe Regulations: The administrative details for the
orderly handling of the petty cash fund and reimbursement of expenditures made
therefrom shall be as prescribed by the mayor. (Ord. 3171, 4-10-1963)
1-13-11: SURPLUS PERSONAL PROPERTY:
   A.   From time to time the city council may, by resolution, approve the sale
of specific items of city owned surplus property that are found to be no longer
necessary or appropriate for municipal purposes for the city of Alton. The sale
of such specific items of surplus personal property shall be conducted at the
direction of the deputy comptroller and shall be in the form of an advertised
public auction or by an internet auction service previously approved by the
city council. Sale of surplus personal property to any entity other than by an
advertised public auction or through an internet auction service previously
approved by the city council must be approved by the city council on a case by
case basis. (Ord. 7337, 11-28-2012; amd. Ord. 7477, 9-9-2015, eff. 10-1-2015)
   B.   Any scrap metal, plastic, or any other recyclable materials with any
monetary value can only be disposed of, sold, traded or bartered by a city
employee pursuant to a specific written directive from the head of the
department holding such material. A report concerning any such materials that
may be transferred pursuant to the specific written directive of the head of a
department shall be forwarded to the office of the mayor, treasurer and
comptroller within two (2) business days following such a transfer. The report
shall contain at a minimum the written directive of the department head, a
description of the materials transferred, the name and location of the
transferee, receipts from the transferee for all such materials and the name or
names of the city employees tasked with delivering the materials to the
transferee. Any funds received on behalf of the city of Alton in connection
with the transfer of such materials shall be conveyed to the office of the
treasurer along with the aforesaid report not less than two (2) business days
following the transfer. (Ord. 7477, 9-9-2015, eff. 10-1-2015)
CHAPTER 14
INDUSTRIAL POLLUTION CONTROL REVENUE BONDS PROCEDURE
SECTION:
1-14-1: Definitions
1-14-2: Legislative Declaration Of Purpose
1-14-3: Additional Powers
1-14-4: Exercise Of Powers; Bonds
1-14-5: Covenants In Bonds
1-14-6: Signatures Of Officers On Bonds; Validity Of Bonds
1-14-7: Lien Of Bonds
1-14-8: Liability For Bonds
1-14-9: Investment Of Funds
1-14-10: Exemption From Construction And Bidding Requirements For Public
Buildings
1-14-11: Additional And Supplemental Powers; Limitations Imposed
1-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever used in this Chapter, unless a different meaning clearly appears from
the context:
CITY: The City of Alton, Madison County, Illinois.
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT PROJECT: Any land, interest in land, building, structure,
facility, system, fixture, improvement, addition, appurtenance, machinery or
equipment or any combination thereof, on all real and personal property deemed
necessary in connection therewith, for use by any person, provided that the
existence of such economic development project will create or retain employment
opportunities in the City.
FINANCING AGREEMENT: Any agreement entered into by the City with any person or
persons which provides that the City shall issue its bonds, notes or other
obligations to finance all or a portion of the costs of a project or projects,
title to which may or may not be vested in the City, provided that said bonds,
notes or other obligations shall be limited obligations of the City as provided
in Section
1-14-8 of this Chapter.
HOSPITAL FACILITY: Any land interest in land, building, structure, facility,
system, fixture, improvement, appurtenance, addition, machinery or equipment or
any combination thereof, and all real and personal property deemed necessary in
connection therewith, having to do with or the end purpose of which, is the
provision of hospital and nursing home and health care services.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, firm, company, corporation
(including public utilities), association, joint stock company, trust, estate,
political subdivision, state agency, or any other legal entity, or its legal
representative, agent or assigns.
POLLUTION: Any form of environmental pollution including, but not limited to,
water pollution, air pollution, land pollution, solid waste pollution, thermal
pollution, radiation contamination, or noise pollution as determined by the
various standards prescribed by this State, the Federal government or other
governmental entities and including, but not limited to, anything which is
considered as pollution or environmental damage in the Environmental Protection
Act 1 , and any amendment thereto and substitution therefor.
POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITY: Any land, interest in land, building, structure,
facility, system, fixture, improvement, appurtenance, addition, machinery or
equipment, or any combination thereof, and all real and personal property
deemed necessary in connection therewith, having with or the end purpose of
which is, reducing, controlling or preventing pollution.
PROJECT: Any economic development project, pollution control facility or
hospital facility, water facility or any combination thereof.
PROJECT COSTS: Includes the sum total of all reasonable or necessary costs
incidental to the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, repair,
alteration, improvement and extension of a project including without limitation
the cost of studies and surveys; plans, specifications, architectural and
engineering services; legal, marketing or other special services; financing,
acquisition, demolition, construction, equipment and site development of new
and rehabilitated buildings, rehabilitation, reconstruction, repair or
remodeling of existing buildings and all other necessary and incidental
expenses including an initial bond and interest reserve together with interest
on bonds issued to finance a project to a date six (6) months subsequent to the
estimated date of completion.
WATER FACILITY: Any land, interest in land, building, structure, facility,
system, fixture, improvement, appurtenance, addition, machinery or equipment,
or any combination thereof, and all real and personal property deemed necessary
in connection therewith, having to do with or the end purpose of which, is the
furnishing of water, on reasonable demand, to members of the general public.
(Ord. 4700, 6-9-1982)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS.
1-14-2: LEGISLATIVE DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
It is hereby determined and declared that the purpose of this Chapter is to
provide a financing device which will aid in financing the cost of projects in
order to relieve conditions of unemployment and to encourage the increase of
industry within the City, thereby reducing the evils attendant upon
unemployment and to provide for the increased welfare and prosperity of the
residents of the City; it is hereby further determined and declared to be the
purpose of this Chapter to provide a financing device which will aid in
financing the cost of pollution control facilities in order to eliminate, abate
or reduce the serious dangers to the public health and welfare caused by
environmental pollution and to provide a financing device which will aid in
financing the cost of hospital facilities; it is hereby further determined and
declared to be the purpose of this Chapter to provide a financing device which
will aid in financing the cost of water facilities; and the same are hereby
declared and determined to be public purposes and functions pertaining to the
government and affairs of the City. (Ord. 4599, 3-25-1981)
1-14-3: ADDITIONAL POWERS:
In addition to powers which it may now have, the City shall have the power
under this Chapter:
   A.   To construct, acquire by gift, purchase or lease, to reconstruct,
improve, better or extend and to finance one or more projects, whether or not
now or hereafter in existence and whether or not the City has any title to such
project or projects, within the City, and if desirable, to acquire by gift,
purchase or lease lands or rights in land in connection with any project.
   B.   To issue its revenue bonds to defray in whole or in part the project
costs of any project and to designate an appropriate name for such bonds.
   C.   To rent, lease or sell any project to any person or to execute a
financing agreement with any person or persons in such manner that payments to
be received with respect to the project or such financing agreement shall
produce revenues and receipts sufficient to provide for the prompt payments at
maturity of principal, interest and redemption premiums, if any upon all bonds
issued to finance the cost of such project.
   D.   To pledge to the punctual payment of bonds authorized under this
Chapter, the interest thereon, and the redemption premiums, if any, the revenue
and receipts to be received from such project or such financing agreement.
   E.   To mortgage such project in favor of the holder or holders of bonds
issued therefor.
   F.   To sell and convey such project, including without limitation the sale
and conveyance thereof subject to a mortgage, if any, as provided in this
Chapter, for such price and at such time as the governing body of the City may
determine. However, no sale or conveyance of such project shall ever be made in
such manner as to impair the rights or interests of the holder or holders of
any bonds issued to finance the project costs of such project.
   G.   To issue its bonds to refund in whole or in part, bonds theretofore
issued by such City under authority of this Chapter.
      1.   The principal proceeds from the sale of any refunding bonds shall be
applied only as follows: either,
         a.   To the immediate payment and retirement of the obligations being
refunded; or
         b.   To the extent not required for the immediate payment of the bonds
being refunded then such proceeds shall be deposited in trust to provide for
the payment and retirement of the bonds being refunded, and to pay any expenses
incurred in connection with such refunding, but provision may be made for the
pledging and disposition of any surplus, including, without limitation,
provision for the pledging of any surplus to the payment of principal and
interest on series of refunding bonds. Money in any such trust may be invested
in direct obligations of, or obligations the principal and interest of which
are guaranteed by, the United States government. Nothing herein shall be
construed as a limitation on the duration of any deposit in trust for the
retirement of obligations being refunded which shall not have matured and which
shall not be presently redeemable, or, if presently redeemable, shall not have
been called for redemption.
   H.   To issue its notes or other obligations for the same purposes and under
the same conditions authorized in this Chapter for the issuance of its bonds.
Property acquired by the City pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter shall
be exempt from the imposition and collection of taxes thereon while owned the
City, but the use of such property is subject to taxation to be paid by the
lessee or occupant as provided in section 26 of the Revenue Act of 1939, filed
May 17, 1939, or as may hereafter be amended. (Ord. 4186, 3-23-1977)
1-14-4: EXERCISE OF POWERS; BONDS:
The exercise of all powers granted by this Chapter may be authorized, and bonds
authorized to issued under this Chapter for the purposes set forth by ordinance
of the governing body of the City which may be adopted at the same meeting at
which it is introduced and shall take effect immediately upon adoption.
The bonds shall bear interest at such rate or rates, payable at such times, may
be in one or more series, may bear such date or dates, may mature at such time
or times not exceeding forty (40) years from their respective dates, may be
payable in such medium of payment at such place or places, may carry such
registration privileges, may be subject to such terms of redemption at such
premiums, may be executed in such manner, may contain such terms, covenants and
conditions, and may be in such form, either coupon or registered, as such
ordinance may provide or as may be subsequently determined by the governing
body before the bonds are issued. The bonds may be sold at public or private
sale in such manner and upon such terms as may be deemed advisable by the
governing body of the City. Pending the preparation of the definitive bonds,
interim receipts or certificates in such form and with such provisions as the
governing body of the City may determine, may be issued to the purchaser or
purchasers of bonds sold pursuant to this Chapter. The bonds and interim
receipts or certificates shall be deemed to be securities and negotiable
instrument's within the meaning and for all purposes of the "Uniform Commercial
Code 1 . (Ord. 3803, 3-28-1973)
 
Notes
1 1. 810 ILCS.
1-14-5: COVENANTS IN BONDS:
Any ordinance authorizing the issuance of bonds under this Chapter may contain
covenants as to:
   A.   The use and disposition of the revenues and receipts from the project
or financing agreement for which the bonds are to be issued, including the
creation and maintenance of reserves;
   B.   The issuance of other or additional bonds relating to the project or
any rehabilitation, improvements, renovations, enlargements or addition's
thereto;
   C.   The maintenance and repair of such project;
   D.   The insurance to be carried thereon and the use and disposition of
insurance moneys;
   E.   The appointment of any bank or trust company within or outside the
State of Illinois, having the necessary trust powers as trustee for the benefit
of the bondholders, paying agent and bond registrar;
   F.   The investment of any funds held by such trustee; and
   G.   The terms and conditions upon which the holders of the bonds or any
portion thereof or any trustees therefor, are entitled to the appointment of a
receiver.
Any ordinance authorizing the issuance of bonds under this Chapter may provide
that the principal of and interest on any bonds issued under this Chapter shall
be secured by a mortgage or indenture of trust covering such project for which
the bonds are issued and may include any improvements or extensions thereafter
made. Such mortgage or indenture of trust containing such covenants and
agreements to properly safeguard the bonds as may be provided for in the
ordinance authorizing such bonds and shall be executed in the manner as may be
provided for in the ordinance. The provisions of this Chapter and any such
ordinance or ordinances and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall
constitute a contract with the holder or holders of the bonds and continue in
effect until the principal of, the interest on, and the redemption premiums, if
any, on the bonds so issued have been fully paid, and the duties of the City
and its corporate authorities and officers under this Chapter and any such
ordinance or ordinances and any such mortgage or indenture of trust shall be
enforceable by any bondholder by mandamus, foreclosure of any such mortgage or
indenture of trust or other appropriate suit, action or proceedings in any
court of competent jurisdiction; provided, the ordinance or any mortgage or
indenture of trust under which the bonds are issued may provide that all such
remedies and rights to enforcement may be vested in a trustee for the benefit
of all the bondholders which trustee shall be subject to the control of a
majority of the holders or owners of any outstanding bonds. (Ord. 3986, 6-11-
1975)
1-14-6: SIGNATURES OF OFFICERS ON BONDS; VALIDITY OF BONDS:
The bonds shall bear the manual or facsimile signatures of such officers of the
City as may be designated in the ordinance authorizing such bonds and such
signatures shall be the valid and binding signatures of the officers of the
City, notwithstanding that before the delivery thereof and payments therefor
any or all of the persons whose signatures thereon have ceased to be officers
of the City issuing such. The validity of the bonds is not dependent on nor
affected by the validity or regularity of any proceedings relating to the
acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping,
betterment or extension of the project for which the bonds are issued. The
ordinance authorizing the bonds may provide that the bonds shall contain a
recital that they are issued pursuant to this Chapter, which recital shall be
conclusive evidence of their validity and of the regularity of their issuance.
(Ord. 3986, 6-11-1975)
1-14-7: LIEN OF BONDS:
All bonds issued under this Chapter shall have a lien upon the revenues and
receipts derived from the project or financing agreement for which the bonds
have been issued, and the governing body may provide in the ordinance or
ordinances authorizing such bonds for the issuance of additional bonds to be
equally and ratably secured by a lien upon such revenues and receipts or may
provide that the lien upon such revenues and receipts is subordinate. (Ord.
3986, 6-11-1975)
1-14-8: LIABILITY FOR BONDS:
All bonds issued under and pursuant to this Chapter shall be limited
obligations of the City payable solely out of the revenues and receipts derived
from the project or financing agreement with respect to which such bonds are
issued. No holder of any bonds issued under this Chapter has the right to
compel any exercise of taxing power of the City to pay the bonds, the interest
or premium, if any, thereon and the bonds do not constitute an indebtedness of
the City or a loan of credit thereof within the meaning of any constitutional
or statutory provision. It shall be plainly stated on the face of each bond
that it has been issued under the provisions of this Chapter and that it does
not constitute an indebtedness of the City or a loan of credit thereof within
the meaning of any constitutional or statutory provisions. (Ord. 3986, 6-11-
1975)
1-14-9: INVESTMENT OF FUNDS:
The City, or any trustee on behalf of the City, may invest any funds held by it
pursuant to this Chapter in bonds, notes, certificates of indebtedness,
treasury bills or other securities constituting direct obligations of the
United States of America; in certificates of deposit or time deposits
constituting direct obligations of any bank as defined by the Illinois Banking
Act 1 , as heretofore and hereafter amended, provided, however, that
investments may be made only in those certificates of deposit or time deposits
in banks which are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, if
then in existence; or in short term discount obligations of the Federal
National Mortgage Association. Any such securities may be purchased at the
offering or market price thereof at the time of such purchase. (Ord. 3803, 3-
28-1973)

1-14-10: EXEMPTION FROM CONSTRUCTION AND BIDDING REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLIC
BUILDINGS:
The acquisition and construction of a project shall not be subject to any
requirements relating to public buildings, structures, grounds, works or
improvements imposed by State law 1  or any other similar requirements which
may be lawfully waived by this Section and any requirement of competitive
bidding or restriction imposed on the procedure for award of contracts for such
purpose or the lease, sale or other disposition of property of the City is not
applicable to any action taken under authority of this Chapter. (Ord. 3803, 3-
28-1973)
 
Notes
1 2. 65 ILCS 5/8-10-1 et seq.
1-14-11: ADDITIONAL AND SUPPLEMENTAL POWERS; LIMITATIONS IMPOSED:
The powers conferred by this Chapter are in addition and supplemental to, and
the limitations imposed by this Chapter shall not affect, the powers conferred
by any law or any other ordinance. Projects may be acquired, purchased,
constructed, reconstructed, improved, bettered, equipped, extended and
financed, and bonds may be issued under this Chapter for such purposes,
notwithstanding that any law or any other ordinance may provide for the
acquisition, purchase, construction, reconstruction, improvement, equipping,
betterment, extension and financing of a like project, or the issuance of bonds
for like purposes, and without regard to the requirements, restrictions,
limitations or other provisions contained in any law or any other ordinance.
(Ord. 3803, 3-28-1973)
CHAPTER 15
PROPERTY TAX ABATEMENT
SECTION:
1-15-1: Property Tax Abatement Within The City
1-15-2: Property Tax Abatement For Industrial Firms Within The County
1-15-3: Urban Decay Tax Abatement
1-15-4: Residential Property Tax Abatement
1-15-1: PROPERTY TAX ABATEMENT WITHIN THE CITY:
The city authorizes and directs the county clerk to abate ad valorem taxes
imposed upon real estate described on description and plat attached to
ordinance 4927 and made a part hereof, located within the city, upon which new
improvements have been constructed or upon which existing improvements have
been renovated or rehabilitated, subject to the following conditions:
   A.   The improvements or renovations are of the scope and nature for which a
building permit is required and has been obtained;
   B.   Any abatement of taxes on any parcel shall not exceed the amount
attributable to the construction of the improvements and the renovation or
rehabilitation of existing improvements on such parcel;
   C.   Such abatement shall be allowed only for industrial or manufacturing
property located within the city;
   D.   Such abatement shall be at the rate of one hundred percent (100%) of
the value of the improvements for the assessment year in which the improvements
are made, and the three (3) assessment years immediately following the year in
which the improvements are made;
   E.   The abatements will apply to the assessed value at the time of approval
and the then current taxing rate. If there would be increases in the taxing
rate or reassessments done during the time of the abatement period which would
increase the assessed value, the business or industry would be responsible for
the taxes on the increases. (Ord. 4927, 7-24-1985)
1-15-2: PROPERTY TAX ABATEMENT FOR INDUSTRIAL FIRMS WITHIN THE COUNTY:
   A.   Length Of Abatement: The length of abatement will range from no
abatement to a maximum of four (4) years, considered on a firm by firm basis
using the following criteria as parameters:
      1.   New commercial or industrial firms locating, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value and an increase in the work force, maximum of
four (4) year abatement, minimum of three (3) year abatement.
      2.   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value and an increase in the work force, maximum of
four (4) year abatement, minimum of three (3) year abatement.
      3.   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value, no increase in the work force but retains
existing employees, maximum of three (3) year abatement, minimum of two (2)
year abatement.
      4.   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value and a reduction of the work force, maximum of
two (2) year abatement, minimum of no abatement.
   B.   Amount Of Abatement: As established by law, the total aggregate
abatement granted to any one industrial firm cannot exceed one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) over a ten (10) year period. Additionally, the city will
prorate the amount of abatement in the following manner:
      1.   New commercial or industrial firm locating, resulting in an increase
in the assessed value and an increase in the work force, maximum of one hundred
percent (100%) abatement on the increase in assessed value, minimum of fifty
percent (50%) abatement on the increase in assessed value.
      2.   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value and an increase in the work force, maximum of
one hundred percent (100%) abatement on the increase in assessed value, minimum
of fifty percent (50%) abatement on the increase in assessed value.
      3.   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value, no increase in the work force but retains
existing employees, maximum of seventy five percent (75%) abatement on the
increase in assessed value, minimum of twenty five percent (25%) abatement on
the increase in assessed value.
      4.   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value but a reduction in the work force, maximum of
fifty percent (50%) abatement in the increase in assessed value, minimum of
zero percent (0%) abatement.
The actual percentage of abatement granted will be considered on a firm by firm
basis with the following to be used for major determinants: current assessed
valuation, current number of employees, increase in assessed value due to
expansion and the actual number of employees added/retained.
   C.   Eligible Applicants: City property tax abatements will be considered on
the increase in assessed value for:
      1.   Any commercial or industrial firm locating in the City from another
county, state or country. The location of the new facility in the City by a
business already operating in Illinois will not be entitled to an abatement
unless it is clearly shown that the establishment of the business in Alton will
not result in the loss of employment at that business's other locations in the
State of Illinois for the term of the abatement;
      2.   Any commercial or industrial firm newly created within the State of
Illinois and locating in Alton; or
      3.   Existing Alton commercial or industrial firms that expand within the
City.
   D.   Eligible Areas: Any area zoned C-1 or higher within the City will be an
eligible area.
   E.   Guidelines For Consideration Of Request For Property Tax Abatement:
      1.   Abatements will apply to the increase in assessments only.
      2.   The length of abatements will range from four (4) years to no
abatement, with the City Council to determine the exact length using the
previously identified criteria.
      3.   The amount of abatement will range from one hundred percent (100%)
to zero percent (0%) with the City Council to determine the percentage amount
using the previously identified criteria.
      4.   An area zoned C-1 or higher within the City will be considered an
eligible area.
      5.   The total amount of all abatements shall not exceed fifteen percent
(15%) of the City's taxable industrial property value in any one year.
      6.   The requests to the Alton City Council for property tax abatement
will be considered on a priority of a first-come, first-served basis.
      7.   All requests to the Alton City Council for property tax abatement
should be made in writing and include the following information:
         a.   Name of firm.
         b.   Location of firm.
         c.   Phone number.
         d.   Name and title of person requesting abatement.
         e.   Brief explanation of firm's operations where abatement is being
requested.
         f.   Current number of employees at this location.
         g.   Current total assessed valuation at this location.
         h.   Copy of the firm's annual report, where the firm does an annual
report, unless waived by State or Federal law. Where subsidiary, annual report
of parent corporation.
         i.   If a corporation, the corporate registration number; if other
than a corporation, photocopy of registration certificate received from the
Madison County Clerk.
         j.   The total number of full-time and part-time employees hired,
added or retained as a result of the location/expansion including their
combined estimated annual payroll.
         k.   Total cost of the expansion/location.
         l.   Market area for products manufactured.
         m.   Projected impact on City businesses producing a similar or same
product or service.
         n.   Estimated amount of abatement being requested annually.
         o.   Length of abatement being requested.
         p.   Estimated total amount of abatement being requested.
         q.   Amount of abatements requested and granted in the past ten (10)
years within the City to include current year.
         r.   Additional information as may be requested by the City Council.
      8.   All applications shall be submitted to the City Council which shall
refer same to the Committee of the Whole for its recommendation. Same shall
then be forwarded to the Madison County Department of Community Development for
an advisory opinion and recommendations of the City Council.
   F.   Identification Of Firms By "Type":
      Type 1   New commercial or industrial firm locating, resulting in an
increase in the assessed value and an increase in the work force.
      Type 2   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in
an increase in the assessed value and an increase in the work force.
      Type 3   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in
an increase in the assessed value, no increase in the work force but retains
existing employees.
      Type 4   Existing commercial or industrial firm expanding, resulting in
an increase in assessed value but a reduction in the work force.
   G.   Maximum And Minimum Tax Abatement Ranges:
 
      Length          Amount
      Max.    Min.    Max. Min.
Type 1 4 years 3 years 100% 50%
Type 2 4 years 3 years 100% 50%
Type 3 3 years 2 years 75%  25%
Type 4 2 years 0 years 50%  0%
 
(Ord. 5011, 4-9-1986)
1-15-3: URBAN DECAY TAX ABATEMENT:
An Urban Decay Tax Abatement program is hereby created and the City authorizes
and directs the County Clerk to abate property taxes imposed on newly
constructed, owner occupied single-family and duplex residential dwellings in
the area known as the Hunterstown Redevelopment District. Such Urban Decay Tax
Abatement program is subject to the following conditions:
   A.   The Urban Decay Tax Abatement program shall only be allowed for newly
constructed, owner occupied single-family and duplex residential dwellings in
the area known as the Hunterstown Redevelopment District, as depicted by the
map attached to Ordinance 6140 on file in the City Clerk's office.
   B.   The Urban Decay Tax Abatement program shall be in effect for a period
of ten (10) years following the date of adoption.
   C.   Any eligible structure which has received a valid building permit
within the effective period of time for the program shall be entitled to
receive real property tax abatement upon all real property tax upon completion
of the structure in the following manner:
 
Year 1 through 6 100 percent abatement
Year 7           80 percent abatement
Year 8           60 percent abatement
Year 9           40 percent abatement
Year 10          20 percent abatement
 
   D.   The urban decay tax abatement shall be extended to all subsequent
owners of an eligible property during the abatement period. (Ord. 6140, 3-26-
1997)
1-15-4: RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY TAX ABATEMENT:
Within and upon certain real estate formerly utilized by the Madison County
housing authority as Sullivan Homes and Curran Homes, more particularly
described on exhibit A, attached to ordinance 6919 and by this reference made a
part hereof, as to any new improvements which may be constructed from and after
the effective date hereof, the city may authorize and direct the county clerk
to abate ad valorem taxes imposed upon the various parcels of real estate
therein located, subject to the following conditions:
   A.   The improvements are designed, constructed and maintained, for
residential purposes only;
   B.   Any abatement of taxes of any parcels pursuant to this section shall
not exceed the amount attributable to the construction of the improvements on
such parcel as may occur after the effective date hereof;
   C.   Such abatement shall be at the rate of one hundred percent (100%) of
the value of the improvements for the assessment year in which the improvements
are made, and for the four (4) assessment years immediately following the year
in which the improvements are made. The determination to authorize and direct
the county clerk to abate the ad valorem taxes for the properties and under the
conditions as aforesaid shall rest solely with the city council of the city of
Alton. The city council may, from time to time, direct that such taxes be
abated by way of a resolution specifically identifying the Madison County tax
parcel identification number on which such taxes are to be abated. (Ord. 6919,
11-9-2005)
CHAPTER 16
MUNICIPAL PROPERTY AND FUNCTIONS
SECTION:

1-16-1: CORPORATE SEAL:
A seal in a circular form, consisting of two (2) inscribed circles with a
device of a figure of justice seated at the foot of the bluffs, leaning on a
pillar, with scales poised, overlooking the river, on which a steamboat is
passing; the sun rising in the distance and an anchor at her feet, with the
word "Excelsior" beneath and the words "City of Alton, Illinois, 1837" in Roman
capitals engraved between the circles, shall be the Seal of the City, to be
used in all cases that have been or shall hereafter be provided by the laws of
the United States, the laws of the several respective states of the United
States and the ordinances of the City, and in all the cases in which, by the
laws and customs of nations, it is necessary to use a seal by a corporation.
(1961 Code § 1-12)
1-16-2: OFFICIAL FLAG:
The flag presented to the City by the Greater Alton Association of Commerce is
hereby adopted as the official flag of the City of Alton, Illinois. Said
official flag shall be displayed at such times and places as are appropriate
and the City Clerk is hereby designated as the official custodian of said flag.
(Ord. 3637, 1-27-1971)
CHAPTER 17
GIFT BAN
SECTION:
1-17-1: Short Title
1-17-2: Definitions
1-17-3: Gift Ban
1-17-4: Exceptions
1-17-5: Attendance At Events
1-17-6: Disposition Of Gifts
1-17-7: Reimbursement
1-17-8: Ethics Officer
1-17-9: Further Restrictions
1-17-10: Complaint Procedure
1-17-11: Enforcement
1-17-12: Penalty
1-17-1: SHORT TITLE:
This Chapter shall be entitled the GIFT BAN CODE OF THE CITY OF ALTON,
ILLINOIS. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the following definitions apply:
EMPLOYEE: All full-time and part-time employees, appointed and elected
officials, and directors of a governmental entity.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or
other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not
limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements
related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of
an employee, member, officer or judge.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
   A.   Is seeking official action: 1) by the public official or employee or 2)
in the case of an employee, by the employee or by public official or other
employee directing the employee;
   B.   Does business or seeks to do business: 1) with the public official or
employee or 2) in the case of an employee, with the public official or other
employee directing the employee;
   C.   Conducts activities regulated: 1) by the public official or employee or
2) in the case of any employee, by the public official or other employee
directing the employee;
   D.   Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or
nonperformance of the official duties of the public official or employee; or
   E.   Is registered or required to be registered with the Secretary of State
under the Lobbyist Registration Act. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-3: GIFT BAN:
Except as otherwise provided in this Chapter, no public official or employee
shall solicit or accept any gift from any prohibited source or in violation of
any Federal or State statute, rule or regulation. This ban applies to and
includes spouses of and immediate family living with such public official and
employee. No prohibited source shall offer or make a gift that violates this
Chapter. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-4: EXCEPTIONS:
The restriction in Section
1-17-3 of this Chapter does not apply to the following:
   A.   Market Value: Anything for which the public official or employee pays
the market value or anything not used and promptly disposed of as provided in
Section
1-17-6 of this Chapter.
   B.   Contribution: A contribution, as defined in article 9 of the State of
Illinois Election Code 1 , that is lawfully made under that Act or attendance
at a fundraising event sponsored by a political organization.
   C.   Gift: A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the
individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt,
great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law,
mother-in-law, son- in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law,
stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half
brother, half sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or
grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiancé or fiancée.
   D.   Personal Friendship: Anything provided by an individual on the basis of
a personal friendship unless the public official or employee has reason to
believe that, under the circumstances, the gift was provided because of the
official position or employment of the public official or employee and not
because of the personal friendship.
In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship,
the public official or employee shall consider the circumstances under which
the gift was offered, such as:
      1.   The history of the relationship between the individual giving the
gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts
between those individuals;
      2.   Whether to the actual knowledge of the public official or employee,
the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax
deduction or business reimbursement for the gift; and
      3.   Whether to the actual knowledge of the public official or employee
the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar
gifts to other public officials or employees.
   E.   Loan: A commercially reasonable loan evidenced in writing with
repayment due by a date certain made in the ordinary course of lender's
business.
   F.   Defense Fund: A contribution or other payments to a legal defense fund
established for the benefit of a public official or employee that is otherwise
lawfully made.
   G.   Intra-Office: For the purpose of this Chapter, "intra- office gifts"
means any gift given by one public official or employee of the City to another
official or employee.
   H.   Benefits: Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation and other
benefits:
      1.   Resulting from the outside business or employment activities (or
outside activities that are not connected to the duties of the public official
or employee) of the public official or employee or the spouse of a public
official or employee if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because
of the official position or employment of the public official or employee and
are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances;
      2.   Customarily provided by a prospective employer in connection with
bona fide employment discussions; or
      3.   Provided by a political organization in connection with a
fundraising or campaign event sponsored by that organization.
   I.   Pension: Pension and other benefits resulting from continued
participation in an employee welfare and benefits plan maintained by a former
employer.
   J.   Materials: Informational materials that are sent to the office of the
public official or employee in the form of books, articles, periodicals, other
written materials, audiotapes, videotapes, or other forms of communication.
   K.   Awards: Awards or prizes that are given to competitors in contests or
events open to the public, including random drawings.
   L.   Honorary Degree: Honorary degrees and associated travel, food,
refreshments, and entertainment provided in the presentation of degrees and
awards.
   M.   Training: Training (including food and refreshments furnished to all
attendees as an integral part of the training) provided to a public official or
employee, if the training is in the interest of the governmental entity.
   N.   Education: Educational missions, including meetings with government
officials either foreign or domestic, intended to educate public officials on
matters of public policy, to which the public official or employee may be
invited to participate along with other Federal, State or local public
officials and community leaders.
   O.   Inheritances: Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death.
   P.   Federal Government: Anything that is paid for by the Federal
Government, State or governmental entity, or secured by the government or
governmental entity under a government contract.
   Q.   Personal Hospitality: A gift of personal hospitality of an individual
other than a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal, including
hospitality extended for a nonbusiness purpose by an individual, not a
corporation or organization, at the personal residence of that individual or
the individual's family or on property or facilities owned by that individual
or the individual's family.
   R.   Attendance: Free attendance at a widely attended event permitted in
Section
1-17-5 of this Chapter.
   S.   Opportunities: Opportunities and benefits that are:
      1.   Available to the public or to a class consisting of all public
officials or employees, whether or not restricted on the basis of geographical
consideration;
      2.   Offered to members of a group or class in which membership is
unrelated to employment or official positions;
      3.   Offered to members of an organization such as an employee's
association or credit union, in which membership is related to employment or
official position and similar opportunities are available to large segments of
the public through organizations of similar size;
      4.   Offered to any group or class that is not defined in a manner that
specifically discriminates among government employees on the basis of branch of
government or type of responsibility, or on a basis that favors those of higher
rank or rate of pay;
      5.   In the form of loans from banks and other financial institutions on
terms generally available to the public; or
      6.   In the form of reduced membership or other fees for participation in
organization activities offered to all government employees by professional
organizations if the only restrictions on membership relate to professional
qualifications.
   T.   Commemorative Gift: A plaque, trophy, or other item that is
substantially commemorative in nature and that is extended for presentation.
   U.   Golf Or Tennis: Golf or tennis.
   V.   Promotional Products: Donations of products from an Illinois company
that are intended primarily for promotional purposes, such as display or free
distribution, and are of minimal value to any individual recipient.
   W.   Nominal Gift: An item of nominal value such as a greeting card,
baseball cap, or T-shirt.
   X.   Food: Food or refreshments of nominal value.
   Y.   Meals: Meals or beverages consumed on the premises on which they were
purchased.
   Z.   Catered Food: Catered food or refreshments. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
 
Notes
1 1. 10 ILCS (1996) 5/9.1 et seq.
1-17-5: ATTENDANCE AT EVENTS:
   A.   A public official or employee may accept an offer of free attendance at
a widely attended convention, conference, symposium, forum, panel discussion,
dinner, viewing, reception, or similar event, provided by the sponsor of the
event, if:
      1.   The public official or employee participates in the event as a
speaker or panel participant, by presenting information related to government,
or by performing a ceremonial function appropriate to the public official's or
employee's position or employment; or
      2.   Attendance at the event is appropriate to the performance of civic
affairs in Illinois or the official duties or representative function of the
public official or employee.
   B.   A public official or employee who attends an event described in
subsection A1 of this Section may accept a sponsor's unsolicited offer of free
attendance at the event for an accompanying individual.
   C.   A public official or employee, or the spouse or dependent thereof, may
accept a sponsor's unsolicited offer of free attendance at a charity event,
except that reimbursement for transportation and lodging may not be accepted in
connection with the event.
   D.   For purposes of this Section, the term "free attendance" may include
waiver of all or part of a conference or other fee, the provision of
transportation, or the provision of food, refreshments, entertainment, and
instructional materials furnished to all attendees as an integral part of the
event. The term does not include entertainment collateral to the event, nor
does it include food or refreshments taken other than in a group setting with
all or substantially all other attendees, except as otherwise authorized under
Section
1-17-4 of this Chapter. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-6: DISPOSITION OF GIFTS:
The recipient of a gift that is given in violation of this Chapter may, at his
or her discretion, return the item to the donor or give the item or an amount
equal to its value to an appropriate charity. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-7: REIMBURSEMENT:
   A.   A reimbursement (including payment in kind) to a public official or
employee from a private source other than a registered lobbyist or agent of a
foreign principal for necessary transportation, lodging, and related expenses
for travel to a meeting, speaking engagement, fact-finding trip, or similar
event in connection with the duties of the public official or employee as an
office holder or employee shall be deemed to be a reimbursement to the
governmental entity and not a gift prohibited by this Chapter if the public
official:
      1.   Discloses the expenses reimbursed and the authorization to the
Commissioner of Accounts and Finance, or similar authority as appropriate,
within thirty (30) days after the travel is completed; and
      2.   In the case of an employee, receives advance authorization from the
public official or other employee under whose direct supervision the employee
works to accept reimbursement.
   B.   For purposes of subsection A of this Section, events, the activities of
which are substantially recreational in nature, shall not be considered to be
in connection with the duties of a public official or employee.
   C.   Each advance authorization to accept reimbursement shall be signed by
the public official or other employee under whose direct supervision the
employee works and shall include:
      1.   The name of the employee;
      2.   The name of the person who will make the reimbursement;
      3.   The time, place and purpose of the travel; and
      4.   A determination that the travel is in connection with the duties of
the employee as an employee would not create the appearance that the employee
is using public employment for private gain.
   D.   Each disclosure made under subsection A1 of this Section of expenses
reimbursed or to be reimbursed shall be signed by the public official, in the
case of travel by the public official, or by the public official or other
employee under whose direct supervision the employee works, in the case of
travel by an employee, and shall include:
      1.   A good faith estimate of total transportation expenses reimbursed or
to be reimbursed;
      2.   A good faith estimate of total lodging expenses reimbursed or to be
reimbursed;
      3.   A good faith estimate of total meal expenses reimbursed or to be
reimbursed;
      4.   A good faith estimate of the total of other expenses reimbursed or
to be reimbursed;
      5.   A determination that all those expenses are necessary
transportation, lodging, and related expenses. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-8: ETHICS OFFICER:
The Mayor and City Council shall designate an Ethics Officer, who shall serve
without salary, and who shall:
   A.   Review statements of economic interest and disclosure forms of public
officials and employees before they are filed with the Madison County Clerk;
and
   B.   Provide guidance to public officials and employees in the
interpretation and implementation of this Chapter. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-9: FURTHER RESTRICTIONS:
The Mayor and City Council may adopt or maintain policies consistent with this
Chapter. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-10: COMPLAINT PROCEDURE:
Complaints alleging the violation of this Chapter shall be filed with the
Legislative Ethics Commission as provided by State law. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-1999)
1-17-11: ENFORCEMENT:
The Legislative Ethics Commission may recommend to the Mayor and City Council
disciplinary action against the person it determines to be in violation of this
Chapter. The recommendation may prescribe the following courses of action:
   A.   A reprimand.
   B.   To cease and desist the offensive action.
   C.   A return or refund of money or other items, or an amount of restitution
for services, received in violation of this Chapter.
   D.   Dismissal or removal from office.
   E.   Donation to a charity of an amount equal to the gift. (Ord. 6386, 5-13-
1999)
1-17-12: PENALTY:
Notwithstanding any other fine as prescribed by law and not by any way of
limitation thereof, any individual who knowingly violates any provision of this
Chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 6386, 5-13-
1999)
CHAPTER 18
ELIJAH P. LOVEJOY DAY
SECTION:
1-18-1: Elijah P. Lovejoy Day Proclaimed
1-18-1: ELIJAH P. LOVEJOY DAY PROCLAIMED:
That in recognition of the timeless principles for which Elijah P. Lovejoy
stood, and as an expression of hope that such principles shall always endure,
the City Council does hereby designate November 9 of each year as "Elijah P.
Lovejoy Day". The Council does hereby recommend and encourage all citizens of
the City to make such expressions of commemoration on said Elijah P. Lovejoy
Day as they may deem appropriate. (Ord. 6476, 4-26-2000)
CHAPTER 19
LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITY
SECTION:
1-19-1: Title
1-19-2: Scope
1-19-3: Definitions
1-19-4: Notices
1-19-5: Late Payment
1-19-6: Payment
1-19-7: Certain Credits And Refunds
1-19-8: Audit Procedure
1-19-9: Appeal
1-19-10: Hearing
1-19-11: Interest And Penalties
1-19-12: Abatement
1-19-13: Installment Contracts
1-19-14: Statute Of Limitations
1-19-15: Voluntary Disclosure
1-19-16: Publication Of Tax Ordinances
1-19-17: Review Procedure; Liens
1-19-18: Application
1-19-19: Severability
1-19-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as, and may be cited as, the LOCALLY IMPOSED AND
ADMINISTERED TAX RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITY ORDINANCE. (Ord. 6556, 2-14-2001)
1-19-2: SCOPE:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the city's procedures in
connection with all of the city's locally imposed and administered taxes. (Ord.
6556, 2-14-2001)
1-19-3: DEFINITIONS:
Certain words or terms herein shall have the meanings ascribed to them as
follows:
ACT: The "Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act".
CITY: The city of Alton, Illinois.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The city's mayor and city council.
HEARING OFFICER: An administrative individual appointed by the mayor with the
advice and consent of the corporate authorities to conduct hearings and to
issue final determinations regarding the collection of all locally imposed and
administered taxes.
LOCAL TAX ADMINISTRATOR: The city's treasurer is charged with the
administration and collection of the locally imposed and administered taxes,
including staff, employees or agents to the extent they are authorized by the
local tax administrator to act in the local tax administrator's stead. The
local tax administrator shall have the authority to implement the terms of this
chapter to give full effect to this chapter. The exercise of such authority by
the local tax administrator shall not be inconsistent with this chapter and the
act.
LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX OR TAX: Each tax imposed by the city that
is collected or administered by the city not an agency or department of the
