      1.   The history of the area;
      2.   Location of significant local, county, state, or national events in
the area;
      3.   Connection between the area and a person who significantly
contributed to the development of the community, county, state, or nation;
      4.   Census data of the area;
      5.   The number and location of churches and other houses of worship in
the area;
      6.   The number and location of locally owned businesses in the area;
      7.   The location of schools in the area;
      8.   The number and location of cultural institutions in the area;
      9.   The number and location of fraternal or service organizations in the
area;
      10.   Any national, state, or local migration patterns;
      11.   Patterns or history of segregation;
      12.   Patterns or history of land use;
   D.   Public Hearing Procedure and Appeal: The applicant and any business or
property owner in the area or resident in the area shall be entitled to speak
at the public hearing. The commission may accept comments from any other
interested person, group, or association. The commission shall review and
evaluate all available information. A record of the proceedings shall be made
and retained as a public record. The commission shall approve, deny, or modify
the requested designation within thirty (30) days after the public hearing. The
commission shall notify the applicant of its decision and such decision shall
be in writing. The applicant or a property owner(s) within the designated area
may appeal the commission's decision to the city council. A written notice of
such appeal must be filed with the City Clerk within fifteen (15) days after
the decision of the commission. The City Council, sitting in a quasi-judicial
capacity, shall review the record and may, in its sole discretion, allow new or
further evidence to be presented, and shall thereafter decide upon such appeal
within two (2) regular meetings after the filing of the appeal. The City Clerk
shall notify the applicant and any appealing property owner(s) of the City
Council's decision. Failure of the City Council to timely conduct such an
appeal hearing or render a decision not later than the conclusion of the next
regularly scheduled city council meeting following such a hearing, shall be
deemed to be for all intents and purposes a final order of affirmation of the
decision of the commission. The City Council's decision shall be deemed a
legislative decision of the City Council. (Ord. 7774, 9-10-2020)
CHAPTER 7
FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND BOARD
SECTION:
2-7-1: Firefighters' Pension Fund Created
2-7-2: Board Created; Members
2-7-3: Powers; Duties
2-7-4: Gifts; Grants
2-7-5: Disbursement Of Funds
2-7-6: Board Treasurer
2-7-7: Annual Report
2-7-1: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND CREATED:
There is hereby created a firefighters' pension fund to be administered as
provided in 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-101 et seq., as amended. (1973
Code)
2-7-2: BOARD CREATED; MEMBERS:
The firefighters' pension fund of the city of Alton shall be administered
pursuant to Illinois statutes by a board of trustees to be known as the "board
of trustees of the firefighters' pension fund". The board of trustees of the
firefighters' pension fund shall consist of five (5) members.
Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor. Two (2) members
of the board shall be active participants of the pension fund who are elected
from the active participants of the fund. One member of the board shall be a
person who is retired under the firemen's pension fund act of 1919 1  who is
elected from persons retired under the firemen's pension fund act of 1919 2 .
For the purposes of this section, a firefighter receiving a disability pension
shall be considered a retired firefighter. In the event that there are no
retired firefighters under the fund or if none is willing to serve on the
board, then an additional active firefighter shall be elected to the board in
lieu of the retired firefighter that would otherwise be elected.
If the regularly constituted fire department of the city of Alton is dissolved
and 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-106.1 is not applicable, the board shall
continue to exist and administer the fund so long as there continues to be any
annuitant or deferred pensioner in the fund. In such cases, elections shall
continue to be held as specified in this section, except that: a) deferred
pensioners shall be deemed to be active members for the purposes of such
elections; b) any otherwise unfillable positions on the board, including ex
officio positions shall be filled by election from the remaining firefighters
and deferred pensioners of the fund, to the extent possible; and c) if the
membership of the board falls below three (3) persons, the Illinois director of
insurance or his designee shall be deemed a member of the board, ex officio.
The members chosen from the active and retired firefighters shall be elected by
ballot at elections to be held on the third Monday in April of the applicable
years under the Australian ballot system, as such place or places, in the
municipality, and under such regulations as shall be prescribed by the board.
No person shall cast more than one vote for each candidate for whom he or she
is eligible to vote. In the elections for board members to be chosen from the
active firefighters, all active firefighters and no others may vote. In the
elections for board members to be chosen from retired firefighters, the retired
firefighters and no others may vote.
Each member of the board so elected shall hold office for a term of three (3)
years and until his or her successor has been duly elected and qualified.
The board shall canvass the ballots and declare which persons have been elected
and for what term or terms respectively. In case of a tie vote between two (2)
or more candidates, the board shall determine by lot which candidate or
candidates have been elected and for what term or terms respectively. In the
event of the failure, resignation, or inability to act of any board member, a
successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special election called
by the board and conducted in the same manner as a regular election.
The board shall elect annually from its members a president and secretary.
Board members shall not receive or have any right to receive any salary from a
pension fund for services performed as board members. (Ord. 7021, 9-26-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 40 ILCS 5/4-118 et seq.
2 2. 40 ILCS 5/4-118 et seq.
2-7-3: POWERS; DUTIES:
Said board shall have exclusive control and management of the funds provided by
this chapter, together with all moneys donated, paid, assessed or provided by
law for the relief or pension of disabled, superannuated and retired
firefighters, their widows and dependents, and said board shall assess each
firefighter a sum not to exceed one percent (1%) of the salary of said
firefighters, to be deducted by the city comptroller and withheld from the
monthly pay of each firefighter so assessed, which said sums shall be turned
over to the city treasurer for the fund herein, and together with all interest
accrued thereon to be placed by the city treasurer to the credit of said
pension fund, subject to the order of said board, and said board shall assess
five percent (5%) of an amount equal to the monthly salary or wages of each
firefighter attached to his rank at the time of his retirement after twenty
(20) years service which shall be paid monthly by said retired firefighter to
the city treasurer herein from the time of his retirement until said
firefighter shall reach the age of fifty (50) years.
The board herein created shall keep a record of its meetings and proceedings,
provide for its necessary expenses out of its own funds and make any necessary
rules and regulations for its government. (Ord. 1435, 2-28-1924)
2-7-4: GIFTS; GRANTS:
In addition to the sources of income hereinabove set forth, all rewards in
money, fees, gifts and prizes in money that may be paid or given for on account
of extraordinary service, or which may be raised by individual efforts of a
firefighter of the city, shall be paid into said pension fund.
The board of trustees herein shall have authority to take by gift, grant,
device or bequest any money, real estate or any valuable thing and also all
fines or penalties imposed upon firefighters. (Ord. 1435, 2-28-1924)
2-7-5: DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS:
The board of trustees herein shall have authority to provide for the payment of
said monthly sums as shall be provided by an act of the legislature of the
state of Illinois providing for and regulating the pensioning of disabled
firefighters.
Said board shall also have the power and authority to pay out said sums as may
be hereafter provided by law by the state of Illinois to the widow and minor
children of any firefighter who shall die from any cause while in service.
Said board shall also have authority to pay said sums as shall be provided by
law for pensions to firefighters who have served at least twenty (20) years of
active service and have reached the age of fifty (50) years. (Ord. 1435, 2-28-
1924)
2-7-6: BOARD TREASURER:
The city treasurer shall be ex officio treasurer of the board herein and shall
keep his books and accounts concerning said fund in a manner to be prescribed
by the board.
In addition to his regular bond as city treasurer, the treasurer of the fund
herein shall furnish a bond for the faithful performance of his duties in such
sum as the board shall direct, which said bond shall be filed in the office of
the city clerk after its approval by the board.
The city comptroller herein shall draw warrants upon the treasurer of said fund
under the direction or request in writing by said board for the payment of said
sums or funds as may properly be paid out. (Ord. 1435, 2-28-1924)
2-7-7: ANNUAL REPORT:
The board of trustees herein shall make an annual report of the condition of
the pension fund herein and of the amount of taxes necessary to be levied for
the carrying out of the provision of this chapter, which said report shall be
made on the first Monday of November. (Ord. 1435, 2-28-1924)
CHAPTER 8
POLICE PENSION FUND BOARD
SECTION:
2-8-1: Police Pension Fund Created
2-8-2: Board Established; Members
2-8-3: Powers And Duties
2-8-1: POLICE PENSION FUND CREATED:
There is hereby created a Police Pension Fund to be administered as provided in
40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq. (1973 Code)
2-8-2: BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS:
A board of five (5) members shall constitute a board of trustees to administer
the pension fund and to designate the beneficiaries thereof. The board shall be
known as the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund of the City.
Two (2) members of the Board shall be appointed by the Mayor. The third and
fourth members of the Board shall be elected from the active participants of
the pension fund by such active participants. The fifth member shall be elected
by and from the beneficiaries. (1999 Code)
2-8-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The said Board of Trustees shall decide when under the statute in such
case made and provided any individual shall be entitled to have relief or
pension under this Chapter, and the Board shall have further authority to pay
out sums of money as provided by law to the beneficiaries of such police
officers as may be entitled to relief or pension under said Act of the
Legislature.
   B.   The said Board of Trustees shall have exclusive control and management
of the fund or funds which shall herein be established by this Chapter and
under the statute referred to and they shall have power to appoint a clerk and
define his duties and to make all necessary rules and regulations for the
guidance of the said Board of the police officers in conformity with the
provisions of the statute in such case made and provided.
   C.   The said Board of Trustees shall have such other and further powers as
may be conferred upon them by said statute in such case made and provided, and
they shall also collect and keep in their fund or funds established by them all
such sums of money as authorized they should collect and keep. The said Board
shall elect officers, keep records and do all other things and acts they may
have the power to do mentioned in the said statute providing for the
establishing of the Police Pension Fund hereinbefore mentioned. Said Board of
Trustees shall make an annual report of the conditions of said Police Pension
Fund to the City Council, said report shall be made on the first Monday of
November each and every year after this Chapter goes into effect. (Ord. 1540,
2-1-1926)
CHAPTER 9
ALTON MUNICIPAL BAND
SECTION:
2-9-1: Establishment
2-9-2: Organization
2-9-3: Purpose, Duties And Reports
2-9-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
The Alton Municipal Band was established by the City of Alton no later than
1927 by ordinance 1627. The Alton Municipal Band has continued to serve the
citizens and residents of the City of Alton for many decades. The City Council
of the City of Alton, Illinois desires to facilitate the continuation of the
mission of the members of the Alton Municipal Band as they seek to serve their
fellow citizens by delivering free community concerts in City parks each year.
(Ord. 7565, 4-26-2017)
2-9-2: ORGANIZATION:
The Alton Municipal Band shall be organized and managed by a board composed of
no fewer than three (3) active members of the Alton Municipal Band. The members
of the board shall be appointed by the Mayor by and with the consent of the
City Council, from a slate of band members willing and able to serve on said
board. The terms of appointment shall be staggered as follows:
   A.   One member for a term of three (3) years, effective May 1, 2017;
   B.   One member for a term of two (2) years, effective May 1, 2017;
   C.   One or more members for a term of one year, effective May 1, 2017;
   D.   Annually thereafter the Mayor shall appoint by and with the consent of
the City Council, a member who shall hold his or her office for the term of
three (3) years, or until their successor is appointed and approved.
At the first meeting after it is established, the board shall set a regular
meeting schedule, as it may deem appropriate. Annually, the members of the
board shall elect one of their members as Chairman along with a Vice Chairman,
Secretary and Treasurer with each member serving in their respective office for
a one year term. One member may serve in no more than two (2) offices
simultaneously.
The Chairman shall communicate with the Mayor and City Council to apprise the
Mayor and City Council of the dates and locations of all of their concerts or
performances to be held throughout the year. All of the dates and locations of
concerts or performances by the Alton Municipal Band shall be posted on the
website maintained by the City of Alton and whenever possible not less than
fourteen (14) days prior to any concert or performance. (Ord. 7565, 4-26-2017)
2-9-3: PURPOSE, DUTIES AND REPORTS:
The Alton Municipal Band Board shall perform the following functions:
   A.   Oversee selection of persons to serve as members of the Alton Municipal
Band based upon their talents and willingness to serve. Members of the Alton
Municipal Band shall be considered to be independent contractors and in most
instances shall provide their own musical instruments. Members may be
compensated for their contributions to the Alton Municipal Band as-determined
by the Board of the Alton Municipal Band. Any member receiving any compensation
for his or her service to the Alton Municipal Band shall be required to
acknowledge in writing that they are an independent contractor and that they
are not an employee of the Alton Municipal Band or the City of Alton.
   B.   The Board of the Alton Municipal Band shall prepare and submit to the
City Council of the City of Alton, Illinois each fiscal year a copy of its
budget for the operation of the Alton Municipal Band showing anticipated
revenues and expenses. Following the fiscal year of the Alton Municipal Band,
the Board of the Alton Municipal Band shall submit to the City Council a report
of the actual revenues and actual expenses of the operation of the Alton
Municipal Band for the prior fiscal year. The Alton Municipal Band shall be
free to accept revenue from sources other than the City of Alton and shall be
free to perform other concerts or performances (in addition to the free
concerts and performances performed by the Alton Municipal Band for the benefit
of the residents of the City of Alton in the Alton City parks), so long as such
additional revenues and expenses are disclosed to the City Council of the City
of Alton by the aforesaid reports.
   C.   The City Council of the City of Alton, Illinois shall continue to fund
the Alton Municipal Band by way of the established tax levy as adopted in
ordinance 1627 by the citizens of Alton and endorsed each year by the City
Council of the City of Alton, Illinois. (Ord. 7565, 4-26-2017)
CHAPTER 10
APPEARANCE REVIEW COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-10-1: Definition
2-10-2: Commission Created
2-10-3: Members
2-10-4: Terms
2-10-5: Organization
2-10-6: Powers And Duties
2-10-7: Appearance Plan
2-10-8: Public Hearing
2-10-9: City Council To Adopt Plan
2-10-10: Permit; Certificate Of Approval
2-10-11: Issuance Of Certificate
2-10-12: Violation
2-10-13: Appeal
2-10-1: DEFINITION:
EXTERIOR DESIGN FEATURE: The general arrangement, scale and proportion of any
building, portion of a building, sign or structure and includes the kind, color
and texture of the building materials of such portion and the types and designs
of roof, windows, doors, lights, attached or ground signs and other
installations and fixtures pertinent to such portions as will be open to public
view from any street, place or way. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
2-10-2: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created an Appearance Review Commission, in and for the City.
(Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
2-10-3: MEMBERS:
The Appearance Review Commission, (hereinafter referred to as Commission) shall
consist of seven (7) members appointed by the Mayor by and with the advice and
consent of the City Council. Members of the Commission shall be of known
interest in community appearance. In making appointments to the Commission, the
Mayor shall seek to appoint as members persons who are recognized as
experienced in matters of aesthetic judgment by virtue of training, education,
experience and interest and possessing qualities of impartiality and broad
judgment. No member of the Commission shall participate in discussion or vote
on requests of a certificate of approval from any client he is serving or from
any business or property in which he has a substantial interest or of which he
is an officer or employee. (Ord. 5840, 12-22-1993)
2-10-4: TERMS:
The initial appointment of members of the Commission shall be two (2) for one
year, two (2) for two (2) years, and one for three (3) years. Thereafter, all
appointments shall be made for a term of four (4) years. Vacancies on said
Commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place has
become vacant in the same manner as provided in Section
2-10-2 of this Chapter. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
2-10-5: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   The Commission shall elect its own officers, which shall be a chairman,
vice chairman and secretary. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978; amd. Ord. 5840, 12-22-1993)
   B.   All meetings of the Commission shall be held at the call of the
chairman and at such other times as the Commission shall determine. Three (3)
members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum. A majority decision of
members of the presently appointed Board present at a duly constituted meeting
shall be required for all Commission actions. (Ord. 6091, 8-14-1996)
   C.   The Commission may adopt its own rules and procedures, not inconsistent
with this Chapter. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978; amd. Ord. 5840, 12-22-1993)
2-10-6: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   To hold public hearings on and make recommendations for an appearance
plan as provided hereafter. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
   B.   To consult with and cooperate with other commissions, City departments
and any other governmental bodies affecting the appearance of the Alton
Downtown and Broadway Area Redevelopment District. (Ord. 6027, 2-14-1996)
   C.   To study exterior design drawings, landscape, and site plans and
materials for any proposed public improvement in said district, and to make
recommendations to the City Council as to the architectural or aesthetic
aspects thereof.
   D.   To hold hearings, when required, on the issuance of certificates of
approval as provided hereinafter, in connection with questions pertaining to
applications for building and sign permits in said district and to issue or
deny said certificates pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 4297,
4-12-1978)
   E.   To hold hearings, when required by the guidelines of the Alton
Commercial Building Facade Program, on the issuance of certificates of approval
as provided hereinafter, in connection with applications to the said Program,
and to thereafter issue or deny certificates pursuant to the provisions of this
Chapter and the policies and guidelines referred to in this Chapter, without
regard to the location of any property which is the subject of such
application, if the same is within the City limits. (Ord. 5901, 8-10-1994)
2-10-7: APPEARANCE PLAN:
The Appearance Commission shall, within ninety (90) days after their
appointment, prepare a proposed appearance plan to apply to the Alton Downtown
and Broadway Area Redevelopment District, which district is set forth in the
legal descriptions, parcel descriptions, and drawings adopted by reference and
made a part of this Chapter as if set out in full. Said appearance plan shall
be based on the intent and purpose of this Chapter and shall consider, among
other things:
   A.   The exterior design features of proposed buildings, landscaping, and
site planning thereof.
   B.   The exterior design features of proposed renovation and repair of
existing buildings, including the landscaping and site planning thereof.
   C.   Existing City ordinances and regulations of the City. (Ord. 6027, 2-14-
1996)
2-10-8: PUBLIC HEARING:
After agreeing on a proposed appearance plan, the Commission shall hold a
public hearing thereon. A copy of the proposed plan shall be on file during the
regular business hours in the office of the City Clerk in the City Hall for
public inspection pending the conclusion of the public hearing. Notice of the
public hearing shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general
circulation in Alton, not more than thirty (30) and not less than fifteen (15)
days before the hearing. Within thirty (30) days after adjournment of the
public hearing, the Commission shall recommend a final appearance plan to the
City Council. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
2-10-9: CITY COUNCIL TO ADOPT PLAN:
The City Council shall, after the receipt of an approved appearance plan from
the Commission, consider same at a public meeting and may adopt the same in
whole or in part. The appearance plan, as finally approved, shall be adopted by
ordinance. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
2-10-10: PERMIT; CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL:
After the adoption of the appearance plan as set forth in this Chapter, the
Commission shall have regulatory powers over exterior architectural features of
buildings and structures within the district to which this Chapter applies. No
permit required of the ordinance of the City for a sign or for the erection,
construction, alteration or repair of any building or structure within the
district which involves an exterior design feature, as herein defined, shall be
issued by the Department of Public Works of the City, except upon the granting
of a certificate of approval by the Commission or by direction of the City
Council as hereinafter provided. If the Director of Public Works shall
determine that no exterior design feature as defined in this Chapter is
involved in the work for which the permit is sought in this district, such
permit may be issued without such certificate of approval. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-
1978)
2-10-11: ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE:
The following procedure is applicable for the issue of a certificate of
approval:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the Department of Public Works, after receipt
of an application for permit, to determine and advise the applicant whether,
under the provisions of this Chapter, a certificate of approval is required.
   B.   Any applicant or prospective applicant for a permit which may require a
certificate of approval, may file a written request for a preliminary
conference with the Commission. Said conference with the Commission shall be
held within twenty one (21) days of the receipt of the request or at the next
scheduled meeting of the Commission, whichever is sooner. At such conference,
the Commission shall give consideration to the exterior drawings, sketches or
photographic examples, landscapes and site plans and materials on a specific
project, and shall give the applicant its informal opinion to assist said
prospective applicant in the development of a plan which would be considered
with the requirements and purposes of the appearance plan in this Chapter.
   C.   Applicants for permits which require a certificate of approval as set
forth in this Chapter, shall apply for said certificate from the Commission.
Upon receipt of such application, the Commission shall schedule a meeting to be
held within twenty one (21) days and at such meeting the applicant shall be
given a hearing on such application.
      1.   At the time of the hearing, the applicant shall provide the
Commission with drawings which shall include plans and existing elevations,
site plans, landscaping, and screening plans, renderings and specifications of
signs, parking plans and the statement as to kind, color and texture of
materials. The Commission shall make recommendations as to changes in the
drawings, sketches, landscaping, site plan, materials and color, which, in the
judgment of the Commission, would tend to effect the general purposes of the
appearance plan.
      2.   After hearing and considering the material presented, the Commission
shall issue a certificate of approval if it finds that:
         a.   The applicants' plans are substantially consistent with the
appearance plan, and,
         b.   The proposed exterior design features of the development are so
compatible with the character of applicable district building structures
existing or which might be under construction and would contribute to the
valuable environment of the City, and,
         c.   The exterior design features of the development will not be
detrimental to the harmonious and orderly growth of the City, and,
         d.   The exterior design features of the development will not cause
any substantial depreciation in the property values or taxable values in the
district.
      3.   The Commission shall return its decision within the twenty one (21)
days after the conclusion of the hearing and shall notify the Department of
Public Works and the applicant of a certificate to the applicant, no permit
shall be issued on the application except by express direction of the City
Council upon appeal as hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
2-10-12: VIOLATION:
Upon the granting of a certificate, the exterior drawings, sketches, landscapes
and site plans, renderings and materials for whence the certificate was granted
would be turned over to the Director of Public Works, whose responsibility it
shall be to determine from time to time, as a project is in progress and
finally upon its completion, that there have been no deviations therefrom. Such
deviations shall constitute a violation of this Chapter and shall affect an
immediate revocation of the certificate and of the permit issued for such work.
(Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)
2-10-13: APPEAL:
In the event the Commission denies the certificate or fails to timely act as
hereinabove provided, the applicant shall have the right to appeal directly to
the City Council. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed within
thirty (30) days of the decision or within thirty (30) days of the failure by
the Commission to timely act. The City Council shall consider and decide upon
such appeal within two (2) regular meetings after the filing thereof. Upon such
appeal, all records and findings concerning the application shall be submitted
to the City Council by the Director of Public Works and by the Commission.
Thereupon, the City Council may:
   A.   Adopt a decision of the Commission, or,
   B.   Overrule or modify the decision of the Commission and direct the
issuance of a certificate, or,
   C.   In the event the Commission has failed to timely act as hereinabove
provided, direct or deny the issuance of a certificate. (Ord. 4297, 4-12-1978)

EXPOSITION COMMISSION

CHAPTER 15
POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITY SITING COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-15-1: Definitions
2-15-2: City Approval Of Pollution Control Facilities
2-15-3: Established; Committee Chairperson
2-15-4: Application
2-15-5: Findings; Recommendation To City Council
2-15-6: Articles Of Rules And Procedures
2-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
In addition to those terms defined in 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3 et
seq., the following terms are applicable to this chapter:
ACT: The Illinois environmental protection act, as amended 1 .
APPLICANT: Any person, firm or partnership, association, corporation, company
or organization of any kind.
CHAPTER: This chapter.
CITY: The city of Alton, Madison County, Illinois.
CITY COUNCIL: The duly elected corporate authorities of the city of Alton
pursuant to title 1, chapter 5 of this code.
COMMITTEE: The duly appointed Alton pollution control facility siting
committee.
COUNTY: Madison County, Illinois.
FACILITY: An Alton pollution control facility. (Ord. 6769, 9-24-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
2-15-2: CITY APPROVAL OF POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITIES:
No site approval for the development or construction of a new facility or
expansion of an existing facility within the city may be granted by the city
council unless an application is filed for approval of such a site and a public
hearing is held before the Alton pollution control facility siting committee.
The form of application is found in appendix A attached to ordinance 6769.
(Ord. 6769, 9-24-2003)
2-15-3: ESTABLISHED; COMMITTEE CHAIRPERSON:
The committee is hereby established and shall consist of three (3) council
members to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city
council. Committee members shall be appointed for each application received.
Any committee member who has, or feels he or she has any disqualifying interest
in the property of the proposed site or affairs of the applicant, may be
excused from participating in any siting hearing. With the advice and consent
of the city council, replacement appointees shall be appointed by the mayor.
The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall select a
chairperson for the committee. (Ord. 6769, 9-24-2003)
2-15-4: APPLICATION:
   A.   Filing Procedures: Fifteen (15) complete applications, accompanied by
the required filing fee shall be filed in the office of the city clerk of the
city of Alton for any proposed facility or the expansion of an existing
facility within the city. The application shall contain sufficient details
describing the proposed facility to demonstrate compliance, including all site
plans, exhibits and maps. The date an application, including the filing fee, is
filed with the city clerk shall be considered the official filing date for all
time limit purposes.
   B.   Filing Fee: A filing fee of two hundred fifty thousand dollars
($250,000.00), paid by a cashier's check, shall accompany an application. Said
fee shall be used by the city to defray any costs incurred by the city in
processing the application including, but not limited to: hearing officer(s),
court reporter, transcription services, public notice, building rental,
committee per diems (to be determined by the city council from time to time),
staff review, attorneys, city consultants (i.e., engineers, traffic experts,
land planners, and their tests, exhibits and testimony and travel expenses) and
any other relevant costs incidental to considering the application. The fee
shall also cover the city's costs of preparing a record sufficient to form the
basis of an appeal of the city council decision to the Illinois pollution
control board.
In the event the costs exceed the filing fee, the applicant shall pay to the
city an additional fee of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) within five (5)
business days of being notified of the deficiency. The city will send the
applicant regular invoices for the fees and costs incurred. In the event a
balance remains, the surplus funds will be returned to the applicant upon
written request of the applicant.
   C.   Amended Application: One amended application may be filed pursuant to
the act. In the event the applicant files an amendment, an additional deposit
of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) shall be filed with the amendment. The
fee shall be paid by a cashier's check.
   D.   Public Record: The application and all related documentation shall be
available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. Any request
for copies of the application and/or related documentation shall be made
available at the cost charged by the city for freedom of information act
requests.
   E.   Public Notice: The applicant shall be responsible for publishing any
required public notices and sending any notices required by 415 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/39.2. Proof of all notice requirements shall be filed with
the city clerk prior to the first hearing date.
   F.   Public Hearing: The committee will operate pursuant to the articles of
rules and procedures found in section
2-15-6 of this chapter. During the course of the public hearing before the
committee, all testimony shall be recorded. Testimony shall be received from
the applicant, the applicant's witnesses, any city witnesses and any other
witnesses or objectors. (Ord. 6769, 9-24-2003)
2-15-5: FINDINGS; RECOMMENDATION TO CITY COUNCIL:
   A.   After all testimony has been received and the written comment period
has expired, the committee shall submit its recommendation, in writing, to the
city council. Recommendations for approval shall be given only if the proposed
facility meets the criteria in 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/39.2.
   B.   Upon receipt of the committee's recommendation, which shall be
accompanied by a copy of the record of the public hearing, the city council
shall consider the application pursuant to the act. (Ord. 6769, 9-24-2003)
2-15-6: ARTICLES OF RULES AND PROCEDURES:
   A.   Rules And Procedures: The following rules and procedures are
supplementary to the act and shall govern the committee:
      1.   Chairperson Responsibilities And Duties: The chairperson shall
supervise the affairs of the committee, preside at all meetings subject to the
powers granted to the hearing officer(s) at a public hearing, set meeting and
hearing dates and times and decide points of order. The chairperson shall be
the only committee member to respond to written and verbal communications.
      2.   Acting Chairperson: In the absence of the chairperson, an acting
chairperson shall perform all the duties and exercise all the powers of the
chairperson.
      3.   Court Reporter: A court reporter shall be employed by the committee
and shall be present at all public hearings and shall provide the committee
with a certified transcript of the hearing as soon as possible.
      4.   Secretary: The city may employ a secretary to assist the hearing
officer(s) during the hearing process.
      5.   Meetings, Hearings, Quorum: All meetings and hearings of the
committee shall be pursuant to the open meetings act. One member present at any
meeting or hearing shall constitute a quorum. In the absence of the
chairperson, those members present shall elect one of their own as the acting
chairperson.
      6.   Hearing Officer: For any public hearing concerning an application
for site approval of a facility, the committee may appoint a hearing officer or
officers. The hearing officer shall serve at the pleasure of the committee.
      7.   Notices: Notice shall be given pursuant to this chapter and the act.
All notices shall contain the following information:
         a.   The name and address of the applicant requesting site location
approval.
         b.   The owner of the site; if ownership is in a land trust, the names
and addresses of the beneficiaries of the trust shall be stated.
         c.   The legal description of the site, street address and property
identification number(s) (PIN). If there is no street address, a description of
the site with reference to location, ownership or occupancy or in some other
manner that will reasonably identify the property.
         d.   The nature and size of the proposed facility.
         e.   The nature of the activity at the proposed facility.
         f.   The probable life of the proposed facility.
         g.   The date, time and location of the public hearing.
         h.   A statement that the application is available to the public in
the office of the city clerk and that copies of the application are available
for purchase at the cost charged by the city for freedom of information act
requests.
   B.   Conduct Of The Hearing:
      1.   The applicant shall have the burden of presenting evidence on the
suitability of the proposed site.
      2.   The applicant may appear on his/her behalf, or be represented by
counsel or agent at the hearing.
      3.   The committee shall hear testimony from the applicant and/or any
witnesses the applicant may call. Upon the close of the applicant's testimony,
evidence and any objectors, the city may present any witnesses and evidence it
may wish to present, unless the city is the applicant. The hearing officer
shall decide the order of the presentation of testimony subject to these rules.
      4.   All witnesses shall testify under oath. Testimony may include the
use of exhibits. All witnesses shall be subject to reasonable examination as
follows: direct, cross, redirect, recross, etc.
      5.   The hearing officer may exclude irrelevant, immaterial, incomplete
or unduly repetitious testimony or other evidence. The hearing officer shall
rule on all questions relating to the admissibility of evidence. These rulings
shall not be appealable to the city council.
   C.   Recommended Committee Hearing Procedure:
      1.   Call to order.
      2.   Introduction of the committee members and hearing officer(s).
      3.   Recognition of the applicant and identification of the application.
      4.   Recognition of fees, notices and the date the application was filed.
      5.   Recognition of the city and other parties wishing to present
evidence and/or cross examination. All parties wishing to present evidence or
cross examine any witnesses must sign in or submit written notification of said
intent in the office of the city clerk on or before the first date of the
hearing. If the hearing should extend beyond one session, no additional parties
shall be allowed to testify or cross examine.
      6.   Presentation of testimony.
      7.   Public comment, subject to limitations imposed by the hearing
officer.
      8.   Summary statements by the applicant, city and other parties, subject
to the limitations imposed by the hearing officer(s).
      9.   Adjourn and declare hearing closed.
   D.   Committee Recommendation: After the public hearing has adjourned the
committee shall hold a public meeting for making its recommendation to the city
council. No further evidence, testimony or input shall be received at the
meeting. Findings and the recommendation shall be pursuant to section
2-15-5 of this chapter.
   E.   Waiver Of Rules: In order to ensure fundamental fairness, compliance
with the act and to protect the public interest, the committee, by majority
vote of the members present and voting, may waive any of the rules and
procedures stated herein. (Ord. 6769, 9-24-2003)
CHAPTER 16
LINCOLN DOUGLAS DEBATE COMMITTEE
(Rep. by Ord. 7295, 1-11-2012)
CHAPTER 17
CLIMATE PROTECTION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-17-1: Committee Established; Members
2-17-2: Organization
2-17-3: Expenditures
2-17-1: COMMITTEE ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS:
There is hereby established a climate protection and energy efficiency
committee consisting of a chairman and not less than six (6) additional members
to be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the city council. All
members shall serve for a term of four (4) years or until their successors have
been duly appointed and qualified, except that as to the initial establishment
of the committee, four (4) members shall be appointed for a term of four (4)
years and three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. All
members of the committee shall serve without compensation. In making the
appointments to the committee, the mayor shall designate one appointee to serve
as chairman for the duration of his or her term. (Ord. 7092, 8-27-2008)
2-17-2: ORGANIZATION:
The climate protection and energy efficiency committee shall establish its own
schedule of meetings, organize and appoint such subcommittees as may be deemed
necessary, and conduct its business in such a manner as to progressively
approach the goals of climate protection and energy efficiency within the
government and jurisdiction of the city of Alton. All elected or appointed
officials of the city of Alton shall make themselves available to meet with the
committee and shall strive to cooperate with the goals of the committee. (Ord.
7092, 8-27-2008)
2-17-3: EXPENDITURES:
Any and all expenditure of municipal funds by the climate protection and energy
efficiency committee shall first be authorized and approved by the city
council. (Ord. 7092, 8-27-2008)
CHAPTER 18
HASKELL HOUSE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF ALTON COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-18-1: Commission Created
2-18-2: Authority
2-18-3: Responsibility To City Council
2-18-4: Accounts
2-18-5: Public Meetings
2-18-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby established the Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton
Commission, which shall be composed of seven (7) members, all appointed by the
Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council.
The first seven (7) members shall be appointed as aforesaid, with terms which
shall be as follows: three (3) members for the term of three (3) years, two (2)
members for the term of two (2) years and two (2) members for a term of one
year. Annually thereafter, upon the expiration of each respective member's
term, members shall be appointed to serve three (3) year terms. Notwithstanding
the foregoing, all members shall continue to serve until such time as their
respective successors are appointed and qualified unless removed by the Mayor.
The Mayor shall have the authority to remove any member of the commission at
any time for reasons cited by the Mayor in his request to the City Council to
approve a resolution of removal of a member of the commission, which shall be
effective upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Aldermen present at a City
Council meeting. (Ord. 7584, 10-11-2017)
2-18-2: AUTHORITY:
The Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton Commission shall have the
authority to supervise the management of the Haskell House Children's Museum
and to coordinate the efforts of the various departments of the City of Alton
to promote the utilization of the Haskell House Children's Museum in a manner
consistent with the original mission of establishing and maintaining the
Haskell House Children's Museum. The Haskell House Children's Museum Commission
shall require approval by the City Council before entering into any contracts
of any type and to authorize expending any fund of the City of Alton. (Ord.
7584, 10-11-2017)
2-18-3: RESPONSIBILITY TO CITY COUNCIL:
The Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton Commission shall be an entity
created by and responsible to the City Council of the City of Alton, Illinois.
The Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton Commission shall abide by any
directives as may be established by resolution of the City Council of the City
of Alton as may be adopted from time to time. (Ord. 7584, 10-11-2017)
2-18-4: ACCOUNTS:
The Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton Commission shall account for all
funds received and disbursed in the performance of its duties and
responsibilities. The City Comptroller and the City Treasurer of the City of
Alton shall coordinate with the members of the Haskell House Children's Museum
of Alton Commission so as to permit continuous transparency of the financial
records of the Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton Commission to the City
Treasurer and the City Comptroller and through them to the City Council of the
City of Alton and through them to the general public. Any assets acquired by
the Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton Commission or in their name shall
be the Municipal property of the City of Alton, managed and disposed of in
accordance with all applicable rules, ordinances and statutory requirements
pertaining to Municipal property.
All financial accounts of the Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton
Commission shall be included in the annual audit of the City of Alton. (Ord.
7584, 10-11-2017)
2-18-5: PUBLIC MEETINGS:
All meetings of the Haskell House Children's Museum of Alton Commission shall
be considered public meetings and shall be held in accordance with the
requirements of the Public Meetings Act of the State of Illinois. (Ord. 7584,
10-11-2017)
CHAPTER 19
RIVERFRONT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-19-1: Establishment; Term Of Members
2-19-2: Purpose
2-19-3: Organization
2-19-4: Expenditures And Reporting
2-19-1: ESTABLISHMENT; TERM OF MEMBERS:
   A.   There is hereby established a Riverfront Commission, which shall be
composed of seven (7) members, all appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and
consent of the City Council.
   B.   The first seven (7) members shall be appointed as aforesaid, with terms
which shall be as follows: three (3) members for the term of three (3) years,
two (2) members for the term of two (2) years and two (2) members for a term of
one year. Annually thereafter, upon the expiration of each respective member's
term, members shall be appointed to serve three (3) year terms.
   C.   Membership of the Commission shall be composed of an ex-officio member
of the City Council and representation from the land development industry,
finance and business, river industry, tourism and recreation, the riverfront
casino, public safety and a public at large member.
   D.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, all members shall continue to serve
until such time as their respective successors are appointed and qualified
unless removed by the Mayor. The Mayor shall have the authority to remove any
member of the commission at any time for reasons cited by the Mayor in his
request to the City Council to approve a resolution of removal of a member of
the Commission, which shall be effective upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the
Aldermen or Alderwomen present at a City Council meeting.
   E.   The said members shall organize and shall elect one of their number
president and may elect one vice president, one secretary and one treasurer, or
such officers as they, by resolution, may deem appropriate, who shall hold
their respective offices for the term of one year, or until their successors
are duly elected and qualified. (Ord. 7848, 7-13-2022)
2-19-2: PURPOSE:
The Riverfront Commission will be charged and authorized to:
   A.   Provide for administrative briefings on the status of riverfront
development and redevelopment progress in Alton and within an area of the City
limits of Alton along its riverfront and elsewhere and to research information
and materials from other riverfront communities and development in the region
and along the Mississippi River.
   B.   Provide suggestions, options and feedback to the intended to further
develop the design of the riverfront that supports, enhances, and grows the
facilities, programs, and services of the City of Alton in a fiscally
responsible manner that meets community needs.
   C.   Engage with members of the public to ensure that all parties in
community, as well as regional stakeholders, have an opportunity to participate
in the stewardship and future development of Alton riverfront in a meaningful
way.
   D.   Review and provide feedback on Land Use Regulations, ordinances and
other such policy changes that affect the riverfront and other areas referred
to the Commission for review and comment.
   E.   Work with the Mayor and City Council and the US Army Corps of Engineers
to develop a Riverfront Strategic Plan and to engage the public soliciting
input that will inform the overarching design, development, and management of a
plan for the Alton Riverfront and to also provide for an evaluation of any
current and or previous recommendations made towards its development or
redevelopment. (Ord. 7848, 7-13-2022)
2-19-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   The Riverfront Commission shall establish its own schedule of meetings,
organize and appoint such subcommittees as may be deemed necessary, and conduct
its business in such a manner as to progressively approach the goals of
Riverfront Development within the government and jurisdiction of the city of
Alton.
   B.   In the performance of their responsibilities the commission and its
members shall abide by the Illinois open meetings act and the commission shall
be considered a "public body" for all legal purposes. (Ord. 7848, 7-13-2022)
2-19-4: EXPENDITURES AND REPORTING:
   A.   Any and all expenditure of municipal funds by the Riverfront Commission
shall first be authorized and approved by the city council.
   B.   The Commission and its members shall have no authority to incur any
financial obligations of any kind in the name of the city without prior
approval of the mayor and city council as to any specific item or expense.
   C.   Where the Commission wishes to make a recommendation or provide advice
to the City Council, the matter will be submitted and considered through City
staff under the City Council's agenda review and approvals process. Any
requests by the Commission to provide recommendations and advice for
presentation to the Council will be approved at the City's discretion.
   D.   On a quarterly basis, the Commission will also work with the municipal
administration to prepare a quarterly report to Council summarizing its
progress and provide any other reports as requested by the City Council as
requested. (Ord. 7848, 7-13-2022)
TITLE 3
DEPARTMENTS
CHAPTER 1
PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-1-1: Department Established
3-1-2: Public Works Director
3-1-3: Street Division
3-1-4: Sewer Division
3-1-5: Reserved
3-1-6: Equipment Services Division
3-1-7: Nuisance Abatement Division
3-1-8: Engineering Division
3-1-9: Park Maintenance Director
3-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a public works department in the city of Alton.
(Ord. 7232, 12-15-2010)
3-1-2: PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR:
   A.   The public works director shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with
the consent of the city council. He shall be qualified by education, training,
and experience applicable to municipal public works functions. A temporary
public works director may be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the
city council, as deemed appropriate from time to time in the absence of a
permanent public works director, and a temporary public works director need not
have the full qualifications required of a permanent public works director. A
temporary public works director shall serve in office no longer than six (6)
consecutive months without reappointment and approval by the city council.
   B.   The duties of the public works director shall be as follows:
      1.   To perform the administrative functions of the public works
department through appropriate staff.
      2.   To generally oversee the operations of the street division, the
sewer division, the park maintenance division, the equipment services division,
the nuisance abatement division, and the engineering division.
      3.   To issue permits for the excavation into or the disturbance of any
public street, alley, or other public property not under the control of the
parks and recreation commission or any other commission designated by the city
council.
      4.   To review all contracts, plans, or specifications that pertain to
any repair, maintenance or construction projects involving expenditures of city
funds or in part controlled by city authority. No city funds or city authority
shall be exercised in connection with said contracts, plans or specifications
without the prior written approval of the public works director. The review of
said contracts, plans, or specifications by the public works director shall be
limited to assuring the technical and professional aspects of said contracts,
plans, or specifications so that the overall objective sought by each project
will be reasonably fulfilled.
      5.   Such other duties as may be assigned by the mayor or by city of
Alton ordinance from time to time.
      6.   To assign all equipment and personnel in the public works
department.
      7.   To utilize any public works department equipment and personnel in
emergency situations as needed. (Ord. 7232, 12-15-2010; amd. Ord. 7768, 8-13-
2020)
3-1-3: STREET DIVISION:
   A.   The street division shall operate as a separate division of the public
works department under the direction of the public works director. The duties
of the street division shall be assigned by the street maintenance operations
supervisor, and they shall include, but not be limited to, the maintenance of
all city streets and alleys located on public right of way or easements.
   B.   The street maintenance operations supervisor shall be qualified by
education, knowledge, and experience in the maintenance and construction of
streets and alleys. The street maintenance operations supervisor shall be
employed under the civil service regulations of the city of Alton. (Ord. 7232,
12-15-2010)
3-1-4: SEWER DIVISION:
   A.   The sewer division shall operate as a separate division of the public
works department under the direction of the public works director. The duties
of the sewer division shall be assigned by the sewer maintenance operations
supervisor, and they shall include, but not be limited to, the maintenance and
operation of all city storm sewers located on public right of way or easements.
   B.   The sewer maintenance operations supervisor shall be qualified by
education, knowledge, and experience in the maintenance, construction, and
operation storm sewers. The sewer maintenance operations supervisor shall be
employed under the civil service regulations of the City of Alton. (Ord. 7232,
12-15-2010; amd. Ord. 7768, 8-13-2020)
3-1-5: RESERVED:
(Reserved by Ord. 7768, 8-13-2020)
3-1-6: EQUIPMENT SERVICES DIVISION:
   A.   The equipment services division shall operate as a separate division of
the public works department under the direction of the public works director.
The duties of the equipment services division shall be assigned by the
equipment maintenance operations supervisor, and they shall include, but not be
limited to, the operation of the city garage; the repair and maintenance of
city vehicles and equipment; and the storage and utilization of fuel and other
supplies with regard to city equipment.
   B.   The equipment maintenance operations supervisor shall be qualified by
education, knowledge, and experience in the maintenance and operation of
municipal equipment. The equipment maintenance operations supervisor shall be
employed under the civil service regulations of the city of Alton. (Ord. 7232,
12-15-2010)
3-1-7: NUISANCE ABATEMENT DIVISION:
   A.   The nuisance abatement division shall operate as a separate division of
the public works department under the direction of the public works director.
The duties of the nuisance abatement division shall be assigned by the nuisance
abatement supervisor, and they shall include, but not be limited to, the
enforcement of all animal control ordinances adopted by the city council; the
mowing of grass and other vegetation on public right of way, easements, or
other city property; the cleanup of litter on public right of way, easements,
or other city property; and the abatement of other public nuisances as may be
assigned by the public works director or by city of Alton ordinance from time
to time.
   B.   The nuisance abatement supervisor shall be qualified by education,
knowledge, and experience in the abatement of public nuisances. The nuisance
abatement supervisor shall be employed under the civil service regulations of
the city of Alton. (Ord. 7232, 12-15-2010)
3-1-8: ENGINEERING DIVISION:
   A.   The engineering division shall operate as a separate division of the
public works department under the direction of the public works director. The
duties of the engineering division shall be assigned by the city engineer, and
they shall include, but not be limited to, the review of all subdivision plats
and plans submitted to the city council and city plan commission, and
recommendations thereon; the study and recommendations of all plans and/or
other data submitted by consulting firms or others dealing with all public
property improvements; the preparation of and recommendation on the annual
budget for motor fuel tax expenditures; and providing assistance to the public
works director in all other areas of the public works department where
necessary.
   B.   The city engineer shall be a qualified engineer with a degree in civil
engineering from an accredited college or university. The city engineer shall
be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the city council. The
city engineer may be designated as an employee of the city, with the rights and
responsibilities of the personnel policies of the city, or as a consultant on a
contractual basis to be agreed upon by the engineer and the city.
   C.   A temporary city engineer may be appointed by the mayor, with the
consent of the city council, as deemed appropriate from time to time in the
absence of a permanent city engineer, and a temporary city engineer need not
have the full qualifications required of a permanent city engineer. A temporary
city engineer shall serve in office no longer than six (6) consecutive months
without reappointment and approval by the city council. (Ord. 7232, 12-15-2010)
3-1-9: PARK MAINTENANCE DIRECTOR:
A park maintenance director shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the
consent of the city council. The park maintenance director shall supervise the
maintenance and control of all public parks, public squares, playgrounds,
buildings and improvements thereon which constitute the parks and common
grounds of the city. The park maintenance director shall be the responsible
party for the day to day administration and supervision of the various
employees and equipment utilized in the maintenance and improvement of the city
parks and improvements thereon. The park maintenance director shall be
qualified by education, knowledge and experience to organize and administer the
activities determined to be appropriate by the director of public works to
carry out the city's responsibilities to maintain and improve the city's parks
and shall coordinate his activities and efforts with the executive director and
the recreation director of the parks and recreation department of the city of
Alton. (Ord. 7411, 6-11-2014)
ARTICLE A. CODE HEARING UNIT 1
SECTION:
3-1A-1: Unit Established
3-1A-2: Purpose
3-1A-3: Hearing Officer
3-1A-4: Administration
3-1A-5: Administrative Hearing Proceedings
3-1A-6: Service Of Violation Notices
3-1A-7: Additional Notice
3-1A-8: Final Determination
3-1A-9: Administrative Review
3-1A-10: Enforcement Of Judgment
3-1A-11: Petition To Set Aside
3-1A-12: Schedule Of Civil Fines
3-1A-13: Defenses To Certain Violations
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., 5/11-31.1-1 et seq.; 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3.
3-1A-1: UNIT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a division of the Department of Public Works of the
City of Alton to be known as the Alton Code Hearing Unit. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-
1998)
3-1A-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the Code Hearing Unit shall be to expedite the fair and
efficient prosecution, adjudication and correction of code violations, thereby
enforcing compliance with the ordinances of the City now in effect and as may
hereafter be enacted, through a system of administrative adjudications. The
jurisdiction of the Code Hearing Unit shall encompass the adjudication of any
violation of any municipal ordinance to the fullest extent permitted by the
constitution and laws of the State. Currently 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
1-2.1-2 excepts therefrom: a) proceedings not within the statutory or home rule
authority of municipalities, and b) any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code
or a similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of
vehicles and except for any reportable offense under 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 6/16-204. The adoption of this system of administrative adjudication
shall not preclude the City from using other methods to enforce municipal
ordinances. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-3: HEARING OFFICER:
   A.   The Code Hearing Unit shall provide for adjudicatory hearings which
shall be presided over by a hearing officer, who shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the advice and consent of the City Council.
   B.   The powers and duties of a hearing officer shall include the following:
      1.   Administering oaths, hearing testimony and accepting evidence that
is relevant to the existence of the code violation;
      2.   Issuing subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony at the hearing, upon the request of the parties or their
representatives;
      3.   Preserving and authenticating the record of the hearing and all
exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
      4.   Issuing a written finding of fact, decision, and order, determining
on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing whether a code violation
exists and if so, determining the fine, penalty or action with which the
defendant must comply;
      5.   Imposing penalties consistent with applicable code provisions and
assessing costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation, except
that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to impose a penalty
of incarceration or a fine in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00),
exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance, except
that in cases to enforce the collection of a tax there shall be no maximum
limit on fines.
   C.   Every administrative hearing officer must be an attorney licensed to
practice law in the State for at least three (3) years and prior to appointment
must have successfully completed the formal training program of Kathleen Field
Orr, Scariana, Kula, Ellch and Himes, which includes the following:
      1.   Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings
which the hearing officer will conduct;
      2.   Orientation to each subject area of the code violations which the
hearing officer will adjudicate;
      3.   Observation of administrative hearings; and
      4.   Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence
and issuing final orders.
No hearing officer shall be precluded from engaging in the general practice of
law in any matters not hostile to the interest of the City. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-
1998)
3-1A-4: ADMINISTRATION:
The Code Hearing Unit shall have the powers and duties to administer the system
of administrative adjudication, including the docketing of cases; maintaining
records and case files; adopting, distributing, processing, issuing, and
serving notices; cooperating with the City Treasurer to assess, collect,
receipt for, and account for fines and penalties to be collected; referring
unpaid fines and penalties to appropriate agencies for collection and
enforcement, when necessary; and preserving order and decorum in and around the
hearing room. The Code Hearing Unit is authorized to promulgate such rules,
regulations, forms, and standard operating procedures as are reasonably
required to operate and administer the administrative adjudication system
hereby created, and they shall be published and kept on file in the office of
the Director where they shall be available to the public for inspection and
copying during normal business hours. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-5: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING PROCEEDINGS:
This system of administrative adjudication shall afford parties due process of
law, including notice and opportunity for a hearing during which they may be
represented by counsel, present witnesses, and cross-examine opposing
witnesses. Parties may request the hearing officer to issue subpoenas to direct
the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses and the production of
relevant documents.
   A.   Hearings shall be scheduled with reasonable promptness, provided that
for hearings scheduled in all nonemergency situations, if requested by the
defendant, the defendant shall have at least fifteen (15) days after service of
process to prepare for a hearing. For purposes of this subsection,
"nonemergency situation" means any situation that does not reasonably
constitute a threat to the public interest, safety, or welfare. If service is
provided by mail, the fifteen (15) day period shall begin to run on the date
that the notice is deposited in the mail.
   B.   A proceeding before a code hearing officer shall be instituted upon the
filing of a written pleading by an authorized official of the City.
      1.   When a Building Inspector finds a code violation while inspecting a
structure, he shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and
report form, indicating the name and address of the structure owner, the type
and nature of the violation, the date and time the violation was observed, the
names of witnesses to the violation, and the address of the structure where the
violation is observed.
      2.   A parking, standing or compliance violation notice ("compliance
violation" means a violation of a municipal regulation governing the condition
or use of equipment on a vehicle or governing the display of a municipal wheel
tax license) shall specify the date, time and place of violation of parking,
standing, or compliance regulation; the particular regulation violated; the
fine and any penalty that may be assessed for late payment, when so provided by
ordinance; the vehicle make and state registration number; and the
identification number of the person issuing the notice. The violation notice
shall state that the payment of the indicated fine, and of any applicable
penalty for late payment, shall operate as a final disposition of the
violation. The notice also shall contain information as to availability of a
hearing in which the violation may be contested on its merits. The violation
notice shall specify the time and manner in which a hearing may be had.
      3.   Any other code violation may be charged by means of a multiple copy
violation notice and report form which identifies the person or entity charged
and includes the type and nature of the code violation to be adjudicated, the
date and location of the adjudicatory hearing, the legal authority and
jurisdiction under which the hearing is to be held, and the penalties for
failure to appear at the hearing.
   C.   The formal and technical rules of evidence do not apply in an
adjudicatory hearing. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it
is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct
of their affairs.
   D.   A person authorized to issue and serve violation notices shall certify
the correctness of the facts entered on the violation notice by signing his
name to the notice at the time of service or in the case of a notice produced
by a computerized device, by signing a single certificate to be kept by the
Code Hearing Unit attesting to the correctness of all notices produced by the
device while it was under his control. The original or a facsimile of the
violation notice shall be retained by the Code Hearing Unit and shall be a
record kept in the ordinary course of business. A violation notice issued,
signed and served in accordance with this Section, or a copy of the notice,
shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the
correctness of the facts shown on the notice. The notice or copy shall be
admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal proceedings.
   E.   No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer except in
cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the
defendant. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any
continuance authorized by a hearing officer shall not exceed twenty five (25)
days. The case for the City may be presented by the Building Inspector, by any
other municipal employee or by an attorney designated by the City. However, in
no event shall the case for the City be presented by an employee of the Code
Hearing Unit. The case for the dwelling owner may be presented by the owner,
his attorney, or any other agent or representative.
   F.   To the extent reasonably possible, cases of alleged building code
violations shall be heard not less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40)
days after the violation is reported.
   G.   Persons who are not residents of the City may contest the merits of an
alleged parking, standing or compliance violation without attending a hearing
by filing with the Code Hearing Unit an entry of appearance and affidavit duly
signed and stating the person's name, address, and grounds for contesting the
allegations. The hearing officer shall consider the affidavit of such a
nonresident in the same way as if the same testimony were given in person.
   H.   If on the date set for hearing the party or his attorney fails to
appear, the hearing officer may find the defendant in default and shall proceed
with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code
violation.
   I.   At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a
determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing whether or
not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be
designated as findings, decision and order. The findings, decision and order
shall include the hearing officer's findings of fact, a decision whether or not
a code violation exists based upon the findings of fact, and an order, ordering
the owner to correct the violation or dismissing the case in the event a
violation is not proved. If a code violation is proved, the order may also
impose the sanctions that are provided in the code for the violation proved. A
copy of the findings, decision and order shall be served on the owner within
five (5) days after they are issued. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-6: SERVICE OF VIOLATION NOTICES:
Parties shall be served with process in a manner reasonably calculated to give
them actual notice.
   A.   Methods of service shall include as appropriate, personal service of
process upon a party or its employees or agents; service by mail at a party's
address; or notice that is posted upon the property where the violation is
found when the party is the owner or manager of the property when such posting
is not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is scheduled.
   B.   A parking, standing or compliance violation notice may be served by
affixing the original or a facsimile of the notice to an unlawfully parked
vehicle or by handing the notice to the operator of a vehicle if he is present.
(Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-7: ADDITIONAL NOTICE:
Service of additional notices may be sent by first class United States mail,
postage prepaid, to the address of the registered owner of the cited vehicle as
recorded with the Secretary of State or, under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-1306, to the lessee of the cited vehicle at the last address known to the
lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of lease. The service shall be deemed
complete as of the date of deposit in the United States mail. The notices shall
be in the following sequence and shall include, but not be limited to, the
information specified herein:
   A.   A second notice of violation shall specify the date and location of the
violation cited in the parking, standing, or compliance violation notice, the
particular regulation violated, the vehicle make and state registration number,
the fine and any penalty that may be assessed for late payment when so provided
by ordinance, the availability of a hearing in which the violation may be
contested on its merits, and the time and manner in which the hearing may be
had. The notice of violation shall also state that failure either to pay the
indicated fine and any applicable penalty, or to appear at a hearing on the
merits in the time and manner specified, will result in a final determination
of violation liability for the cited violation in the amount of the fine or
penalty indicated, and that, upon the occurrence of a final determination of
violation liability for the failure, and the exhaustion of, or failure to
exhaust, available administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid
fine or penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the City.
   B.   A notice of final determination of parking, standing, or compliance
violation liability shall be sent following a final determination of parking,
standing, or compliance violation liability and the conclusion of judicial
review procedures. The notice shall state that the unpaid fine or penalty is a
debt due and owing the City. The notice shall contain warnings that failure to
pay any fine or penalty due and owing the City within the time specified may
result in the City's filing of a petition in the Circuit Court to have the
unpaid fine or penalty rendered a judgment or may result in suspension of the
person's driver's license for failure to pay fines or penalties for ten (10) or
more parking violations under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5.
   C.   A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to the
person liable for any fine or penalty that remains due and owing on ten (10) or
more parking violations. The notice shall state that failure to pay the fine or
penalty owing within forty five (45) days of the notice's date will result in
the City notifying the Secretary of State that the person is eligible for
initiation of suspension proceedings under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-
306.5. The notice shall also state that the person may obtain a photostatic
copy of an original ticket imposing a fine or penalty by sending a self-
addressed, stamped envelope to the City along with a request for the
photostatic copy. The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be
sent by first class United States mail, postage prepaid, to the address
recorded with the Secretary of State. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-8: FINAL DETERMINATION:
A final determination of violation liability shall occur following failure to
pay the fine or penalty after a hearing officer's determination of violation
liability and the exhaustion of or failure to exhaust any administrative review
procedures provided by ordinance. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing
to contest the alleged violation in the time and manner specified in a prior
mailed notice, the hearing officer's determination of violation liability shall
become final: a) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that
determination, or b) upon expiration of the period for filing the petition
without a filing having been made. A judgment entered by default may be set
aside and a new hearing ordered upon a petition to set aside if it is filed
within twenty one (21) days after the judgment and if it establishes good cause
for the defendant's failure to appear. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-9: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW:
The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be subject to
review in the circuit court of the county where the City is located, and the
provisions of the Administrative Review Law, and all amendments and
modifications thereto, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto are adopted and
shall apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the final
findings, decision and order of a hearing officer. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-10: ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENT:
   A.   Any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other
sanction, or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of or the
failure to exhaust judicial review procedures under the Illinois Administrative
Review Law are a debt due and owing the City and may be collected in accordance
with applicable law.
   B.   After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the
Illinois Administrative Review Law may be sought for a final determination of a
code violation, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the
findings, decision, and order of the hearing officer may be enforced in the
same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
   C.   In any case in which a defendant has failed to comply with a judgment
ordering a defendant to correct a code violation or imposing any fine or other
sanction as a result of a code violation, any expenses incurred by a
municipality to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney
fees, court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure,
after they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer,
shall be a debt due and owing the city and may be collected in accordance with
applicable law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a hearing officer pursuant
to this subsection C, the city shall provide notice to the defendant that
states that the defendant shall appear at a hearing before the administrative
hearing officer to determine whether the defendant has failed to comply with
the judgment. The notice shall set the date for such a hearing, which shall not
be less than seven (7) days from the date that notice is served. If notice is
served by mail, the seven (7) day period shall begin to run on the date that
the notice was deposited in the mail.
   D.   Upon being recorded in the manner required by article XII of the code
of civil procedure or by the uniform commercial code, a lien shall be imposed
on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of the defendant in the amount
of any debt due and owing the city under this article. The lien may be enforced
in the same manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a court of
competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-11: PETITION TO SET ASIDE:
A petition to set aside a determination of parking, standing or compliance
violation liability may be filed by a person owing an unpaid fine or penalty
within twenty one (21) days after such determination. The petition shall be
filed with and ruled upon by the hearing officer on the basis of the petition
and such other evidence as the hearing officer may reasonably require, within
fourteen (14) days after receipt of all such evidence. The grounds for the
petition shall be limited to: a) the person not having been the owner or lessee
