of the cited vehicle on the date the violation notice was issued, b) the person
having already paid the fine or penalty for the violation in question, and c)
excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing. After the
determination of parking, standing or compliance violation liability has been
set aside upon a showing of just cause, the party shall be provided with a
hearing on the merits for that violation. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
3-1A-12: SCHEDULE OF CIVIL FINES:
Fines, penalties and sanctions shall be imposed as provided in connection with
the ordinance provision which was violated. (Ord. 7299, 2-22-2012)
3-1A-13: DEFENSES TO CERTAIN VIOLATIONS:
As to violations of any municipal ordinance or code that establishes
construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or
other health safety standards applicable to structures in the city, it shall be
a defense to a code violation if the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or
representative proves to the hearing officer's satisfaction one of the
following:
   A.   The code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact exist, or at
the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed.
   B.   The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants
and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the dwelling
free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the
violations.
   C.   An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the owner
or his agent to all or part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the
code violation. (Ord. 6348, 11-25-1998)
CHAPTER 2
LAW DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-2-1: Law Department Established
3-2-2: Corporation Counselor
3-2-3: City Attorney
3-2-4: Outside Employment
3-2-5: Assistants
3-2-1: LAW DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a Law Department which shall consist of the City
Attorney and Corporation Counselor, and such assistants as may be authorized as
provided in Section
3-2-5 of this Chapter. (1961 Code, § 2-41; amd. 1999 Code)
3-2-2: CORPORATION COUNSELOR:
   A.   Appointment, Qualifications: The Corporation Counselor of the City
shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the consent of the City Council.
He shall be the official head of the Law Department and shall be responsible
for its efficient operation. He shall be an attorney licensed to practice law
in the State of Illinois and shall be a bona fide resident of the City. (Ord.
5315, 1-25-1989)
   B.   Duties: It shall be the duty of the Corporation Counselor to counsel
and advise the City Council, the Mayor and heads of departments; to prepare or
revise ordinances when so requested by the Council or any committee thereof; to
prepare for execution all contracts and agreements of which the City is a party
and shall approve as to form all such legal instruments; to give legal opinions
upon any legal matter or question submitted to him by the Council or any
officer of the City; and to assist the City Attorney in the prosecution or
defense of all actions in courts of record or all courts of appeal, when
necessary. (Ord. 3171, 4-10-1963)
3-2-3: CITY ATTORNEY:
   A.   Appointment, Qualifications: The City Attorney shall be appointed by
the Mayor, by and with the consent of the City Council. He shall be an attorney
licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois and shall be a bona fide
resident of the City. Nothing contained in this Section, nor in Section
3-2-2 of this Chapter, shall be construed to prohibit or preclude the City
Council from employing outside counsel for special projects as they may deem
fit from time to time. (Ord. 5315, 1-25-1989)
   B.   Duties: It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to prosecute all
actions for violation of the provisions of this Code, to prosecute and defend
any and all suits or cause of action of which the City may be a party and to
represent the City in all matters before the Illinois Commerce Commission or
any other judicial or quasi-judicial commissions where there is a possibility
of an appeal to a court of record. He shall also, when necessary, assist the
Corporation Counselor in the performance of his duties as are outlined in this
Chapter. (1961 Code, § 2-45)
3-2-4: OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT:
The duties of the Corporation Counselor and City Attorney shall not preclude
either office from engaging in the general practice of law in any matters not
hostile to the interest of the City. (1961 Code, § 2-46; amd. 1999 Code)
3-2-5: ASSISTANTS:
The Mayor may appoint assistants to the Corporation Counselor and the City
Attorney, by and with the consent of the City Council. Any such assistants
shall be attorneys licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois, and they
shall perform such duties as may be assigned to them by the Corporation
Counselor or the City Attorney from time to time. (1999 Code)
CHAPTER 3
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-3-1: Department Established
3-3-2: Ranks Of Police Department
3-3-3: Power Of Arrest
3-3-4: Vacations
3-3-5: Participation In Police Pension Fund Required
3-3-6: Deputy Chief Of Police (Rep. by Ord. 6747, 7-9-2003)
3-3-7: Operation Of All-Terrain Vehicles
3-3-8: Bail Processing Fee
3-3-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a department of the municipal government of the
city which shall be known as the police department. (1973 Code)
3-3-2: RANKS OF POLICE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Chief Of Police: There is created the office of chief of the police of
the city of Alton. The chief of police shall be appointed by the mayor, by and
with the advice and consent of the city council, at the first regular meeting
of the new city council of each year or in the event of a vacancy. The chief of
police shall continue to serve until removed by order of the mayor or until his
successor shall be appointed and qualified, whichever event shall first occur.
He shall, in subordination to the mayor, have the full management and control
of the police department, and all regulations and orders thereof shall be
promulgated through him. All subordinate officers and members of said police
department shall be subject to such rules and regulations as shall, from time
to time, be prescribed by said chief of police. (Ord. 6747, 7-9-2003; amd. Ord.
6940, 4-12-2006)
   B.   Deputy Police Chief: There is hereby created the position of deputy
police chief, who shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and
consent of the city council, at the first regular meeting of the new city
council of each year or upon a vacancy. The deputy police chief shall continue
to serve until removed by order of the mayor or until a successor shall be
appointed and qualified, whichever event shall first occur. The deputy police
chief shall perform such duties and have all such powers as may be lawfully
delegated to him by the chief of police. In the event of the absence of the
chief of police, vacancy in the office of chief of police, or at the request of
the chief of police, the deputy police chief shall assume all powers and duties
of the chief of police. The mayor shall have authority to determine that the
chief of police is physically or mentally unable to perform his duties, and
upon notification to the deputy police chief of such a determination by the
mayor, the deputy police chief shall likewise assume all duties of the chief of
police until relieved by directive from the mayor. Any acts by the deputy
police chief, while properly performing the duties of the chief of police under
the circumstances as aforesaid, shall be deemed acts of the chief of police for
all purposes. The compensation fixed for the deputy police chief shall remain
consistent and shall not increase during any period during which he assumes the
duties of the chief of police.
   C.   Captain: The captain, under the general supervision of the chief of
police and deputy police chief, shall perform such duties as assigned from time
to time by the chief of police. The captain shall be a superior officer in the
police department with authority over all police officers except the chief of
police and deputy police chief.
   D.   Lieutenants: Lieutenants, under the general supervision of the chief of
police, deputy police chief, and captain, shall perform duties that may
include, but are not limited to, management responsibilities with advanced
supervisory duties in the direction of uniformed or plain clothes police
officers on an assigned shift or division. The lieutenants shall perform their
duties as assigned by the chief of police from time to time.
   E.   Sergeants: Sergeants, under the general supervision of the chief of
police, deputy police chief, captain, and lieutenants, shall perform duties as
assigned by the chief of police from time to time, including, but not limited
to, supervisory duties with regard to police patrolmen on an assigned platoon.
   F.   Patrolmen: Patrolmen, under the general supervision of the chief of
police, deputy police chief, captain, lieutenants, and sergeants, shall perform
such police duties as may be assigned by superior officers from time to time.
They shall be governed in their activities by the regulations and directions of
their superior officers.
   G.   Personnel: The position of police officer of the city of Alton is
hereby created in addition to the chief of police and deputy police chief, who
shall be police officers. Persons may be appointed to serve as police officers
of the city of Alton with the various ranks as follows:
      1.   Chief of police.
      2.   Deputy police chief.
      3.   Captain.
      4.   Lieutenants, not to exceed six (6) in total.
      5.   Sergeants, not to exceed fourteen (14) in total.
      6.   All others with the rank of patrolmen.
   H.   Appointment And Promotion: Captain, lieutenants, sergeants, and
patrolmen shall be appointed and promoted by merit in accordance with the
statutes, rules and procedures relating to the function of the civil service
commission of the city of Alton, Illinois.
   I.   Existing Contract: The adoption and approval of this section is not
intended to negate or nullify any of the respective rights or obligations of
the parties with regard to the existing contract between the city of Alton and
Police Benevolent & Protective Association Unit #14, covering the period April
1, 1999, to March 31, 2004. (Ord. 6747, 7-9-2003)
3-3-3: POWER OF ARREST:
The several members of the police force, when on duty, shall devote their
entire time to the proper discharge of the duties of their stations, according
to the laws and provisions of this code and the rules and regulations of the
police department, and it shall be their special duty to preserve order, peace
and quiet, and to enforce the provisions of this code throughout the city.
(1917 Code § 236)
3-3-4: VACATIONS:
Full time members of the police department annual vacation leave shall be
computed as follows:
   A.   Two (2) weeks for each employee who has completed one or more years of
continuous service.
   B.   Three (3) weeks for each employee who has completed two (2) or more
years of continuous service.
   C.   Four (4) weeks for each employee who has completed ten (10) or more
years of continuous service.
   D.   Five (5) weeks for each employee who has completed fifteen (15) or more
years of continuous service. (Ord. 3683, 8-12-1971)
3-3-5: PARTICIPATION IN POLICE PENSION FUND REQUIRED:
No person shall be employed as a police officer for the city without having
first applied for and having been accepted as a member of the police pension
fund of the city. The city council hereby provides that it is a condition of
employment with the Alton city police department that all Alton city police
officers shall actively participate and become members of the police pension
fund (municipalities 500,000 and under as provided in 40 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-101 through 5/3-150). The failure of any police officer to
participate in said pension fund shall be grounds for cause for removal from
his position as an Alton city police officer. (Ord. 5279, 9-14-1988; amd. Ord.
5438, 3-28-1990)
3-3-6: DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE:
(Rep. by Ord. 6747, 7-9-2003)
3-3-7: OPERATION OF ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES:
The members of the city of Alton police department are hereby authorized to
operate vehicles commonly referred to as all- terrain vehicles upon any street,
alley or highway located within the corporate limits of the city, and upon any
public property located within the city, while in the performance of their
respective duties as employees of the city, notwithstanding the fact that said
vehicles are not licensed by the state of Illinois and are otherwise prohibited
from operation upon public street, alley or highways. (Ord. 6493, 6-14-2000)
3-3-8: BAIL PROCESSING FEE 1  :
There is hereby imposed a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for bail
processing against any person arrested for violating a bailable municipal
offense, or a state or federal law. It shall be a duty of the Alton police
department to collect the bail processing fee in addition to any bail
established by statute or order of the court against any person released on
bail who is processed by the police department of the city of Alton. All bail
processing fees collected shall be remitted on a regular basis to the city
treasurer and deposited to the general fund of the city of Alton. (Ord. 7475,
9-9-2015, eff. 10-1-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-12.1.
CHAPTER 4
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-4-1: Department Established
3-4-2: Ranks Of Fire Department
3-4-3: Duties And Responsibilities
3-4-4: Copy Of Rules
3-4-5: Certification
3-4-6: Participation In Firefighters' Pension Fund Required
3-4-7: Foreign Fire Insurance Board
3-4-8: Recovery Of Cost Of Responding To Hazardous Waste/Chemical Spills And/Or
Related Fires
3-4-9: Operation Of All-Terrain Vehicles
3-4-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a department of the municipal government of the
city which shall be known as the fire department. (1973 Code)
3-4-2: RANKS OF FIRE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Fire Chief: There is created the office of chief of the fire department
of the city of Alton. The fire chief shall be appointed by the mayor, by and
with the advice and consent of the city council, at the first regular meeting
of the new city council of each year or upon a vacancy. The fire chief shall
continue to serve until removed by order of the mayor or until his successor
shall be appointed and qualified, whichever event shall first occur. The fire
chief shall be the chief officer of the fire department and shall have full
command and control over said department and all members thereof, with full
power and authority over its organization, government and discipline and to
that end, the fire chief may prescribe and establish, from time to time, such
rules and regulations as the fire chief may deem advisable for administration
of the fire department.
   B.   Deputy Fire Chiefs: There is hereby created the position of deputy fire
chief, who shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent
of the city council, at the first regular meeting of the new city council of
each year or upon a vacancy. A deputy fire chief shall continue to serve until
removed by order of the mayor or until a successor shall be appointed and
qualified, whichever event shall first occur. A new deputy fire chief shall
perform such administrative functions as may be assigned by the fire chief from
time to time. There shall not be employed by the fire department more than two
(2) deputy fire chiefs at any one time. (Ord. 6748, 7-23-2003)
   C.   Battalion Chiefs: Battalion chiefs, under the general supervision of
the fire chief and the deputy fire chiefs, shall serve as heads of shifts,
direct the activities of the captains, engineers, and firefighters on their
respective shift and shall perform such administrative functions as may be
assigned by the fire chief or deputy fire chiefs.
   D.   Captains: Captains, under the general supervision of the fire chief,
deputy fire chiefs, and battalion chiefs, shall serve as supervisors of a fire
company. A captain shall command a fire company in the fire station house and
at the scene of a fire or incident outside the fire station house until the
arrival and presence of a superior officer. The captain shall perform such
administrative functions as may be assigned by the fire chief, deputy fire
chief, or battalion chief from time to time.
   E.   Engineers: Engineers, under the general supervision of the fire chief,
deputy fire chiefs, battalion chiefs, and captains, shall perform such
firefighter duties as may be assigned by superior officers from time to time.
The engineers' duties shall include, but not be limited to, driving and
operating any and all firefighting or rescue apparatus.
   F.   Firefighters: Firefighters, under the general supervision of the fire
chief, deputy fire chiefs, battalion chiefs, captains, and engineers, shall
perform such firefighter duties as may be assigned by superior officers from
time to time. Firefighters shall perform such duties as shall be necessary to
extinguish fires, including the handling of hoses, axes, pipes, fire
extinguishers, and other equipment, and they shall drive, operate and maintain
fire vehicles, pumps and rescue equipment, and shall otherwise assist in
general rescue work; also they shall conduct inspections of properties and
otherwise implement the purposes of the fire prevention code. They shall be
governed in their activities by the regulations and directions of their
superior officers. (Ord. 6748, 7-23-2003; amd. Ord. 7251, 5-11-2011)
   G.   Personnel: The position of firefighter of the city of Alton is hereby
created. In addition to the fire chief, through March 31, 2004, there shall be
not to exceed sixty (60) persons required to be appointed to the position of
firefighter with various ranks as follows:
      1.   Fire chief. (Ord. 6748, 7-23-2003)
      2.   Deputy fire chiefs and battalion chiefs, not to exceed six (6) in
total. (Ord. 6859, 12-15-2004; amd. Ord. 7251, 5-11-2011)
      3.   Captains, not to exceed twenty (20) in total.
      4.   Engineers, not to exceed sixteen (16) in total. (Ord. 6876, 4-27-
2005)
      5.   All others with rank of firefighter. (Ord. 6748, 7-23-2003)
   H.   Appointment And Promotion: Battalion chiefs, captains, engineers and
firefighters shall be appointed and promoted by merit in accordance with the
statutes, rules and procedures relating to the function of the civil service
commission of the city of Alton, Illinois. (Ord. 6748, 7-23-2003; amd. Ord.
7251, 5-11-2011)
   I.   Function And Purpose: The fire department shall have primary
responsibility for fighting fires, executing a fire prevention program, and
providing general rescue and assistance services.
   J.   Existing Contract: The adoption and approval of this section is not
intended to negate or nullify any of the respective rights or obligations of
the parties with regard to the existing memorandum of understanding between the
city of Alton and Local Union 1255 of the International Association Of
Firefighters, covering the period April 1, 1999, to March 31, 2004. (Ord. 6748,
7-23-2003)
3-4-3: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   Vicinity Of Fire: The chief of police may prescribe the limits in the
vicinity of any fire within which no persons except those who reside therein,
and the members of the fire department, or those admitted by the officers of
the fire department, shall be permitted to come, and it shall be the duty of
the police department to aid in carrying into effect the provisions of this
section. (1917 Code § 367)
   B.   Illegal Acts:
      1.   Hindering Firefighters: It shall be unlawful for any person to
wilfully offer any hindrance or obstruct in any manner, with teams, streetcars,
interurban cars, railroad cars, switch engines, trains, automobiles, auto
trucks, or other vehicles of any kind or description, any member of the fire
department who may be responding to a fire alarm, in and upon the streets,
avenues, alleys and public places of the city; or to wilfully offer any
hindrance, or obstruct in any manner, any member of the fire department in the
performance of his duty at a fire, or to wilfully injure, deface or destroy any
of the fire apparatus belonging to the city. Any person found guilty of so
doing shall be subject to penalty as in this code provided; and, in addition,
be liable for damages for the injury done to any such apparatus. (1917 Code §
370)
      2.   No Loafing In Houses: No person other than a firefighter, police
officer or public officer shall enter or assemble with any other person or
persons in any hose house belonging to the city without the permission of the
officer in charge of such hose house. (1917 Code § 371)
      3.   Injuring Apparatus: It shall be unlawful for any person to break,
deface, destroy or otherwise injure any fire department apparatus belonging to
the city. (1917 Code § 372)
      4.   Impersonating Firefighter: It shall be unlawful for any person not a
member of the fire department to impersonate a firefighter or officer of the
fire department. (1917 Code, § 375)
   C.   Entering Fire Department: It shall be the duty of all members of the
fire department to prevent all persons not belonging to the department from
entering any house or handling any apparatus belonging to the department
without permission. (1917 Code, § 373)
   D.   Property Saved: No person shall be entitled to take away any property
in the possession of the fire department saved from any fire until he shall
make satisfactory proof of ownership thereof. (1917 Code, § 377)
3-4-4: COPY OF RULES:
Every member of the fire department shall be furnished with a copy of the rules
and regulations prescribed by the chief of said department, for the government
of the same. (1917 Code, § 374)
3-4-5: CERTIFICATION:
   A.   If an applicant can provide proof that the state of Illinois recognizes
the applicant's certification as an emergency medical technician--basic, a
preference credit of three (3) points shall be added to the final grade
evaluation of the applicant if that grade evaluation is seventy (70) or higher.
If an applicant can provide proof that the state of Illinois recognizes the
applicant's certification as an emergency medical technician-- paramedic, a
paramedic preference credit of six (6) points shall be added to the final grade
evaluation of the applicant if that grade evaluation is seventy (70) or higher.
Total points to be added based on certification as an emergency medical
technician shall not exceed six (6) points.
   B.   No individual may be certified for regular, full-time employment as a
firefighter of the city unless he or she shall first be certified by the
Illinois State Fire Marshal as a firefighter II, which requires successfully
completing an approved training course as provided by 50 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 740/1 through 740/15. Any firefighter who has not received the
certification as aforesaid by the end of the twelve (12) month probationary
period shall not be retained as an employee of the city but shall be
terminated. (Ord. 6541, 11-8-2000)
3-4-6: PARTICIPATION IN FIREFIGHTER'S PENSION FUND REQUIRED:
No person shall be employed as a firefighter for the city without having first
applied for and having been accepted as a member of the firefighter's pension
fund of the city. The city council hereby provides that it is a condition of
employment with the fire department that all members of the fire department
shall actively participate and become members of the firefighter's pension fund
(municipalities 500,000 and under as provided in 40 ILCS 5/4-101 through 5/4-
144). The failure of any member of the fire department to participate in said
pension fund shall be grounds for cause for removal from his position as a
member of the fire department. (Ord. 5438, 3-28-1990)
3-4-7: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD:
   A.   In accordance with the Foreign Fire Insurance Act 1 , all foreign fire
insurance company money paid to the city treasurer as provided in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 shall be set apart and shall be appropriated
annually by the corporate authorities to the foreign fire insurance board. The
treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board shall receive the appropriated
money and shall pay out the money upon the order of the foreign fire insurance
board for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the department.
   B.   The officers of the foreign fire insurance board created by this
section shall be a chairman, a secretary, a treasurer, and a vice chairman. The
vice chairman shall be the duly appointed chief of the fire department of the
city. The other three (3) officers shall be elected by the full-time members of
the Alton fire department. The chairman shall be elected for an initial term of
three (3) years from 1990 into 1993; and thereafter the term of the chairman
shall be two (2) years. The treasurer shall be elected for an initial term of
two (2) years from 1990 to 1992; and thereafter the term of the treasurer shall
be two (2) years. The secretary shall be elected for an initial term of one
year from 1990 into 1991; and thereafter the term of the secretary shall be two
(2) years. Any elections to be held each year shall be held simultaneously on a
day during the first week of August to be specifically determined by notice
from the chief of the fire department at least thirty (30) days in advance.
Notice of election shall be conspicuously posted in each firehouse of the fire
department.
   C.   The officers of the board shall be required to assure that the
treasurer of the board shall give a sufficient bond to the municipality,
approved by the mayor, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the
treasurer of his duties under this section and any rules or regulations
provided by the board.
   D.   The officers of the board shall give not less than fourteen (14) days'
advance notice of a time and date for a meeting at least annually for the
purpose of allowing any full-time member of the fire department to appear and
suggest proposals for expenditure of funds held by the treasurer. The officers
of the board shall thereafter determine what expenditures are appropriate by
consideration of written resolutions. A majority vote of the persons serving as
officers shall be required before the adoption of any such resolution. The
officers of the board shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that
the board feels are appropriate expenditures. The treasurer of the board shall
make disbursement only in response to written resolution certified by the
secretary to have been passed by a majority vote of the persons then serving as
officers and only to the extent available funds permit the disbursements. No
officer shall be authorized to incur any form of debt in the name of the board.
All checks disbursed from the board shall require the signature of the
treasurer and the chairman of the board. Any decision by the officers of the
board to make disbursements shall be deemed a final decision and not reviewable
after checks are issued. The secretary shall be responsible for the maintenance
of minutes of all meetings of the officers of the board, notices required, and
related documents. The treasurer shall be responsible for the maintenance of
all records concerning receipts and disbursements of funds.
   E.   The officers of the board are hereby empowered to consider and adopt
any additional rules and regulations they determine to be necessary or
appropriate for the effective and efficient management of the board from time
to time.
   F.   As part of the annual municipal audit, these funds shall be audited to
verify that these purchases are for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the
department. (Ord. 6054, 3-27-1996)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 et seq.
3-4-8: RECOVERY OF COST OF RESPONDING TO HAZARDOUS WASTE/CHEMICAL SPILLS AND/OR
RELATED FIRES:
Any person, firm, business or corporation that is responsible for causing the
fire, police and/or public works department of the city to respond to incidents
involving hazardous waste/chemical spills and/or related fires within and
beyond the corporate limits of the city shall be charged a fee equal to the
cost of said response of the fire, police or public works departments of the
city. (Ord. 6387, 5-12-1999)
3-4-9: OPERATION OF ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES:
The members of the city of Alton fire department are hereby authorized to
operate vehicles commonly referred to as all- terrain vehicles upon any street,
alley or highway located within the corporate limits of the city, and upon any
public property located within the city, while in the performance of their
respective duties as employees of the city, notwithstanding the fact that said
vehicles are not licensed by the state of Illinois and are otherwise prohibited
from operation upon public street, alley or highways. (Ord. 6493, 6-14-2000)
CHAPTER 5
DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
SECTION:
3-5-1: Department Established
3-5-2: Director
3-5-3: Deputy Director
3-5-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a Department of Planning and Development within the
Municipal government of the City. The Department shall oversee efforts of the
City of Alton to improve and enhance the quality of life for the citizens of
Alton through the provision of programs, activities and initiatives relating to
economic development, zoning/land use administration, community development,
and short and long-range planning. Furthermore, the department shall solicit
and promote private and public investment in the City of Alton so as to promote
economic development, including the creation and retention of jobs within the
City of Alton and the enhancement of its tax base to sustain the efforts of the
City of Alton so as to promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens
of the City of Alton. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-2018)
3-5-2: DIRECTOR:
There is hereby established the Office of Director of Planning and Development,
which shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor, by and with the consent of
the City Council. Education, knowledge and experience shall qualify the
Director of Planning and Development. The Director of Planning and Development
shall oversee all economic and community development efforts within the City of
Alton, including the administration of all grants and programs related to
economic and community development. The Director of Planning and Development
shall work under the supervision of the Mayor. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-2018)
3-5-3: DEPUTY DIRECTOR:
There is hereby established the Office of Deputy Director of Planning and
Development, which shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor, by and with the
consent of the City Council. Education, knowledge and experience shall qualify
the Deputy Director of Planning and Development. The Deputy Director of
Planning and Development shall serve as the Zoning Administrator and assist the
Director of Planning and Development with economic and community development
efforts within the City of Alton as may be directed by the Director of Planning
and Development. The Deputy Director of Planning and Development shall work
under the supervision of the Director of Planning and Development. (Ord. 7664,
8-22-2018)
CHAPTER 6
PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-6-1: Department Established
3-6-2: Directors And Employees
3-6-3: Disposition Of Funds
3-6-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a parks and recreation department in the city of
Alton. (Ord. 6721, 4-9-2003)
3-6-2: DIRECTORS AND EMPLOYEES:
   A.   Executive Director: An executive director of the parks and recreation
department shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the city
council. The executive director shall administer all of the property, programs,
and activities conducted by the parks and recreation department of the city of
Alton. The executive director shall be the chief administrative officer of the
parks and recreation department. (Ord. 6721, 4-9-2003)
   B.   Maintenance Director 1 : (Rep. by Ord. 7411, 6-11-2014)
   C.   Recreation Director: A recreation director shall be appointed by the
mayor by and with the consent of the city council. The recreation director
shall supervise the recreational programs of the parks and recreation
department and shall supervise all other employees assigned playground or
recreation duties. The recreation director shall be the responsible party for
the day to day administration of playground and recreation activities. The
recreation director shall be qualified by education, knowledge and experience
to organize and administer the recreational programs determined to be
appropriate by the executive director. (Ord. 6721, 4-9-2003)
The executive director and recreation director shall be required to establish
their residence within the city of Alton within ninety (90) days of their
appointment to their position and to maintain their respective residence within
the city of Alton thereafter. (Ord. 6721, 4-9-2003; amd. Ord. 7417, 8-13-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-9 of this title.
3-6-3: DISPOSITION OF FUNDS:
The city treasurer shall receive and hold all monies that may come to the parks
and recreation department either by subscription, donation, appropriations or
fees for the improvement and maintenance of the parks or from other sources and
may draw orders, checks or warrants against such funds as he shall hold for
park purposes on proper order in writing as directed to him by the executive
director of the parks and recreation department of the city or by any
legislative or executive order for any necessary expense or expenditures for
playground and recreation purposes or other matters relative thereto or arising
out of playground and recreation matters. (Ord. 6721, 4-9-2003)
CHAPTER 7
INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-7-1: Department Established
3-7-2: Information Technology Director
3-7-3: Information Technology Technician
3-7-4: Mission And Goals
3-7-5: Fingerprinting
3-7-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established an Information Technology Department in the City,
to be effective immediately upon passage hereof. (Ord. 7457, 4-22-2015)
3-7-2: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DIRECTOR:
   A.   The Information Technology Director shall be appointed by the Mayor, by
and with the consent of the City Council. The Director shall be qualified by
education, training and experience to carry forth the mission and goals of the
Information Technology Department.
   B.   The duties of the Information Technology Director shall be as follows:
      1.   To generally oversee the operations of the City of Alton with regard
to the demands of information technology, including all computers, networking
capabilities, e-mails and websites owned, operated, or maintained by the City
of Alton.
      2.   To be available to assist the various departments with regard to
issues involving telephones, fax machines, copiers, and scanners.
      3.   To oversee the policies of each department with regard to the
maintenance of records and all policies concerning the destruction of said
records except with regard to the statutory duties of the Office of the City
Clerk and City Treasurer. The City Clerk shall retain ultimate responsibility
with regard to the statutory requirements with regard to the records of the
City Clerk and City Treasurer but the Information Technology Director shall be
available for consultation with regard to the implementation of those
requirements.
      4.   To perform such other duties as may be assigned by the Mayor or by
ordinance, approved by the City Council, from time to time. (Ord. 7457, 4-22-
2015)
3-7-3: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TECHNICIAN:
   A.   The information technology technician shall be appointed by the Mayor,
by and with the consent of the City Council. The technician shall be qualified
by education, training and experience to carry forth the mission and goals of
the Information Technology Department.
   B.   The duties of the information technology technician shall be as
follows:
      1.   Identifies and procures the hardware and software needed to satisfy
user requirements.
      2.   Installs hardware and peripheral components such as monitors,
keyboards, printers and disk drives on user's premises.
      3.   Loads appropriate software packages such as operating systems,
networking components, office applications, new software, and hardware, on the
LAN coordinating assistance from IT Director.
      4.   Provides telephone, in person and online support to end users.
      5.   Provides updates, status and completion information to manager and/
or users via e-mail or the help desk support system.
      6.   Refers major hardware problems to IT Director for correction.
      7.   Connects users to networks and provides initial training in
facilities and applications.
      8.   Administers e-mail and antivirus systems.
      9.   Rotates daily backup media.
      10.   Assists in research and procurement of computer accessories and
supplies.
      11.   Adds and maintains users on the network; assigning application
access, ensuring security and maintaining their configurations are within
standards.
      12.   Performs other duties as assigned. (Ord. 7539, 9-14-2016)
3-7-4: MISSION AND GOALS:
The mission and goals of the Information Technology Department shall be to
assist all departments of the City of Alton with regard to all issues involving
information technology including the acquisition of information, the storage of
information, and the permissible destruction of information records in a modern
and efficient manner. (Ord. 7539, 9-14-2016)
3-7-5: FINGERPRINTING:
The City, through its Information Technology Department, will provide livescan
fingerprinting services to all individuals and businesses located in the Alton
area, and the corporate authorities of the City deem it appropriate to impose a
fee for such service in order to partially offset the cost to the City to
provide such service. A fee is hereby imposed upon persons requesting such
service pursuant to the following fee schedule:

CHAPTER 8
DEPARTMENT OF CODE ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
3-8-1: Department Established
3-8-2: Director
3-8-3: Housing Division
3-8-4: Housing Inspector
3-8-5: Building Division
3-8-6: Building Coordinator
3-8-7: Building Inspector
3-8-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a Department of Code Enforcement. The Department of
Code Enforcement shall be dedicated to improving the health, safety and welfare
of the City of Alton by maintaining, preserving and improving the City's
physical structures and properties by enforcing Building and Housing
Construction Codes, Life Safety Codes, Property Maintenance Codes,
Accessibility Codes, together with the supervision of occupancy inspections and
landlord licensing requirements. The Department of Code Enforcement shall be
responsible for review, inspection and issuance of all permits relating to
housing, building, sign and structure permits. The Department of Code
Enforcement shall supervise all efforts to obtain the demolition of dangerous
and unsafe structures found to be beyond reasonable repair. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-
2018)
3-8-2: DIRECTOR:
There is hereby established the Office of Director of Code Enforcement, which
shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor, by and with the consent of the
City Council. Education, knowledge and experience shall qualify the Director of
Code Enforcement. The Director of Code Enforcement shall oversee all
responsibilities of the Department of Code Enforcement. The Director of Code
Enforcement shall work under the supervision of the Mayor. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-
2018)
3-8-3: HOUSING DIVISION:
The Housing Division shall operate as a separate division of the Code
Enforcement Department under the direction of the Director of Code Enforcement.
The Housing Division shall be led by a Housing Coordinator who shall be
qualified by education, knowledge and experience in the administration of
Building and Housing Code enforcement, including but not limited to, the
ability to administer and oversee the enforcement of provisions of this Code
related to landlord licensing, vacant property registration programs,
residential Property Maintenance Code enforcement, administration of
residential occupancy permit regulations and shall serve as a liaison to the
Alton Police Department and Alton Fire Department. The initial Housing
Coordinator shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the consent of the
City Council, and the position shall thereafter be under the civil service
regulations of the City of Alton. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-2018)
3-8-4: HOUSING INSPECTOR:
There is hereby created the position of housing inspector in the City of Alton.
Education, knowledge and experience shall qualify the housing inspector to
conduct occupancy inspections, enforce the Property Maintenance Codes of the
City of Alton, enforce the Zoning Codes of the City of Alton and perform such
other duties as may be assigned by the Housing Coordinator or the Director of
the Department of Code Enforcement from time to time. The total number of
housing inspectors shall be determined by the annual budgetary process of the
City of Alton. Initial housing inspectors shall be appointed by the Mayor, by
and with the consent of the City Council, and the positions shall thereafter be
under the civil service regulations of the City of Alton. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-
2018)
3-8-5: BUILDING DIVISION:
The Building Division shall operate as a separate division of the Department of
Code Enforcement under the direction of the Director of Department of Code
Enforcement. The Building Division shall be led by a Building Coordinator who
shall be qualified by education, knowledge and experience in the administration
of Building Code enforcement, including but not limited to, the ability to
administer and oversee the enforcement of provisions of this Code relating to
commercial buildings. The Building Division shall have responsibility for
review and issuance of commercial building and demolition permits, construction
inspections and review, sign permits and enforcement of Subdivision and Zoning
Code requirements of this Code. Additional duties of the Building Division
shall be assigned by the Director of the Department of Code Enforcement. (Ord.
7664, 8-22-2018)
3-8-6: BUILDING COORDINATOR:
The Building Division shall be led by a Building Coordinator who shall be
qualified by education, knowledge and experience to perform the duties of the
administration of the Building Division. The Building Coordinator shall serve
as a liaison to the Appearance Review Commission, Historical Commission,
Planning and Zoning Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals. The Building
Coordinator shall be initially appointed by the Mayor, by and with the consent
of the City Council, and the position shall thereafter be under the civil
service regulations of the City of Alton. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-2018)
3-8-7: BUILDING INSPECTOR:
There is hereby created the position of building inspector in the City of
Alton. Education, knowledge and experience shall qualify the building
inspector. The duties of the building inspector shall include inspection of
premises in relation to applications for business licenses, construction
permits and inspections, and all commercial Property Code enforcement, the
demolition of dangerous and unsafe structures beyond reasonable repair in
commercial zoning districts together with such other duties as may be assigned
by the Building Coordinator or the Director of the Department of Code
Enforcement from time to time. The total number of building inspectors shall be
determined by the annual budgetary process of the City of Alton. Initial
building inspectors shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the consent of
the City Council, and thereafter the positions shall be under the civil service
regulations of the City of Alton. (Ord. 7664, 8-22-2018)
TITLE 4
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUSINESS REGULATION CERTIFICATES
SECTION:
4-1-1: Title
4-1-2: Definitions
4-1-3: Regulation Certificates Required
4-1-4: Applications For Certificates
4-1-5: Term Of Certificates
4-1-6: Fees
4-1-7: Record Of Certificates
4-1-8: Food Service Sanitation
4-1-9: Conditions And Appeal
4-1-10: Exclusions And Reductions
4-1-11: Administration And Enforcement
4-1-12: Revocation
4-1-13: Conflict
4-1-14: Invalidity
4-1-1: TITLE:
This chapter may be cited and referred to as the BUSINESS REGULATION
CERTIFICATES. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-1-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms wherever they occur in this chapter shall be
construed as herein defined:
COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT: Shall refer to a "food establishment", an "industrial
establishment", a "retail and wholesale establishment" or a "service
establishment", as defined herein.
FOOD ESTABLISHMENT: A building or premises or portion thereof, the principal
use of which is for sale or dispensing or distribution or serving of food,
foodstuff or drink for consumption on or off the premises or in or out of the
building, not to include the sale or dispensing or distribution of alcoholic
beverages.
INDUSTRIAL ESTABLISHMENT: A building or premises or portion thereof, the
principal use of which is for manufacturing, including assembly, processing,
fabrication and storage or scientific research and development.
OWNER: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or
any other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in any
establishment to maintain and manage its operation.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or
any other legal entity.
RETAIL AND WHOLESALE ESTABLISHMENT: A building or premises or portion thereof,
the principal use of which is for the sale or distribution of any commodity for
a price by a seller to a consumer, or by one business to another business.
SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT: A building or premises or portion thereof, the principal
use of which is for the rendering of personal services for a price whether or
not a commodity is worked upon or exchanged. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-
1979; amd. 1999 Code)
4-1-3: REGULATION CERTIFICATES REQUIRED:
   A.   One Business: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any
commercial establishment as herein enumerated, without having first obtained a
certificate therefor. A class A regulatory certificate shall be required of all
such establishments unless otherwise specified by this code. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs or
continues. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
   B.   Multiple Businesses: In the event the same person or entity is the
owner and operator of more than one commercial establishment located on the
same site and said commercial establishments require, by their varied nature,
two (2) or more regulatory certificates or liquor licenses, said owner and
operator shall be charged only one fee, that being the highest fee required for
a regulatory certificate or a liquor license if the establishment holds a
liquor license. The owner and operator shall be responsible to obtain any other
regulatory certificate or liquor license as may be required by this Code, but
the fee for such additional regulatory certificate or liquor license will be
waived. (Ord. 7557, 2-8-2017; amd. Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
   C.   Site Locations:
      1.   There shall be a business certificate for each place of business or
location. For the purposes of this title, a "place of business" shall be
defined as a building or series of connected buildings on one contiguous lot or
parcel of ground, and separately operated and owned by the same person and
conducting the same general business activity.
      2.   Where two (2) or more separate businesses, separately owned or
operated, share floor space in the same building or on the same parcel of
ground and the floor space is subdivided between the separate businesses, or
types of businesses, then each shall be deemed a separate business and shall be
required to attain a separate business regulatory certificate. (Ord. 4364, 10-
25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-1-4: APPLICATIONS FOR CERTIFICATES:
All persons operating any commercial establishments within the City shall file
with the City Treasurer an application for the appropriate regulatory
certificate to operate their particular commercial establishment. Applications
for such documents shall be made available by the City. The required fee for
the particular regulatory certificate which is applied for, must accompany the
filing of said application. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-1-5: TERM OF CERTIFICATES:
Subject to the terms and provisions of this chapter, the Mayor, or such
personnel as may be designated by the Mayor, shall cause to be issued the
certificate upon the recommendation of the City Treasurer, subject to
investigations by the Building, Fire, Police and Business and Economic
Development Departments, to permit the operation of the establishment in the
City for a period of one year. The term of said certificate shall begin on
January 1 of the year for which such document is issued and shall terminate on
December 31 of the same year. No certificate shall be issued at the yearly rate
of fees except for the full regulatory year; provided, however, that where such
document is issued on or after the first day of July, the regulatory fee shall
be one-half (1/2) of the yearly fee for the unexpired term of the regulatory
year. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979; amd. Ord. 5419, 1-10-1990)
4-1-6: FEES:
   A.   Collection: The yearly fee for a regulatory certificate shall be
collected by the City Treasurer, with the application for a regulatory
certificate. In no event shall any rebate or refund be made of any regulatory
fee, or part thereof, said fee being appropriate to the costs incurred by the
City in connection with the initial processing of an application, including
appropriate inspections as may be required. (Ord. 7281, 10-12-2011)
   B.   Annual Fees: Yearly fees for regulatory certificates in the City shall
be as follows:
 
Class A $ 50.00
Class B 100.00
Class C 200.00
Class D 400.00
Class E 600.00
 
   (Ord. 7078, 5-28-2008)
   C.   Late Fee: A late fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be imposed
on renewals received after December 31 of the year in which the renewal is due.
(Ord. 5983, 6-28-1995)
4-1-7: RECORD OF CERTIFICATES:
The City Treasurer shall cause to be maintained, a record of all establishments
and various regulatory documents which may from time to time be deemed
necessary for the purpose of classifying, inspecting, serving and regulating
all establishments in the City. Subject to the terms and provisions of this
chapter, upon payment in full of the required document fee to the City, the
City shall issue a certificate or similar evidence of the regulation which
shall be displayed by the owner of establishment in a conspicuous place. Such
evidence of regulation shall bear the signature of the Mayor and City Clerk and
be issued under the Corporate Seal. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979; amd.
Ord. 5419, 1-10-1990)
4-1-8: FOOD SERVICE SANITATION:
Any food establishment shall, in addition to other regulations provided herein,
comply with all rules and regulations as established by the Madison County,
Illinois, health department. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979; amd. 1999
Code)
4-1-9: CONDITIONS AND APPEAL:
   A.   Conditions: No business regulatory certificate for the operation of any
establishment in the city shall be issued if one or more of the following
conditions are determined by the city treasurer to exist:
      1.   The building or premises utilized by the establishment does not
comply with the provisions and terms of the building code, zoning ordinance,
fire regulations, health regulations 1  or with all other ordinances and
regulations of the city.
      2.   The building or premises utilized by the establishment are in a
condition of being unsanitary or unsafe so as to endanger the public safety,
health or welfare.
      3.   The proposed operation or activity of the establishment constitutes
an unsanitary or unsafe condition so as to endanger the public safety, health
or welfare.
      4.   The owner, investor, operator or manager of the establishment or
such legal entity comprising the establishment is delinquent in indebtedness to
the city.
      5.   The owner, investor, operator or manager of the establishment
represents an unreasonable danger to the public health, safety or welfare of
the public due to the past criminal or business activities of the owner,
investor, operator or manager of the proposed establishment after considering
the particular nature or circumstances of the activities proposed to be
conducted.
   B.   Appeal: In the event a person is denied the issuance of a business
regulatory certificate by the city treasurer for any of the reasons as set
forth in this section, the city treasurer shall provide a written notice of the
denial to the applicant. The denial shall specify the conditions determined by
the city treasurer to exist upon which the denial is based by referencing the
paragraph or paragraphs of this section relied upon by the city treasurer in
determining to deny the business regulatory certificate. If the applicant
desires to appeal the determination of the city treasurer to deny the business
regulatory certificate, the applicant may do so by compliance with the
following administrative procedures:
      1.   The applicant shall file a written notice of appeal with the office
of the mayor of the city of Alton within fourteen (14) days following the
written denial of the city treasurer. The notice of appeal must be accompanied
by a copy of the written denial of the city treasurer along with a statement
from the applicant of his intent to appeal said denial. The applicant must
provide at a minimum the applicant's current name, address and contact
information, including if available, a phone number and e-mail address. If the
applicant desires to be represented by an attorney licensed to practice law in
the state of Illinois, the applicant shall further set forth the name, current
address and if available the phone number and the e-mail address for said
attorney.
      2.   Upon receipt of a notice of appeal as aforesaid, the mayor shall
schedule an administrative hearing to be held before the mayor, or a hearing
officer to be designated by the mayor, in city hall at a time and on a date to
be determined by the mayor, not less than fourteen (14) days and not more than
thirty (30) days following the receipt of the notice of appeal in the office of
the mayor.
      3.   At the administrative hearing before the mayor, or his designated
hearing officer, the appellant will first present his application for a
business regulatory certificate, together with any supporting documents,
testimony or other evidence he may so choose to present to describe the
particular commercial establishment desired to be operated by the applicant,
along with evidence as to the suitability of the location for the proposed
commercial establishment. Following the presentation of the merits of the
application by the applicant as aforesaid, the city treasurer, or his
designated representative, shall present any and all documents, materials,
testimony or other evidence he may so choose to present in support of the
determination to deny the issuance of the business regulatory certificate.
      4.   All persons who testify in the course of the administrative hearing
shall be sworn by the mayor or the hearing officer. All persons who testify
shall be subject to cross examination by the party not calling the person to
testify. The formal rules of evidence applicable in a court of law shall not be
applied but may be used as a guide in the conduct of the hearing. Hearsay and
other forms of evidence may be admitted in the discretion of the mayor or the
hearing officer.
      5.   The hearing may be continued from time to time by the mayor or the
hearing officer with notice to the applicant and city treasurer or his
designated representative delivered in the course of the hearing or later by
mail. A complete record of the hearing shall be caused to be made by the mayor
or the hearing officer by way of audiotape, stenographer or court reporter.
      6.   Upon the conclusion of the evidence and any arguments that may be
permitted on the record in the discretion of the mayor or the hearing officer,
the hearing shall be adjourned. Within fourteen (14) days following the
adjournment of the hearing, the mayor or the hearing officer shall issue a
written decision to either affirm the decision of the city treasurer to deny
the issuance of a business regulatory certificate or, in the alternative, order
the city treasurer to issue a business regulatory certificate. Notice of the
written decision, including findings of fact to support the decision, shall be
mailed to the applicant by regular U.S. postal service and shall be filed with
the city treasurer and with the city clerk contemporaneously with the mailing
thereof and shall thereafter be considered public records.
      7.   The decision of the mayor or hearing officer shall be considered a
final administrative order and shall be subject to judicial review pursuant to
the Illinois administrative review act. (Ord. 7245, 2-23-2011)
 
Notes
1 1. See titles 5, 9, 10 and 11 of this code.
4-1-10: EXCLUSIONS AND REDUCTIONS:
   A.   The terms and provisions of this chapter shall not be made applicable
to any activity carried on or operated by a governmental institution and the
fee established in section
4-1-6 of this chapter shall be reduced by one-half (1/2) for any not for profit
institution or organization.
   B.   From time to time the city council, by majority vote on a resolution,
may exempt the payment of the fee established in section
4-1-6 of this chapter for certain specified not for profit institutions or
organizations, where the city council makes a finding that the essential
character of the specified institution or organization is charitable in nature
and that the particular activity related by this title shall be conducted in
the best interest of the citizens of the city and that such activity when
considered in light of the purposes of such institutions or organizations tends
to promote the health, safety or welfare of the community.
   C.   The terms and provisions of this title shall not be made applicable to
any activity which the state has declared to be within the exclusive regulation
of the state. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-1-11: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the city treasurer to administer and enforce the terms
of the provisions of this chapter and to make or cause to be made, such
inspections of buildings or premises as may be necessary to accomplish such
administration or enforcement. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979; amd. Ord.
5419, 1-10-1990)
4-1-12: REVOCATION:
The mayor shall have the power to revoke, for cause, any business regulatory
certificate issued by the city treasurer. In the event a business regulatory
certificate is revoked by the mayor, no portion of the business regulatory
certificate fee shall be refunded.
   A.   Causes For Revocation: The mayor shall have sufficient cause to revoke
any business regulatory certificate granted by him if one or more of the
following conditions are determined to exist following the issuance of said
business regulatory certificate:
      1.   The building or premises utilized by the establishment does not
comply with the provisions and terms of the building code, zoning ordinance,
fire regulations, health regulations 1  or with all other ordinances and
regulations of the city.
      2.   The building or premises utilized by the establishment are in a
condition of being unsanitary or unsafe so as to endanger the public safety,
health or welfare.
      3.   The proposed operation or activity of the establishment constitutes
an unsanitary or unsafe condition so as to endanger the public safety, health
or welfare.
      4.   The owner, investor, operator or manager of the establishment or
such legal entity comprising the establishment is delinquent in indebtedness to
the City.
      5.   The owner, investor, operator or manager of the establishment
represents an unreasonable danger to the public health, safety or welfare of
the public due to the past criminal or business activities of the owner,
investor, operator or manager of the proposed establishment after considering
the particular nature or circumstances of the activities proposed to be
conducted. (Ord. 7245, 2-23-2011)
      6.   The owner, manager, operator, or an employee of the business is
found to have violated any City ordinance upon or within the regulated business
establishment or in connection with the operation of the business. (Ord. 7690,
3-27-2019)
   B.   Revocation Procedures:
      1.   In the event the City Treasurer believes that there may be
sufficient cause to revoke any business regulatory certificate issued by him,
he shall file with the Office of the Mayor a written statement setting forth
the cause believed to exist to revoke any business regulatory certificate. The
written statement shall specify the condition or conditions which exist as
specified in subsection A of this section and which constitute sufficient cause
to revoke the business regulatory certificate.
      2.   The written statement of the City Treasurer filed with the Office of
the Mayor shall be referred to hereafter as "charges".
      3.   Upon receipt of a charges as aforesaid, the Mayor shall schedule an
administrative hearing to be held before the Mayor or a Hearing Officer to be
designated by the Mayor, in City Hall at a time and on a date to be determined
by the Mayor but not less than fourteen (14) days and not more than thirty (30)
days following the receipt of the charges in the Office of the Mayor. The
Office of the Mayor shall give notice of the hearing to the holder of the
business regulatory certificate by mailing by regular U.S. Postal Service the
notice of hearing, together with a copy of the charges, to the last address of
record for the holder of the business regulatory certificate.
      4.   At the administrative hearing before the Mayor or his designated
Hearing Officer, the City Treasurer shall first present his documents,
testimony or other evidence he may so choose to support his charges filed with
the Office of the Mayor. The holder of the business regulatory certificate may
be represented by an attorney licensed to practice law in the State of
Illinois, if they so choose. The holder of the business regulatory certificate
shall have an opportunity to respond to the documents, testimony or other
evidence presented by or on behalf of the City Treasurer by presenting
additional documents, testimony or other evidence. All persons who testify
shall be subject to cross examination.
      5.   The hearing may be continued from time to time in the discretion of
the Mayor or the Hearing Officer with notice to the holder of the business
regulatory certificate and City Treasurer or his designated representative
delivered in the course of the hearing or by regular U.S. Postal Service. A
complete record of the hearing shall be made by the Mayor or the Hearing
Officer by audiotape, stenographer or court reporter.
      6.   Upon the conclusion of the evidence and any arguments that may be
permitted on the record in the discretion of the Mayor or the Hearing Officer,
the hearing shall be adjourned. Within fourteen (14) days following the
adjournment of the hearing, the Mayor or the Hearing Officer shall issue a
written decision whether to revoke the business regulatory certificate. Notice
of the written decision, including findings of fact to support the decision,
shall be mailed to the applicant by regular U.S. Postal Service and shall be
filed with the City Treasurer and with the City Clerk contemporaneously with
the mailing thereof and shall thereafter be considered public records.
      7.   After review of any charges filed with the Office of the Mayor by
the City Treasurer, in the matters aforesaid if the Mayor determines that there
exist not only sufficient cause to conduct a hearing to revoke a business
regulatory certificate granted by the City Treasurer, but that the charges
present the reasonable inference of an immediate and substantial threat to the
public health, safety or welfare, so that a condition exists which requires
immediate emergency action; in that event the Mayor may suspend a business
regulatory certificate during the pendency of the hearing described above. In
the event a business regulatory certificate is suspended under the powers of
this subsection, the hearing to be held as described above, shall be held as
promptly as possible. Upon agreement of all parties concerned, the notice and
time requirements for the hearing of this section may be waived. (Ord. 7245, 2-
23-2011)
      8.   The revocation procedures as established in this subsection B shall
not apply to the regulatory certificate or business license required for any
person or beneficial owner to engage in the business of renting or leasing one
or more residential dwelling units in the City of Alton as established by
chapter 21 of this title; there being specific provisions applicable within
chapter 21 of this title concerning the possible sanctions or remedies in the
event of failure to comply with the requirements established for the holder of
such a regulatory certificate or license. (Ord. 7690, 3-27-2019)

4-1-13: CONFLICT:
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with any of the terms or
provisions of this chapter are hereby repealed. All ordinances or parts of
ordinances which more specifically regulate "commercial activities" as
described or defined in this chapter shall remain in full force and effect.
(Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-1-14: INVALIDITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter
is, for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent
provision; and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portion thereof. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
CHAPTER 2
SPECIAL EVENTS
SECTION:
4-2-1: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-2-2: Definition
4-2-3: Exemptions And Exclusions
4-2-4: Exit Lights
4-2-5: Illinois Business Tax Number
4-2-6: Length Of Certificate
4-2-1: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to conduct, promote, or produce
any "special event", as herein defined, without first obtaining a Class B
regulatory certificate as defined in Chapter 1 of this Title. (Ord. 5984, 6-28-
1995)
4-2-2: DEFINITION:
SPECIAL EVENT: Includes, for the purposes of this Chapter, all events which do
not continue in actual and regular business activity for more than a seven (7)
day period and which are not specifically regulated by another chapter or
section of this Title. (Ord. 5984, 6-28-1995)
4-2-3: EXEMPTIONS AND EXCLUSIONS:
No regulatory certificate shall be required for special events held by churches
or fraternal or social organizations; nor for special events held by public or
private schools. (Ord. 5984, 6-28-1995)
4-2-4: EXIT LIGHTS:
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building or hall
used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one hundred (100) persons or
more in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures and other entertainment
is offered, operated or presented to provide and place a sign on which the word
"EXIT" shall appear in letters at least six inches (6") high, over every door
or other opening from such hall to every means of egress therefrom, and a light
shall be provided with a red globe and placed at or over such sign, which light
shall be kept burning during the entire period that the hall is open to the
public and until the audience has left the hall. (Ord. 5984, 6-28-1995)
4-2-5: ILLINOIS BUSINESS TAX NUMBER:
Upon application for a regulatory certificate, pursuant to the provisions of
this Chapter, any person or persons conducting, promoting or producing any
special event must provide the Illinois business tax number of any vendor
participating in retail sales to the City prior to the start of the special
event. (Ord. 5984, 6-28-1995)
4-2-6: LENGTH OF CERTIFICATE:
The special event certificate shall be valid for only one seven (7) day period
at a time. Any requests for an extension of the seven (7) day period must be
approved by the City Treasurer and an additional fee shall be charged. (Ord.
5984, 6-28-1995)
