1958; amd. Ord. 3591, 4-9-1970; Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. 55 ILCS 5/5-1005 et seq.
4-6C-2: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
No person or persons shall open, conduct, manage or maintain a nursing home,
sheltered care home, or home for the aged, without first obtaining a Class C
regulatory certificate, as defined in Chapter 1 of this Title; provided
however, that if such establishment is in operation at the time of the
effective date hereof, they may file application for same within sixty (60)
days after the effective date hereof and continue to operate until said
application is acted upon by the City. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
ARTICLE D. HOTELS
SECTION:
4-6D-1: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-6D-2: Condition Of Premises
4-6D-3: Water Closets
4-6D-4: Register Of Guests
4-6D-5: Inspection
4-6D-1: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a hotel or a building or part
thereof used or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations
are furnished for twenty (20) or more persons for a period of one day or more
without first having obtained a Class C regulatory certificate therefor. (Ord.
4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-6D-2: CONDITION OF PREMISES:
All premises used for hotel purposes shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, and all portions of such premises that are open for use by guests or
by the public shall be kept lighted at all times they are so open to use. All
such premises shall be kept heated between October 1 and May 1 to a temperature
of not less than sixty eight degrees (68°) between the hours of seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and to a temperature of not less than
fifty five degrees (55°) at all other hours. (Ord. 3458, 11-24-1967)
4-6D-3: WATER CLOSETS:
Water closets and lavatories shall be available to all guests using any hotel
and there shall be at least one bathroom equipped with water closet, shower or
tub, and lavatory facilities for each ten (10) residents on the premises. (Ord.
3458, 11-24-1967)
4-6D-4: REGISTER OF GUESTS:
It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any fugitive from justice to stay in
any hotel. Each hotel proprietor shall keep or cause to be kept a register of
guests as required by State law. Such registration shall be available for
inspection by any member of the Police Department at any time. (Ord. 3458, 11-
24-1967)
4-6D-5: INSPECTION:
It shall be the duty of the license inspector to inspect or cause to be
inspected every hotel operated in the City as frequently as may be necessary to
ensure compliance with the provisions of this Article. (Ord. 3458, 11-24-1967)
ARTICLE E. AMBULANCE SERVICE AND INVALID COACH SERVICE
SECTION:
4-6E-1: Definitions
4-6E-2: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-6E-3: Application For License
4-6E-4: Vehicle Registration
4-6E-5: Issuance Of License
4-6E-6: Licensing Authority
4-6E-7: Standards For Ambulances And Invalid Coaches
4-6E-8: Driver And Attendant Standards
4-6E-9: Ambulance Service Or Invalid Coach Service
4-6E-10: Insurance Of Licensee
4-6E-11: Revocation Or Suspension
4-6E-12: Cooperation
4-6E-13: Rules And Regulations
4-6E-1: DEFINITIONS:
AMBULANCE: Any motor vehicle that is especially designed, constructed,
equipped, and intended to be used, maintained and operated for the
transportation of patients in emergency and nonemergency situations.
AMBULANCE SERVICE: The maintenance, operation, or use on the streets, alleys or
any public ways of the City, of a vehicle or vehicles which respond to
emergency calls for the transportation of persons who are sick, injured,
wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless at the time of the dispatch of
the vehicle.
ATTENDANT: A trained and qualified individual responsible for the interim care
of a patient at the scene of an emergency and/or during transit in an ambulance
or invalid coach. Nothing in this definition precludes the attendant from also
serving in the capacity of a driver.
INVALID COACH: Any motor vehicle that is used for the routine transportation of
persons who are physically incapacitated and who must be transported by
stretcher or litter.
INVALID COACH SERVICE: The maintenance, operation, or use on the streets,
alleys or any public ways of the City, of a vehicle or vehicles which respond
to nonemergency calls for the transportation of persons who are physically
incapacitated and who must be transported by stretcher or litter.
PATIENT: An individual who is, or has been sick, wounded or otherwise
incapacitated or helpless at the time of the dispatch of the vehicle.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, association or other
legal entity. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
4-6E-2: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
   A.   Ambulance Service: As used in this Article, ambulance license shall be
interpreted to mean a Class B regulatory certificate as defined in Chapter 1 of
this Title. The requirements of this Article shall be in addition to the
requirements as established for the Class B regulatory certificate of Chapter 1
of this Title. In case of a conflict the requirements of this Article are
hereby declared to prevail.
No person shall own, conduct or operate an ambulance service in the City
without first obtaining an ambulance license as defined herein.
   B.   Invalid Coach Service: As used in this Article, invalid coach license
shall be interpreted to mean a Class B regulatory certificate as defined in
Chapter 1 of this Title. The requirements of this Article shall be in addition
to the requirements as established for the Class B regulatory certificate of
Chapter 1 of this Title. In case of a conflict the requirements of this Article
are hereby declared to prevail.
No person shall own, conduct or operate an invalid coach service in the City
without first obtaining an invalid coach license as defined herein. (Ord. 5008,
3-26-1986)
4-6E-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license to operate an ambulance or invalid coach service and
renewals thereof shall be made upon forms provided by the City Comptroller. The
application shall contain the following:
   A.   The name and address of the applicant; the name and address of the
owner of the ambulances or invalid coaches, if different from that of
applicant.
   B.   The trade or other fictitious name, if any, under which the applicant
does business or proposes to do business.
   C.   The location and description, in such detail as required by licensing
authority, of the place or places from which the ambulance service or invalid
coach service operates or is intended to be operated.
   D.   A description of each ambulance or invalid coach which the applicant
operates or intends to operate within the license year, including the make,
model, year of manufacture, serial number, the length of time the ambulance or
invalid coach has been in use, color scheme, insignia, name, monogram or other
distinguishing characteristics to be used to designate applicant's ambulances
or invalid coaches.
   E.   A detail of training and experience of the applicant in the
transportation and care of patients.
   F.   Such other information as the licensing authority may deem necessary
for a fair determination as to applicant's compliances or ability to comply
with all the provisions of this Article. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
4-6E-4: VEHICLE REGISTRATION:
All applications for license provided herein shall be accompanied by evidence
of a current valid motor vehicle registration for each ambulance or invalid
coach listed in the application. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
4-6E-5: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The licensing authority shall consider in addition to the items provided in the
application form:
   A.   The experience and responsibility of the applicant;
   B.   The effect the proposed service may have on the general health, safety
and welfare of the community;
   C.   Whether applicant is in compliance or can comply with the standards for
ambulances or invalid coaches, including equipment standards;
   D.   Such other matters as may appear to the licensing authority to be
germane to the purpose of this Article. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
4-6E-6: LICENSING AUTHORITY:
The Mayor shall be the licensing authority. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
4-6E-7: STANDARDS FOR AMBULANCES AND INVALID COACHES:
   A.   Ambulances: Every vehicle used as an ambulance shall be designed to
meet the Federal Specification for Ambulances dated July 1, 1985, as prepared
by the General Services Administration, a copy of which shall be kept on file
in the office of the City Clerk; and every vehicle to be used as an ambulance
shall conform to the specifications outlined in said report. Every vehicle used
as an ambulance shall be equipped as outlined in said specifications and shall
include all other equipment and supplies deemed appropriate by the Alton Fire
Chief, except that the equipment specified for release from entrapment or
confinement and the power wrench equipment shall not be required. An ambulance
which meets the criteria set out herein may be used as an invalid coach. (Ord.
5166, 9-9-1987)
   B.   Invalid Coaches: Every vehicle used as an invalid coach shall be
designed and constructed by the manufacturer to safely and comfortably
transport sick, disabled or invalid persons.
Furthermore, an invalid coach shall have installed and contain the following
equipment and supplies:
      1.   Radio communications equipment linked to a hospital or dispatcher;
      2.   Spare oxygen cylinder with a regulator;
      3.   Lateral suction unit;
      4.   Stretcher with linen and pillow;
      5.   Extra linen;
      6.   Extra pillow;
      7.   Two (2) blankets;
      8.   One each large and small emesis basin;
      9.   One complete set of airways;
      10.   Two (2) oxygen cannulas;
      11.   Two (2) oxygen masks;
      12.   All other equipment and supplies as may be deemed appropriate by
the Alton Fire Chief and filed in the City Clerk's Office. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-
1986)
4-6E-8: DRIVER AND ATTENDANT STANDARDS:
   A.   Every ambulance driver or invalid coach driver must possess a valid
driver's license as is issued and required by the State for operation of this
type vehicle 1 .
   B.   In addition to the driver, each ambulance or invalid coach shall have
assigned to it a qualified attendant while such ambulance or invalid coach is
being used for ambulance or invalid coach purposes on the streets, alleys, or
any public way of this City.
   C.   Every ambulance or invalid coach attendant and driver must be qualified
as provided hereafter, except that an ambulance service or invalid coach
service may provide such ambulance or invalid coach with one unqualified driver
or attendant during a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, during which
period such unqualified person is actively engaged in acquiring the necessary
qualifications provided in subsection C4 of this section. A qualified ambulance
or invalid coach attendant and driver shall:
      1.   Be of reputable character and sound physical condition;
      2.   Be free of addiction to intoxicating liquor or drugs;
      3.   Read, write and speak the English language;
      4.   Be certified as an emergency medical technician by the State, or
licensed physician, nurse, physician's assistant, or other licensed medical
professional person. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/6-104.
4-6E-9: AMBULANCE SERVICE OR INVALID COACH SERVICE:
   A.   Each ambulance service licensed by the City shall be operated
continuously at all hours of every day and shall be constituted so as to
provide not less than one approved properly equipped and manned ambulance in
operation, and with one ambulance in immediately operable reserve, all with the
necessary central control and ambulance personnel. (Ord. 7585, 10-11-2017)
   B.   Each invalid coach service licensed by the City shall be operated
continuously from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. of
every day and shall be constituted so as to provide not less than one approved,
properly equipped and manned invalid coach in operation during said hours with
the necessary central control and invalid coach personnel.
   C.   Each licensee must maintain in his office, at all times during the day
or night, a telephone and qualified dispatcher.
   D.   Each ambulance service and invalid coach service licensed shall keep
such adequate records of its equipment and the maintenance thereof, a log of
calls and responses, and records regarding its personnel as the licensing
authority may require. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
4-6E-10: INSURANCE OF LICENSEE:
Every ambulance and invalid coach licensee shall file with the City Clerk,
prior to start of operation under said license, a certificate of insurance of a
reputable and acceptable insurance carrier showing current insurance coverage
for each driver, attendant and ambulance or invalid coach used by the licensee.
The minimum amount of such insurance for personal injury or death shall be one
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person and three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each accident; fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00) for loss of or damage to property, including personal property and
incidental malpractice coverage in the amounts of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00) through three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00). (Ord. 5008,
3-26-1986)
4-6E-11: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
In addition to any penalty that may be provided in this Article, violation of
any of the provisions hereof or a failure to comply with any of the standards
or specifications provided herein, after reasonable notice to licensee and an
opportunity to so comply, may be grounds for suspension or revocation by the
licensing authority, and the privileges thereunder, then once revoked, shall
not again be granted to the same person, firm or corporation, or any such firm
or entity made up in part of the person or persons formerly of interest in the
revoked license or privileges. Any licensee, whose license is revoked or whose
licensee is suspended for a period of more than two (2) weeks, may, in writing,
request of the licensing authority a hearing on such revocation or suspension,
which hearing shall be held within ten (10) days after being notified of the
revocation or suspension. The hearing will be held by the licensing authority,
or his qualified designee, at which hearing anything touching upon any aspect
of the license, the vehicle's equipment, operation, personnel, qualifications,
character, or any other consideration involving the licensee or ambulance
service or invalid coach service of such licensee may be considered. Upon the
conclusion of the hearing, the licensing authority or his qualified designee
shall reduce to writing, within five (5) days, his findings with regard to such
hearing, a copy of which is to be furnished to licensee. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986;
amd. 1999 Code)
4-6E-12: COOPERATION:
All ambulance services listed by the City and the personnel thereof shall
cooperate with one another and with the other public safety and emergency
services operating within the City, both generally and specifically, at the
scene of an emergency. In the event the Fire Chief or his designated assistant
is on the scene, they shall be in charge until the patient is released to the
ambulance service. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-1986)
4-6E-13: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The licensing authority is authorized to make such reasonable rules and
regulations not contrary to or in conflict with the provisions of this Article
as he may deem necessary and desirable to implement, clarify, refine, or
enforce the provisions hereof, all in the public interest. (Ord. 5008, 3-26-
1986)
ARTICLE F. HORSE-DRAWN VEHICLES
SECTION:
4-6F-1: Definitions
4-6F-2: Applications
4-6F-3: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-6F-4: Route Proposals
4-6F-5: Review By City Officials
4-6F-6: License, License Fees, Proof Of Insurance
4-6F-7: Change, Discontinue Service; Transfer Of Certificates
4-6F-8: Offices Required
4-6F-9: Safety And Health
4-6F-10: Stops And Stands
4-6F-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, wherever they occur in this Article, shall be
construed as herein defined:
APPLICANT: Any person who has filed an application to become a certificate
holder under the provisions of this Article.
CERTIFICATE HOLDER: Any person holding one or more business regulatory
certificates issued pursuant to the provisions contained in Chapter 1 of this
Title for the operation of horse-drawn vehicles.
FOR HIRE: The provision of services, or the offering of services, of a horse-
drawn vehicle for the payment of money or other consideration.
HORSE-DRAWN VEHICLE: A coach or other vehicle which is powered in whole or in
part by one or more horses, mules or other animals.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or
any other legal entity. (Ord. 5577, 7-24-1991)
4-6F-2: APPLICATIONS:
An application for the appropriate regulatory certificate shall be made
pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 1 of this Title, with the following
exceptions and additions:
   A.   The portion of subsection
4-1-6A of this Title which addresses the movement of a commercial establishment
from one location in the City to another location in the City shall not be
applicable to horse-drawn vehicles.
   B.   Subsection
4-1-3C of this Title shall not be applicable to horse-drawn vehicles.
   C.   Subsection
4-1-3B of this Title shall not be applicable to horse-drawn vehicles.
   D.   The operation of a horse-drawn vehicle or vehicles shall be considered
the same as the operation of a commercial establishment for application
purposes.
   E.   In addition to any other information which may be requested, the
application shall contain information concerning the previous experience of the
applicant with respect to horse-drawn vehicle operations, the number of
vehicles the applicant desires to operate, and the passenger capacity of each
such vehicle. Further, the application shall contain information concerning the
type of insurance to be carried, the amount of the insurance and the company
issuing the policy. (Ord. 5577, 7-24-1991)
4-6F-3: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any horse-drawn vehicle
operations or to provide horse-drawn vehicle services for hire, as herein
defined, without first obtaining a Class A regulatory certificate as defined in
Section
4-1-6 of this Title. (Ord. 5577, 7-24-1991)
4-6F-4: ROUTE PROPOSALS:
Along with the application for regulatory certificate, all applicants will file
a proposed routing or routings for each horse-drawn vehicle which is to be
operated. All such proposed routings shall include all anticipated stopping
and/or standing locations for each respective horse-drawn vehicle. (Ord. 5577,
7-24-1991)
4-6F-5: REVIEW BY CITY OFFICIALS:
In addition to the investigations listed in Section
4-1-5 of this Title, all applications submitted pursuant to the terms of this
Article shall be subject to an investigation by the Business and Economic
Development Director and the Park Commission. (Ord. 5577, 7-24-1991)
4-6F-6: LICENSE, LICENSE FEES, PROOF OF INSURANCE:
Upon the making of a determination that a business regulatory certificate may
be issued, pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 1 of this Title, the applicant
shall pay an annual license fee provided for Class A certificates in Section
4-1-6 of this Title for each horse-drawn vehicle which is to be operated by the
applicant. No regulatory certificate will issue until all necessary license
fees have been paid by the applicant. The license shall be in the possession of
the operator of all such horse-drawn vehicles at all times when said vehicle is
on a public right of way. Further, the applicant shall present a copy of the
insurance policy, which is intended to cover the operation of all licensed
horse-drawn vehicles, at the time the applicant pays any license fees. (Ord.
5577, 7-24-1991; amd. 1999 Code)
4-6F-7: CHANGE, DISCONTINUE SERVICE; TRANSFER OF CERTIFICATES:
   A.   Any proposed changes in routes, number of horse-drawn vehicles and/or
levels or type of insurance shall be submitted in writing to the City
Treasurer's office. No such proposed changes shall take effect until permission
has been granted by the City Treasurer's office.
   B.   An increase in the number of horse-drawn vehicles to be operated will
result in an additional license fee for each such vehicle. A decrease in the
number of horse-drawn vehicles will not result in any refund of license fees.
   C.   No person who has received a regulatory certificate to operate horse-
drawn vehicles may discontinue the operation of such horse-drawn vehicles
without first filing a written request to discontinue operation and without
first obtaining permission therefor from the City Treasurer's office. The
withdrawal of any vehicle from operation, for the purpose of conditioning,
overhauling or repairing, shall not be considered a discontinuance of operation
under this Section.
   D.   No holder of a regulatory certificate may sell, assign, lease or
otherwise transfer the rights and privileges granted thereunder, including any
licenses which have been issued, to any other person without first having
obtained the written permission of the City Treasurer's office. (Ord. 5577, 7-
24-1991)
4-6F-8: OFFICES REQUIRED:
Each certificate holder is required to have and maintain an office to which can
be directed any reports of lost articles, complaints, inquiries and related
matters. (Ord. 5577, 7-24-1991)
4-6F-9: SAFETY AND HEALTH:
   A.   Each horse harness shall be equipped with a leather diaper. Each
operator of a horse-drawn vehicle shall ensure that any feces deposited on the
public right of way or any private property within the City is cleaned up
immediately after such deposit or as soon thereafter as is reasonable.
   B.   All restrictions and requirements for motorized vehicles contained in
this Code or in the Illinois State Statutes shall apply to horse-drawn vehicles
except those which by nature could have no application. All carriages shall, in
addition, display the international sign for slow-moving vehicles on the rear
of each such vehicle. (Ord. 5577, 7-24-1991)
4-6F-10: STOPS AND STANDS:
For the purposes of taking on and discharging passengers, a horse-drawn vehicle
shall stop at the far corner of all intersections, and while so stopped, shall
keep as close to the right-hand curb as practicable, and shall take on and
discharge passengers as quickly as possible, so as not to reasonably interfere
with traffic. (Ord. 5577, 7-24-1991)
ARTICLE G. TAXICABS
SECTION:
4-6G-1: Definitions
4-6G-2: Taxicab License
4-6G-3: Application For License
4-6G-4: Markings
4-6G-5: Rates
4-6G-6: Driver's License
4-6G-7: Taxicab Safety
4-6G-8: Revocation
4-6G-1: DEFINITIONS:
DRIVER: When used in this article shall include every person in charge of or
operating any "taxicab" as herein defined, either as agent, employee or
otherwise.
OWNER: When used in this article shall be construed to mean any person, firm or
corporation who has the bona fide legal title or control, direction, operation,
maintenance, leasing or the collection of revenues deriving from such taxicabs
so operated for hire on the streets in the city.
TAXICAB: As used in this article means all motor vehicles propelled and
operated for passenger hire, including limousines, and except motor buses
running and operating on established routes, sightseeing buses, charter buses,
and funeral vehicles. (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
4-6G-2: TAXICAB LICENSE:
No owner or driver shall operate any taxicab without first having obtained a
license therefor. (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
4-6G-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring a license for any taxicab shall:
   A.   File an application with the city treasurer on a form provided for that
purpose setting forth the name, business and residence address of the
applicant, full description of the motor vehicle for which a license is
desired, and the registration plate of such motor vehicle as set forth in 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-412(e), as amended from time to time;
   B.   File with the city treasurer a proof of financial responsibility as set
forth in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-101 et seq., as amended from time
to time; (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
   C.   Submit to the city treasurer, with the application, a taxicab license
regulatory fee in the amount applicable to a class A business regulation
certificate as set forth in chapter 1 of this title as established from time to
time; (Ord. 7158, 10-28-2009)
   D.   Taxicab licenses issued under this article shall not be assignable
unless the proposed assignee shall first file with the city treasurer the
information required by this section; (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
   E.   Taxicab licenses issued shall run for one calendar year and may be
renewed upon the payment of a new yearly regulatory fee, and proof of proper
registration and financial responsibility as set forth above. The license
period shall commence on January 1 and end December 31 of each year. (Ord.
6055, 4-10-1996)
4-6G-4: MARKINGS:
Each and every taxicab which may be licensed under this article, and operated
in the city, shall exhibit the license issued in a conspicuous place inside the
vehicle. (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
4-6G-5: RATES:
Each and every taxicab licensed under this article and operated in the city
shall post inside the vehicle at a location visible to passenger(s) the rates
of fare being charged. (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
4-6G-6: DRIVER'S LICENSE:
No person shall operate and drive a taxicab unless he has a valid driver's
license as prescribed in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-100 et seq., as
amended from time to time. (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
4-6G-7: TAXICAB SAFETY:
No taxicab shall be operated in the City unless it is equipped with proper
brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirrors and windshield wipers
in good condition. It shall be the duty of any person operating any taxicab in
the City, whether as owner, operator, driver, lessee or licensee, to submit the
same, upon request to the Chief of Police or any other police officer of the
City, for examination for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not said
taxicab is in good condition and otherwise complied with all the requirements
of the laws of the State with reference to motor vehicles and the operation
thereof. (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981; amd. Ord. 5802, 8-11-1993)
4-6G-8: REVOCATION 1 :
The Mayor of the City is hereby empowered and authorized to remove or suspend
the license of any taxicab found not to be safe or not in good condition; and
the Mayor may revoke any license issued under the provisions of this Article
for failure on the part of the owner, operator, driver, lessee or licensee to
comply with all of the provisions of this Article, or for failure to comply
with any State law pertaining to the operation of motor vehicles or for failure
to comply with any provision or traffic regulations at any particular time in
force in the City. In the event of the suspension or revocation of a license,
no refund shall be made to the person to whom said license was issued for any
portion of the license fee previously paid. (Ord. 4711, 8-11-1981)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  4-1-12 of this Code for due process procedures.
ARTICLE H. SURFACE BLASTING
SECTION:
4-6H-1: Definitions
4-6H-2: License Required
4-6H-3: Blasting Signs, Warnings And Access Control
4-6H-4: Control Of Adverse Effects
4-6H-5: Records Of Blasting Operations
4-6H-6: Penalties
4-6H-7: Administrative Remedies
4-6H-1: DEFINITIONS:
SURFACE BLASTING: The practice of using explosives to loosen earth or stone at
or near the surface of property for mining, construction, excavation,
demolition of existing structures or obstructions, or related activities.
"Surface blasting" shall not include underground mining activities which do not
immediately affect the exposed surface of the earth. (Ord. 5723, 11-25-1992)
4-6H-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any person engaged in blasting operations must obtain and maintain a Class E
regulatory certificate as defined in Chapter 1 of this Title. The Fire Chief of
the City shall be charged with the responsibility to review the application for
a regulatory certificate pertaining to blasting operations and to monitor the
compliance with the terms of this Article by the person conducting the blasting
operation from time to time. It shall be unlawful to conduct any blasting
operation without a valid City issued regulatory certificate. (Ord. 5723, 11-
25-1992)
4-6H-3: BLASTING SIGNS, WARNINGS AND ACCESS CONTROL:
The owner or operator of any blasting operation shall:
   A.   Conspicuously display signs reading "Blasting Area" along the edge of
any blasting area that comes within one hundred feet (100') of any public road,
and at the point where any other road provides access to the blasting area;
   B.   At all entrances to the blasting area from public roads, place
conspicuous signs which state "Warning! Explosives in Use" and which clearly
list and describe the meaning of the audible blast warning;
   C.   Give warning signals that are audible within one-half (1/2) mile of the
blast one minute before each blast occurs;
   D.   Access to the blasting area shall be controlled to prevent the presence
of unauthorized personnel during blasting;
   E.   Conduct all blasting operations between the hours eight o'clock (8:00)
A.M. and four o'clock (4:00) P.M.;
   F.   In an ongoing blasting operation (such as a mining or long-term
construction project), a daily blasting schedule shall be established and made
available to the City for public dissemination which schedule shall specify
within fifteen (15) minutes the time at which blasting shall occur each day and
blasting shall occur at no time other than as determined by said schedule. The
Fire Chief of the City may require such a schedule by giving notice to any
owner or operator that their blasting operation is one required to comply with
this Section due to its ongoing regular blasting operations. (Ord. 5723, 11-25-
1992)
4-6H-4: CONTROL OF ADVERSE EFFECTS:
   A.   Air Blast Limits:
      1.   Air blast shall be controlled so that it does not exceed the values
specified below at any dwelling, public building, school, church, or commercial
or institutional structure, unless such structure is owned by the person who
conducts the blasting operation and is not leased to any person. If a building
owned by the person conducting the blasting operations is leased to another
person, the lessee may sign a waiver relieving the operator from meeting the
air blast limitations of this subsection. The waiver shall be submitted to the
City Clerk before beginning the blasting.
         Lower frequency limited    Maximum
         measuring system, Hz+3dB    Level in dB
         2.0 Hz or lower-flat response    133 peak
      2.   The measuring systems used shall have a flat frequency response of
at least two hundred (200) Hz at the upper end.
   B.   Flyrock: Flyrock, including blasted material traveling in the air or
along the ground, shall not be cast beyond the permit boundaries or more than
one-half (1/2) the distance to the nearest dwelling or other occupied
structure. "Permit boundaries" as used herein shall be the area described
within the permit issued by the City within which surface blasting is to be
allowed.
   C.   Peak Particle Velocity: In all blasting operations the maximum peak
particle velocity, as measured from any one of three (3) mutually perpendicular
directions, shall not exceed one inch (1") per second at the location of any
dwelling, public building, school, church or commercial or institutional
building.
   D.   Recordings: As used herein, airblast or peak particle velocity
recording or record shall mean a visually inspectable cartesian representation
of the time history of the particle velocity levels, and air blast levels
versus time. Time is represented on the "X" axis. The particle velocity is
shown by three (3) traces representing mutually perpendicular components are
oriented vertically, transversely and longitudinally to the horizontal
direction from the recording location to the location of the blast. The air
blast time history is represented by a single trace. The record or recording
includes either analog representation of, or a written description of the
vertical scale for the particle velocity traces and the air blast trace. The
units for the particle velocity traces and scale are in inches per second. The
units for the air blast trace and scale are millibars, pounds per square inch,
or decibels. The recording also includes an analog or descriptive time scale.
The time units are in seconds. (Ord. 5723, 11-25-1992)
4-6H-5: RECORDS OF BLASTING OPERATIONS:
A record level of each blast shall be retained by the operator for at least
three (3) years and shall be available for inspection by the City and the
public on request. The record is to be completed by the end of the work day
following the day in which the blast occurred, and shall contain the following
data:
   A.   Name of the operator conducting blast;
   B.   Location, date, and time of the blast;
   C.   Name, signature and certification of the blaster conducting the blast;
   D.   Type of material blasted;
   E.   Number of holes, burden and spacing;
   F.   Diameter and depth of holes;
   G.   Types of explosives used;
   H.   Total weight of explosives used;
   I.   Weight of explosives per hole;
   J.   Maximum weight of explosives and detonated within any eight (8)
millispeed period;
   K.   Initiation system;
   L.   Type of length of stemming;
   M.   Type of delay, detonator and delay periods used. (Ord. 5723, 11-25-
1992)
4-6H-6: PENALTIES:
Any violation of the regulations of this Article shall be considered an
ordinance offense. Each and every time a violation occurs shall be considered a
separate offense. Each offense shall be punishable as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. The penalties herein provided are in addition to the
administrative remedies provided by Section
4-6H-7 of this Article. (Ord. 5723, 11-25-1992; amd. 1999 Code)
4-6H-7: ADMINISTRATIVE REMEDIES:
   A.   In the event the Fire Chief of the City determines that the owner or
operator of any blasting operation has failed to comply with the requirements
set forth in this Article, the Fire Chief shall give notice to the owner or
operator, which notice shall set forth the specific nature of the alleged
failure to comply. The certificate holder shall then have seven (7) calendar
days to dispute in writing the alleged failure to comply. If he fails to so
dispute the alleged failure in writing within seven (7) days of receipt of the
notice as aforesaid, a violation will be deemed to have occurred. For each
violation cited by the Fire Chief, the holder of the regulatory certificate
shall be assessed a penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. The
one hundred dollars ($100.00) penalty must be paid within three (3) days of
demand for same served upon the holder by the Fire Chief.
Failure to pay the penalties as aforesaid shall result in revocation of the
regulatory certificate permitting blasting operations.
   B.   In the event the holder of the regulatory certificate disputes the
allegations of violations made by the Fire Chief, the matter shall be referred
to the Mayor. The Mayor or his designee shall then conduct a hearing to
determine whether a violation of this Article has been committed. Notice of any
such hearing shall be given to those persons to whom the regulatory certificate
involved was issued by mailing such notices to such persons by regular U.S.
Postal Service not less than three (3) days prior to the commencement of such
hearing. The notice of hearing shall include a brief summary of the causes
believed to exist, which may lead to the revocation of any regulatory
certificate. Those persons receiving said notices may appear at said hearing,
where they may be represented by counsel, and have an opportunity to respond to
any charges or evidence against them, question any witnesses who may present
testimony or evidence at said hearing, and present testimony or evidence in
their own behalf relative to the question of revocation of any regulatory
certificate issued to them. A record of any such hearing will be made upon
written request of any person to whom notice of said hearing was mailed,
provided said written request is received by the office of the Mayor not less
than one day prior to the commencement of said hearing, and further provided
that the person requesting that a record be made agrees to pay for the cost of
such record. At the conclusion of any hearing the Mayor shall make written
findings of fact to support his conclusions. Said findings shall be mailed in
the same manner as were the notices of the respective hearing, and further said
findings shall be filed with the City Clerk and considered public records.
   C.   In the event the Mayor determines that there exists not only sufficient
cause to revoke a regulatory certificate granted by him, but that such cause
presents an immediate and substantial threat to the public safety, health or
welfare, so that a condition exists which requires immediate emergency action;
the Mayor, in that event, may suspend a regulatory certificate during the
pendency of the hearing described in this Section. In the event a regulatory
certificate is suspended under the powers of this Section, the hearing to be
held in accordance with this Section shall be held as promptly as possible.
Upon agreement of all parties concerned, the notice and time requirements of
this Section may be waived in the event a regulatory certificate has been
suspended under the power of this Section. In addition to the power to revoke
the regulatory certificate following a hearing as aforesaid, the Mayor shall
further have the power to suspend the regulatory certificate for blasting for
any period up to one year or, in the alternative, to suggest financial
penalties to the holder of the regulatory certificate which may be paid in lieu
of suspension.
   D.   The decision of the Mayor following the hearing process described above
shall be considered a final administrative decision, appealable under the
Administrative Review Act of Illinois 1 . (Ord. 5723, 11-25-1992)
 
Notes
1 1. 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
ARTICLE I. FORTUNETELLING
SECTION:
4-6I-1: Authority
4-6I-2: Definitions
4-6I-3: Permit Required
4-6I-4: Application For Permit
4-6I-5: Approval By Police Chief
4-6I-6: Prohibited Acts Or Conditions
4-6I-7: Enforcement
4-6I-8: Severability
4-6I-9: Violation; Penalty
4-6I-1: AUTHORITY:
It is hereby declared that the business of fortunetelling, as defined herein,
is a business affecting the public health, safety and general welfare; that the
City is a home rule city under the Constitution of the State of Illinois, 1970.
(Ord. 3963, 12-26-1974)
4-6I-2: DEFINITIONS:
FORTUNETELLING: The practice by anyone of fortunetelling, palmistry,
clairvoyance, spirits, mediumship, seership, prophecy, necromancy or other
craft, science, cards, talismans, charms, potions, magnetism or magnetized
articles or substances, oriental mysteries or magic of any kind or nature, by
which the past, present or future is prophesied, or the restoration of lost
love, friendship or affection is represented as being possible, or the uniting
or procuring of lovers, husbands, wives, lost relatives or friends is
represented, or the removal of evil or hexes is represented, any of the above
of which is offered for or without pay; provided, however, that this definition
shall not be construed to include, prohibit or interfere with the exercise of
any religious or spiritual function of any priest, minister or any accredited
representative of any bona fide church or religion where such priest, minister
or accredited representative holds a certificate of accreditation, commission
or ordination under the ecclesiastical laws of a religious corporation or any
voluntary religious association, and who fully conforms to the rights and
practices prescribed by the law, supreme conferences, convocation, convention,
assembly, association or synod of the system or faith with which they are
affiliated. (Ord. 3963, 12-26-1974; amd. 1999 Code)
4-6I-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in or carry on the business of fortunetelling unless he
has a valid and subsisting fortunetelling permit issued by the City, pursuant
to the provisions of this Article for each and every separate office or place
of business conducted by such person. (Ord. 3963, 12-26-1974)
As used herein, fortunetelling permit shall be interpreted to mean a Class D
regulatory certificate as defined in Chapter 1 of this Title, and the
requirements of a Class D regulatory certificate as so defined shall apply in
addition to the requirements of this Article. In case of conflict, the
requirements of this Article shall be valid. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-
1979)
4-6I-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person desiring a fortunetelling business permit shall file a written
application with the Police Chief on a form to be furnished by the Police
Chief. The applicant shall accompany the application with a tender of the
correct permit fee as hereinafter provided and shall, in addition, furnish the
following:
   A.   The type of ownership of the business, whether individual, partnership,
corporation or otherwise;
   B.   The name, style and designation under which the business or practice is
to be conducted;
   C.   The business address and all telephone numbers where the business or
practice is to be conducted;
   D.   Name, complete residence address and residence telephone number of
applicant;
   E.   Age of applicant;
   F.   Two (2) front face portrait photographs taken within thirty (30) days
of the date of the application of the applicant;
   G.   A complete set of fingerprints taken and to be retained on file by the
Police Chief or his authorized representative;
   H.   The names and addresses of three (3) adult residents of the County of
Madison who will serve as character references. These references must be
persons other than relatives;
   I.   Such other information, identification and physical examination of the
person as shall be deemed necessary by the Police Chief to discover the truth
of the matters hereinbefore required to be set forth in the application;
   J.   Written declaration by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that
the information furnished on the application is true and correct. (Ord. 3963,
12-26-1974; amd. 1999 Code)
4-6I-5: APPROVAL BY POLICE CHIEF:
Upon receiving the application for a fortuneteller's permit, the Police Chief
shall conduct an investigation into the applicant's moral character and shall
investigate or cause to be investigated an investigation of the premises where
the business or practice is to be carried on. Before any permit shall issue
under this Article, the Police Chief shall first sign his approval of the
application based upon his investigation as set forth above. (Ord. 3963, 12-26-
1974)
4-6I-6: PROHIBITED ACTS OR CONDITIONS:
   A.   False Advertising; Identification Sign: No person shall make claim or
advertise by sign, circular, handbill, or in any newspaper, periodical,
magazine or other publication or publications, or by any other means, the
business or practice of fortunetelling as defined herein, to hold themselves
out to be able to cure, alleviate or relieve physical or mental ailments.
Nothing in this subsection shall preclude a nameplate identification sign, not
exceeding four feet by four feet (4' x 4') lighted only with a nonintermittent
light, to be placed where the business or practice is located. (Ord. 3963, 12-
26-1974; amd. Ord. 3970, 3-26-1975)
   B.   Age Limit For Permit: No person shall be eligible to make application
for a permit as provided herein unless he has attained the age of eighteen (18)
years.
   C.   Alcoholic Beverages: No person shall give, sell, dispense, provide or
keep or cause to be sold, given, dispensed, provided or kept, any alcoholic
beverage on the premises of any fortunetelling business or practice. (Ord.
3963, 12-26-1974)
4-6I-7: ENFORCEMENT:
The Chief of Police or his authorized representatives may make and enforce
reasonable rules and regulations not in conflict with but to carry out the
intent of this Article. (Ord. 3963, 12-26-1974)
4-6I-8: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
in this Article is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or
ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not
affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of this Article.
(Ord. 3963, 12-26-1974)
4-6I-9: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Every person, except those persons who are specifically exempted by definition
in this Article, whether acting as an individual, owner, employee of the owner,
operator or employee of the operator, or whether acting as a mere helper for
the owner, employee or operator, or acting as a participant or worker in any
way in the business of fortunetelling, who practices the business of
fortunetelling without first obtaining a permit and paying a license fee to do
so from the City, or shall violate any of the provisions of this Article shall,
upon conviction, be punished as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 3963, 12-26-1974; amd. Ord. 4255, 11-23-1977; 1999
Code)
CHAPTER 7
FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
ARTICLE A. RESTAURANTS
SECTION:
4-7A-1: Definitions
4-7A-2: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-7A-1: DEFINITIONS:
CARRYOUT RESTAURANT: Any place where food or drink is prepared and served to
the public for immediate consumption on the premises and where the food or
drink is available for carryout of the premises by consumers.
CONVENIENCE STORE: A retail establishment offering a variety of products,
including prepared and ready to eat food products or ready to drink soft drinks
sold in single serving containers.
GROCERY STORE: A retail establishment offering a variety of products for sale,
but with an inventory primarily concentrated in food products to be further
prepared by the customer at a future time. If a grocery store also offers for
sale prepared or ready to eat food products or soft drinks in single serving
disposable containers, a grocery store shall also be considered a convenience
store for purposes of this article.
RESTAURANT: Any place where food or drink is prepared and served to the public
for immediate consumption on the premises. (Ord. 7007, 5-9-2007, eff. 6-15-
2007)
4-7A-2: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate a restaurant, carryout restaurant or
convenience store in the city without having first obtained a class C
regulatory certificate as defined in chapter 1 of this title, and without full
compliance with the provisions of this code. No restaurant, carryout restaurant
or convenience store operator shall be required to obtain a class C regulatory
certificate for any period of time during which the restaurant, carryout
restaurant or convenience store in question holds a liquor license from the
city of Alton. (Ord. 7007, 5-9-2007, eff. 6-15-2007)
ARTICLE B. SIDEWALK CAFES
SECTION:
4-7B-1: Definitions
4-7B-2: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-7B-3: Applications For Certificate
4-7B-4: Proof Of Insurance Required
4-7B-5: Compliance With Design Proposed
4-7B-6: Maintenance Of Cafes
4-7B-7: Location And Site Restrictions
4-7B-8: Hours Of Operation
4-7B-9: Revocation Of Certificates
4-7B-10: Violation
4-7B-11: Renewal
4-7B-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, wherever they occur in this article, shall be
construed as herein defined:
APPLICANT: Any person who has filed an application to become a certificate
holder under the provisions of this article.
CERTIFICATE HOLDER: Any person holding one or more business regulatory
certificates issued pursuant to the provisions contained in chapter 1 of this
title for the operation of a sidewalk cafe.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or
any other legal entity.
SIDEWALK CAFE: A publicly accessible outdoor seating area, on public property,
where alcoholic beverages, nonalcoholic beverages, or food may be served. (Ord.
5669, 6-24-1992; amd. Ord. 7268, 8-24-2011; Ord. 7345, 12-19-2012; Ord. 7601,
11-21-2017)
4-7B-2: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a "sidewalk cafe", as herein
defined, without first obtaining a liquor license or a Class C regulatory
certificate, as defined in chapter 1 of this title. (Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
4-7B-3: APPLICATIONS FOR CERTIFICATE:
An application for the appropriate regulatory certificate to operate a sidewalk
cafe may be made pursuant to the provisions of chapter 1 of this title, with
the following additional requirements:
   A.   Only the holder of a liquor license or a Class C regulatory certificate
issued by the City of Alton may apply for a regulatory certificate to operate a
sidewalk cafe. Applicants holding a Class C regulatory certificate shall apply
to the City Treasurer and applicants holding a liquor license shall apply to
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner.
   B.   The application for a regulatory certificate to operate a sidewalk cafe
shall contain a design of the proposed layout of the sidewalk cafe, including
the location of all tables, chairs, and other items intended to be used or
located within the defined area of the sidewalk cafe. The design submitted
shall include accurate dimensions of the area and the various furnishings,
fixtures and other items to be included within the sidewalk cafe. A description
of the furniture, fixtures, and other items to be used on or within the
proposed sidewalk cafe shall also be furnished with the application.
   C.   All applications submitted to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner or
City Treasurer shall be referred to the City Treasurer, Police Department, Fire
Department, Public Works and City Planner for an opportunity to review and
comment before the Local Liquor Control Commissioner or City Treasurer
concludes his investigation and decision. (Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
4-7B-4: PROOF OF INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Following approval of an application for issuance of a regulatory certificate,
but prior to the issuance of said regulatory certificate, an applicant shall
provide to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner a certificate of liability
insurance which names the City of Alton as an additional insured commensurate
with the information contained in the application. (Ord. 6683, 10-23-2002; amd.
Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
The certificate of liability insurance shall be effective from January 1 of
each year through December 31st of each year and a new certificate of liability
insurance shall be provided on or before January 1st of each year and upon any
renewals for each year that the lease is in effect. (Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
4-7B-5: COMPLIANCE WITH DESIGN PROPOSED:
The holder of a regulatory certificate permitting the operation of a sidewalk
cafe shall at all times maintain the sidewalk cafe in compliance with the
design of the sidewalk cafe as proposed in the original application for the
regulatory certificate to operate the sidewalk cafe. Should the holder of the
regulatory certificate permitting the operation of a sidewalk cafe desire to
vary the design, furniture, or fixtures utilized within the sidewalk cafe, a
revised design or plan must be submitted to the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner or the City Treasurer before changes are made by the holder of the
regulatory certificate. The Local Liquor Control Commissioner or the City
Treasurer upon review of the requested modifications may approve the same in a
written approval or request review and input from other departments of the City
of Alton. (Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
4-7B-6: MAINTENANCE OF CAFES:
All sidewalk cafes shall be cleaned, maintained and repaired on a regular
basis. Any public property damaged as a result of the operation of the sidewalk
cafe shall be the responsibility of the certificate holder to repair. All such
repairs and maintenance shall be undertaken immediately upon the request of the
City. (Ord. 5669, 6-24-1992)
4-7B-7: LOCATION AND SITE RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Sidewalk cafes shall only be allowed on property within zoning
districts zoned C-2, C-4 and MR. (Ord. 5669, 6-24-1992)
   B.   All sidewalk cafes located on City property shall maintain at least
three feet (3') in width of unimpeded sidewalk space for pedestrian movement.
(Ord. 7268, 8-24-2011)
   C.   Sidewalk cafes located on City property shall not unreasonably
interfere with pedestrian circulation and shall not interfere with the
circulation or parking of vehicular traffic.
   D.   Sidewalk cafes located on City property shall be directly adjacent to
the principal place of business of the certificate holder and no point of the
sidewalk cafe shall be greater than one hundred twenty five feet (125') from
the main entrance of the principal place of business.
   E.   No permanent additions or structures of any type shall be permitted
upon City property. (Ord. 5669, 6-24-1992)
   F.   There shall be no sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption off of
the premises from a sidewalk cafe. (Ord. 7268, 8-24-2011)
   G.   All sidewalk cafes shall provide lighting which is appropriate and
adequate for the safety of the patrons of the sidewalk cafe and for all others.
(Ord. 5669, 6-24-1992)
   H.   All patrons on the sidewalk cafe must be seated while holding any
alcoholic beverage. (Ord. 7268, 8-24-2011)
4-7B-8: HOURS OF OPERATION:
The lawful hours of operation shall be:
 
Monday - Saturday 6:00 A.M. - 1:00 A.M.
Sunday            12:00 Noon - 1:00 A.M.
(Ord. 5898, 7-27-1994)
No alcoholic liquor may be sold or consumed except during the lawful hours of
operation. (Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
4-7B-9: REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATES 1 :
All regulatory certificates issued pursuant to the terms of this article shall
be subject to revocation upon a determination that the certificate holder or
the sidewalk cafe is in violation of the terms of this article or is in
violation of any other provisions of this Code or any other relevant regulatory
requirement. All such regulatory certificates shall also be subject to
revocation upon a determination that it is in the best interests of the public
health, safety or welfare. There shall be no compensation or other recompense
to a certificate holder or anyone else in connection with the revocation of a
regulatory certificate pursuant to the terms of this article. (Ord. 5669, 6-24-
1992)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  4-1-12 of this title.
4-7B-10: VIOLATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the restrictions
established in this article with regard to the operation of a sidewalk cafe.
Any person who violates the restrictions of the sidewalk cafe regulatory
certificate as established herein may be charged with an ordinance violation
and the holder of the regulatory certificate may also be charged for permitting
or allowing the violation to occur or to continue. (Ord. 7268, 8-24-2011)
4-7B-11: RENEWAL:
Following approval of the application for issuance of a regulatory certificate
for a sidewalk cafe, a lease agreement shall be established for a term of five
(5) years between the applicant and the City of Alton. In the event that no
changes are made to the design, space or application for regulatory
certificate, and the licensee has been in full compliance with all City Code
requirements, the application fee shall be waived and the application for
renewal and renewal may be approved without being referred to the Police
Department, Fire Department, Public Works and City Planner for approval. (Ord.
7601, 11-21-2017)
CHAPTER 8
RETAIL ESTABLISHMENTS
ARTICLE A. DANGEROUS WEAPONS
SECTION:
4-8A-1: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-8A-2: Reports
4-8A-3: Knives, Knuckles
4-8A-4: Revocation
4-8A-1: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling, or to
sell or to give away to any person within the City, any pistol, revolver,
derringer, shotgun or rifle, antique firearm or weapon, stiletto, sword,
bayonet or machete of any and all description, or any knife with a blade three
inches (3") or more in length (except those commonly used in food preparation),
or any blackjack or sap, or any other weapon of like character, which can be
concealed on the person, without first obtaining a Class B regulatory
certificate as defined in Chapter 1 of this Title. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff.
1-1-1979)
4-8A-2: REPORTS:
Every person who is licensed to deal with deadly weapons described in Section
4-8A-1 of this Article shall make out and deliver to the Chief of Police of the
City every Monday before the hour of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon a legible and
correct report of every sale or gift of firearms made under authority of the
said license during the preceding week, which report shall contain the date of
such sale or gift, the name of the purchaser or donee, with his address and
age, the number, kind, description of such weapon, and the purpose given by
such person for the purchase of said weapon. (Ord. 2588, 10-15-1955)
4-8A-3: KNIVES, KNUCKLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or barter to any person within the
City, spring or switch blade knives or knuckles. (Ord. 2588, 10-15-1955)
4-8A-4: REVOCATION 1 :
In case the officers and officials of the City shall be satisfied that such
licensee wilfully and intentionally violated any provision of this Article,
they then may and shall revoke the license of such person from the selling of
such weapons and the money paid for such license shall be forfeited to the City
and license shall be issued to such licensee for a period of three (3) years
thereafter subject to judicial review. (Ord. 2588, 10-15-1955)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  4-1-12 of this Title for due process procedures.
ARTICLE B. LIQUID PETROLEUM AND OTHER HAZARDOUS MATERIALS DEALERS
SECTION:
4-8B-1: Liquid Petroleum Products
4-8B-2: Hazardous Materials
4-8B-1: LIQUID PETROLEUM PRODUCTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage or continue in the business of
selling, dispensing, dealing, peddling or delivering any liquid petroleum
products within the City, commonly used as a combustible fuel, without first
having obtained a Class C regulatory certificate as defined in Chapter 1 of
this Title. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-8B-2: HAZARDOUS MATERIALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage or continue in the business of
selling, dispensing, dealing, peddling or delivering any hazardous materials
within the City, without having first obtained a Class C regulatory certificate
as defined in Chapter 1 of this Title. For the purpose of this Section,
"hazardous materials" shall be those materials so defined in the United States
Department of Transportation, National Highway Traffic Safety Administration
and Materials Transportation Bureau in their publication entitled "Emergency
Action Guide for Selected Hazardous Materials" dated 1978. Copies of said
publication are on file with the City Clerk. (Ord. 4483, 12-27-1979)
ARTICLE C. LUMBERYARDS
SECTION:
4-8C-1: Regulatory Certificate Required
4-8C-2: Inspections
4-8C-1: REGULATORY CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of keeping or maintaining a lumberyard
or other place of business where lumber is stacked in a yard or lumbershed,
without first having obtained a Class D regulatory certificate as defined in
Chapter 1 of this Title. (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
4-8C-2: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to make regular
monthly inspections of each and every lumberyard within the City for the
purpose of ascertaining that said lumberyards are not conducted in such a way
as to constitute a fire hazard. If, at any time, the Chief of the Fire
Department shall be of the opinion that any lumberyard, by reason of the manner
in which said lumber is arranged or laid out, or by reason of the manner in
which it is being conducted, constitutes a fire hazard, he shall report such
fact to the Mayor, and if, upon investigation, it is found that any such
lumberyard does constitute a fire hazard, at the place where it is being
operated, the regulatory certificate of such lumberyard shall be revoked by the
Mayor but only after the owners of same are given an opportunity to be heard in
opposition to such revocation 1 . (Ord. 4364, 10-25-1978, eff. 1-1-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  4-1-12 of this Title for due process procedures.
ARTICLE D. GOING OUT OF BUSINESS AND BANKRUPTCY SALES
SECTION:
4-8D-1: License Required
4-8D-2: Application For License, Term, Fee
4-8D-3: Supplemental License
4-8D-4: Records
4-8D-5: License Valid; One Event
4-8D-6: Additional Stock
4-8D-7: Sale Of Listed Goods Only
4-8D-8: Compliance Required
4-8D-9: Exception
4-8D-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall hereafter, within the city, advertise, represent or hold out
that any sale of goods, wares and merchandise is an insurance, bankruptcy,
mortgage, insolvent, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's,
trustee's, removal or closing out sale, or a sale of goods, wares and
merchandise damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, unless the person so
desiring to conduct such sale shall have first obtained a license to conduct
such sale from the city clerk as hereinafter set forth and provided. (Ord.
1765, 2-24-1932)
4-8D-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, TERM, FEE:
The applicant for such a license shall make to such city clerk an application
therefor in writing and under oath, upon a form to be supplied by such city
clerk for that purpose.
No such sale shall exceed three (3) months in duration, and a fee in the amount
applicable to a class A business regulation certificate as set forth in chapter
1 of this title as established from time to time shall be paid prior to the
issuance of said license. (Ord. 7158, 10-28-2009)
4-8D-3: SUPPLEMENTAL LICENSE:
If it shall be made to appear upon sworn application to the city clerk, at any
time during said period of three (3) months, that all of the goods, wares and
merchandise described and inventoried in the original application for such
license have not been sold, accompanied by a statement or inventory of what
remains unsold thereof, a license supplemental to the one hereinabove provided
for, shall be issued by the city clerk upon the same terms and conditions as
said original license, granting authority to continue such sale for a period of
three (3) months. In such case the city clerk, upon the payment of an
additional fee in the amount applicable to a class A business regulation
certificate as set forth in chapter 1 of this title as established from time to
time and in the manner provided in section
4-8D-2 of this article, shall endorse upon the original application, in a blank
to be provided, consent for such supplemental license, and issue a license
therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. 7158, 10-28-
2009)
4-8D-4: RECORDS:
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to endorse upon the application made for
such license, the date of its filing, and the city clerk shall preserve the
same as a record of his office, and shall make an abstract of the facts set
forth in such application in a book kept for that purpose, properly indexed,
containing the name of the person asking such license, the nature of the
proposed sale, the place where such sale is to be conducted, its duration, the
inventory value of the goods, wares and merchandise to be sold, and a general
statement as to where the same came from, and shall make in said book a
notation as to the issuance or refusal of the license applied for, together
with the date of the same. Said city clerk shall endorse on said application
the date the license therein applied for is granted or refused. (Ord. 1765, 2-
24-1932)
4-8D-5: LICENSE VALID; ONE EVENT:
The license as provided for in this article shall be valid only for a sale of
the goods, wares and merchandise inventoried and described in the application
for such license, in the manner and at the time and place mentioned and set
forth in such application, and any renewal of such goods, wares and
merchandise, so inventoried and described in such application, from the place
of sale mentioned in such application, shall cause such goods, wares and
merchandise to lose their identity as an insurance, bankruptcy, mortgaged,
insolvent's, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's or trustee's
stock of goods, wares and merchandise, or a stock of goods, wares and
merchandise damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, and no license shall
thereafter be issued for the conducting of a sale of any of such goods, wares
or merchandise, so removed from the place set forth and described in such
application, under the provisions of this article, at any other place or
places. (Ord. 1765, 2-24-1932)
4-8D-6: ADDITIONAL STOCK:
No person in contemplation of conducting a sale of goods, wares or merchandise
as described in this Article, under a license as provided for in this Article,
shall order any goods, wares or merchandise for the purpose of selling and
disposing of the same at such sale, and any unusual purchase and additions to
the stock of such goods, wares and merchandise within sixty (60) days prior to
the filing of the application for license to conduct such sale mentioned in
this Article, shall be presumptive evidence that such purchases and additions
to stock were made in contemplation of such sale, and for the purpose of
selling the same at such sale. (Ord. 1765, 2-24-1932)
4-8D-7: SALE OF LISTED GOODS ONLY:
No person carrying on or conducting a sale of goods, wares or merchandise as
described in this Article, under a license as provided herein shall, during the
continuance of such sale, add any goods, wares or merchandise to the stock of
goods, wares or merchandise described and inventoried in his original
application for such license; and no goods, wares or merchandise shall be sold
at or during such sale, excepting the goods, wares or merchandise described and
inventoried in such original application; and each and every addition of goods,
wares or merchandise to such stock of goods, wares or merchandise described and
inventoried in said application; and each sale of such goods, wares or
merchandise as were not inventoried and described in such application, shall
constitute a separate violation of the terms of this Article. (Ord. 1765, 2-24-
1932)
4-8D-8: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
Any person who shall advertise, represent or hold out a sale of goods, wares or
merchandise to be a sale of goods as described in this Article without having
first complied with the provisions of this Article shall be deemed guilty of a
violation thereof, and upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine as in this
Code provided 1 . (Ord. 1765, 2-24-1932)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  1-4-1 of this Code.
4-8D-9: EXCEPTION:
The provisions of this Article shall not apply to sheriffs, constables or other
public or court officers, trustees, executors, administrators, guardians or any
other person or persons acting under the license, direction or authority of any
court, State or Federal, selling goods, wares or merchandise in the course of
their official duties, and none of the provisions of this Article shall apply
to so-called "rummage sales" that may be held by any church or charitable
institution for the purpose of financially aiding such institutions. (Ord.
1765, 2-24-1932)
ARTICLE E. GOLD AND SILVER PURCHASES
SECTION:
4-8E-1: Identity Of Seller Required
4-8E-2: Purchaser To Maintain Records
4-8E-3: Exclusion
4-8E-1: IDENTITY OF SELLER REQUIRED:
Any person who purchases gold or silver in the City must require the seller of
said gold or silver to produce not less than two (2) forms or proof as to the
true identity of the seller and further, that the buyer shall be required to
maintain a list of those persons from whom he purchased gold or silver within
the City, the dates of each respective purchase and a general description of
the gold or silver items purchased in connection with each transaction. (Ord.
4604, 4-22-1981)
4-8E-2: PURCHASER TO MAINTAIN RECORDS:
The information required in Section
4-8E-1 of this Article shall be maintained by any person purchasing gold or
silver within the City for a period of not less than two (2) years from the
date of the respective purchases and said information shall be made available
to the Police Department of the City upon request at any time. (Ord. 4604, 4-
22-1981)
4-8E-3: EXCLUSION:
The aforesaid information shall not be required with regard to the purchase of
gold or silver minted and issued by the United States of America, when said
coins are purchased at their face value. (Ord. 4604, 4-22-1981)
CHAPTER 9
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definitions
4-9-2: Solicitors And Peddlers
4-9-3: Itinerant Vendors And Transient Merchants
4-9-4: Revocation Of Certificate
4-9-5: Trespassing
4-9-6: Failure To Leave After Notice
4-9-7: Penalty
4-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section:
ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person who transports tangible personal property for
retail sale within the City who does not maintain in this City an established
office, distribution house, sales house, warehouse, service center or residence
from which such business is conducted; provided, however, this term shall not
include any person who delivers tangible personal property within the City who
is fulfilling an order for such property which was solicited or placed by mail
or other means.
PEDDLING: Selling or offering for sale, barter or exchange at retail any goods,
wares, merchandise or services of any kind whatsoever by traveling from place
to place along the streets of the City or from residence to residence therein,
but shall not include solicitation or canvassing for orders for future
delivery. "Peddling" may, in some instances, include the activities of an
"itinerant vendor" or "transient merchant" as defined herein. If a peddler is
also an itinerant vendor or transient merchant as defined herein, then those
provisions shall also be applicable. To the extent that the provisions of this
Chapter relative to peddling are inconsistent with those relating to itinerant
vendors and/or transient merchants, the more restrictive provisions shall
apply.
REGISTERED SOLICITOR AND REGISTERED PEDDLER: Any person who has obtained a
valid certificate of registration as hereinafter provided together with a valid
photo ID as issued by the City Treasurer, where such certificate is in the
possession of, and on the person of, the one soliciting or peddling during all
soliciting or peddling.
REGISTERED TRANSIENT MERCHANT AND REGISTERED ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person who
is a transient merchant or itinerant vendor as defined in this Section and who
has obtained and has in his possession a valid certificate of registration, and
valid photo ID as issued by the City Treasurer.
RESIDENCE: Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one
or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure.
SOLICITING: Any one or more of the following activities:
   A.   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise,
foodstuffs, insurance, services of any kind, character or description whatever,
for any kind of consideration whatever, all for future delivery; or
   B.   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any
other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit
association, organization, corporation or project.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Any person who is engaged temporarily in the retail sale of
goods, wares or merchandise in this city and who, for the purpose of conducting
such business, occupies any building, room, vehicle, structure of any kind or
vacant lot; provided, however, this term does not include any person selling
goods, wares or merchandise which are raised, produced or manufactured by such
person, to any person selling vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products at
an established city market, to any person operating a store or refreshment
stand at a resort, or to any person operating a stand or booth on or adjacent
to property owned by such person or upon which such person resides. (1999 Code;
amd. Ord. 7022, 9-26-2007)
4-9-2: SOLICITORS AND PEDDLERS:
   A.   Certificate Of Registration Required; Restriction:
      1.   Solicitation: A certificate of registration as hereinafter provided
shall be secured by every person desiring to engage in "soliciting" or
"peddling", as defined herein, from persons in residences within this city,
and, in addition, by every person desiring to engage in soliciting from any
business, office or manufacturing facility within this city, for gifts or
contributions of money, clothing or other valuable thing for the support or
benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation
or project.
      2.   Retail Sales: A certificate of registration as hereinafter provided
shall be secured by every person desiring to engage in retail sales within this
city as a "transient merchant" or "itinerant vendor", as defined herein. (1999
Code)
      3.   Hours Restricted: Soliciting, peddling or selling by a registered
transient merchant or itinerant vendor is prohibited before nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. every day and after seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. or sundown, whichever shall
first occur, every day. (Ord. 7183, 3-10-2010)
   B.   Application For Certificate:
      1.   Information Requested: Application for a certificate of registration
shall be made upon a form provided by the city clerk and filed with the city
treasurer. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the following
information requested on the application:
         a.   Name and present residence address and length of residence at
such address, applicable business address if other than residence address which
must include street address, social security number, driver's license number,
if any;
         b.   Residence addresses, if any, during the past three (3) years if
other than present address;
         c.   Age of applicant and marital status and, if married, the name of
spouse;
         d.   Physical description of the applicant, including height, weight,
color of hair and color of eyes;
         e.   Name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed
or represents and the length of time of such employment or representation,
residence address of corporate officers and principal;
         f.   Location at which applicant intends to do business, nature of the
business, whether a certificate of registration under the retailers' occupation
tax act has been issued, a list of inventory the applicant intends to offer for
sale;
         g.   Name and address of all employers during the past three (3) years
if other than the present employer;
         h.   Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter
of the soliciting which the applicant will engage in;
         i.   Period of time for which the certificate is applied for;
         j.   A list of all certificates of registration to conduct business as
transient merchant or itinerant vendor received or applied for within this
state for preceding twelve (12) months;
         k.   The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application
for certificate in this city, if any;
         l.   Whether or not a certificate of registration issued to the
applicant under this chapter has ever been revoked;
         m.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter or the ordinances of any other Illinois
municipality regulating soliciting or peddling; and
         n.   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission
of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state or
federal law of the United States.
      2.   Oath: All statements made by the applicant upon the application or
in connection therewith shall be under oath.
      3.   Photographic Identification: In connection with the application for
a certificate, the applicant shall submit to identification photographing.
      4.   City Treasurer's Record: The city treasurer shall cause to be kept
in his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon
by the mayor together with all other information and data pertaining thereto
and all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this
chapter and of the denial of applications. (1999 Code)
      5.   Registration Fee: The applicant for a peddler's or solicitor's
certificate shall pay a fee upon application for a certificate of registration
in the amount applicable to a class B business regulation certificate as set
forth in chapter 1 of this title from time to time. (Ord. 7158, 10-28-2009)
      6.   Felony Or Ordinance Violation: Upon the filing of a complete and
accurate application, as provided herein, a certificate of registration shall
be issued by the mayor or the mayor's other designee within thirty (30) days of
application, except that no certificate shall be issued to any person who has
been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of
Illinois or any other state or federal law of the United States, within five
(5) years of the date of the application; nor to any ordinance of this city nor
to any person whose certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously
been revoked as herein provided.
      7.   Constitutional Rights: Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted
or enforced to deprive any person of any rights guaranteed under the
constitutions of the state of Illinois or the United States. (1999 Code)
4-9-3: ITINERANT VENDORS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS:
The applicant for an itinerant vendor's or transient merchant's certificate of
registration shall pay a fee upon application for a certificate of registration
in the amount applicable to a class E business regulation certificate as set
forth in chapter 1 of this title from time to time. The city treasurer or his
designee shall determine, based upon the application submitted, whether the
applicant under this chapter is a transient merchant or itinerant vendor. It
shall be prima facie evidence that a person is a transient merchant or
itinerant vendor if the person does not transact business from a fixed location
or if the person does not own or lease for a term of at least six (6) months
the property from which business is conducted. A certificate of registration
shall issue to any qualified applicant upon the posting of the appropriate bond
or cash deposit as follows: (1999 Code; amd. Ord. 7158, 10-28-2009)
   A.   Surety Bond: The applicant for a transient merchant's or itinerant
vendor's certificate shall file with the city treasurer's office a surety bond
or shall make a cash deposit. The amount of the bond or deposit shall be equal
to fifty percent (50%) of the wholesale value of the merchandise that the
applicant intends to offer for sale; however, the amount of the bond or deposit
shall not be less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   B.   Bond Transferred To Attorney General: The city treasurer's office shall
transfer said deposit or bond to the attorney general of this state within
fourteen (14) days after the applicant ceases to do business in its
