be suspended or revoked until such time as the State of Illinois or Madison
County Health Department reinstates said permit(s) and/or license(s). (Ord.
7830, 3-23-2022)
4-23-7: FOOD TRUCK PARK:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to operate a food truck park in the City of Alton
without having first obtained a class C regulatory certificate as defined in
chapter 4-1 of this title, and without full compliance with the provisions of
this code. Each food truck park shall comply with all city, county, and state
codes and regulations regarding health and safety.
   B.   A food truck park is required to be on a parcel of at least four
thousand (4,000) square feet in size.
   C.   No participating food truck shall operate within a food truck park
without having first obtained a license as set forth in this chapter.
   D.   A food truck park shall be able to accommodate no less than two (2) and
no more than ten (10) individual food trucks within the food truck park.
   E.   Operating hours for any food truck park possessing a liquor license
pursuant to this code shall be governed by section
4-4-10 of this code. Operating hours for any food truck park not possessing a
liquor license pursuant to this code shall be in accordance with the hours set
forth in this chapter. Operating hours for food trucks operating within the
boundaries of a food truck park shall be in accord with the operating hours of
the food truck park.
   F.   There must be a designated manager of the site that is responsible for
the orderly organization of the food truck park, the cleanliness of the site
and the site's compliance with all rules and regulations during working hours.
   G.   Permanent restrooms must be provided within the boundaries of the food
truck park. The number of restrooms required shall be based on the occupant
load for fixed seating of the food truck park and in compliance with this code.
At a minimum two (2) restrooms shall be available for use.
   H.   Each food truck park is required to provide water and electricity
access for each individual food truck that operates at the site. Each food
truck is not allowed to operate a generator at the food truck park unless
emergency circumstances necessitate the need for use of a generator.
   I.   The owner or operator of any food truck park within the City of Alton
shall cause to be kept a record relating to the dates of operation for all food
trucks that operate within the food truck park. Such record shall be kept on an
annual basis and a copy of the same shall be remitted to the City of Alton
Treasurer's office by December 31 of the year in which such record was kept.
   J.   No food truck operating within a food truck park shall be allowed to
operate within the food truck park while in violation of any other provision of
this chapter.
   K.   A site plan shall be provided for review showing:
      1.   The land area included within the site, the zoning classification of
adjacent sites, and all public and private rights-of-way and easements bounding
and intersecting the site;
      2.   A legal description of the platted lot of the proposed site and the
boundaries thereof;
      3.   The location of each proposed permanent structure on the site and
proposed locations of food trucks, and identification of any proposed outdoor
entertainment locations;
      4.   The location of fire hydrants;
      5.   The dimensions and capacities of parking areas and loading areas;
      6.   Landscaping of all street frontages;
      7.   All pedestrian walks, patios and open areas for use by tenants or
the public;
      8.   The location and height of all walls, fences and screen planting and
landscaping;
      9.   The location, size, height, foot candle level and orientation of all
lighting and signs;
      10.   Location and screening of refuse containers, air conditioners and
outside storage or display;
      11.   Location and number of provided seating and eating areas, including
number of fixed seats and tables;
      12.   A schedule of the phasing of all improvements shown in the plan;
      13.   Location, height, separation of buildings, including location of
restrooms, and open space; and
   L.   Food trucks shall be parked on gravel, compacted gravel, concrete or
other improved surface within a food truck park. Food trucks shall not be
parked on unimproved surfaces.
   M.   One on-premises sign is permitted at the entrance identifying the food
truck park. Each food truck may have attached signage. One portable sign in
accordance with the chapter may be used by each food truck.
   N.   The food truck park must be located at least five hundred feet (500')
from any "R" zoning district. Food truck parks within five hundred feet (500')
from any "R" zoning district, as measured at the property line of the food
truck park boundary, are permitted only by special use permit, with such
application made in accordance with this code.
   O.   Food truck parks that have obtained the required Class C regulatory
certificate are not subject to proximity restrictions relating to restaurants.
All food trucks operating within the boundaries of an authorized food truck
park shall be exempt from the prohibition from operating within five hundred
feet (500') of a restaurant. (Ord. 7830, 3-23-2022)
4-23-8: PENALTIES AND REVOCATION:
   A.   Any food truck or food truck vendor who violates any provision of this
chapter shall subject them to a civil infraction, punishable by a fine as set
forth in this code.
   B.   The license for any food truck or food truck vendor who fails to meet
any requirement of this chapter, violates the provisions of this chapter, or
any other federal, state, or local regulation, makes a false statement on their
application, or conducts activity in a manner adverse to the protection of
public health, safety and welfare shall be subject to immediate revocation,
suspension or fine.
   C.   Any food truck or food truck vendor who violates the provisions of this
chapter shall not be eligible for renewal of a license, or of issuance of a
limited use license, or for participation in any special event, until such time
that such violation is remedied. (Ord. 7830, 3-23-2022)
CHAPTER 24
CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
4-24-1: Purpose And Intent
4-24-2: Definitions

4-24-5: Maximum Number Of Adult-Use Cannabis Business Establishments

4-24-10: Adult-Use Cannabis Lounge
4-24-11: Special Requirements For Certain Adult-Use Cannabis Business
Establishments

4-24-13: Operating Requirements
4-24-14: Odor Emissions
4-24-15: Severability
4-24-16: Effective Date
4-24-17: Penalties
4-24-18: Dissolution Of Use And Revocation Of Zoning
4-24-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
   A.   It is the purpose of this chapter to provide regulations regarding the
cultivation, processing and dispensing of adult-use cannabis occurring within
the corporate limits of the City. Such facilities shall comply with all
regulations provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, P.A. 101-0027
(Act), as it may be amended from time to time, and regulations promulgated
thereunder, and the regulations provided below. In the event that the Act is
amended, the more restrictive of the state or local regulations shall apply.
The Department of Planning and Development shall govern the application process
of a cannabis business establishment license.
   B.   It is further the purpose of this chapter is to protect the public
health, safety, and welfare of the residents, businesses, and property in the
City by prescribing the manner in which adult-use cannabis establishments,
including matters in relation to:
      1.   Providing for a means of cultivation, production, and distribution
of cannabis to persons permitted to obtain, possess, and use cannabis for
recreational purposes under the Act.
      2.   Protecting public health and safety through reasonable limitations
on business operations as they relate to noise, air, and water quality, food
safety, neighborhood and public safety, security for the business and its
personnel, and other health and safety concerns.
      3.   Promoting lively street life and high-quality neighborhoods by
limiting the concentration of any one type of adult-use cannabis establishments
in specific areas.
      4.   Creating regulations that address the particular needs of the
residents and businesses of the City and coordinate with laws that may be
enacted by the State of Illinois regarding adult-use cannabis establishments
and recreational cannabis use.
      5.   Facilitating the implementation of the Act without going beyond the
authority granted by it.
      6.   Protecting public safety and residential areas by limiting the areas
of the City where adult-use cannabis establishments may be located.
      7.   Permitting recreational cannabis use, distribution, cultivation, and
production where it will have a minimal impact and potential negative impacts
are minimized, since these can have an impact on health, safety, and community
resources.
      8.   Use, distribution, cultivation, production, possession, and
transportation of cannabis is currently illegal under federal law, and cannabis
remains classified as a ''Level 1 Controlled Substance" by federal law.
      9.   The General Assembly has adopted enabling legislation that provides
for adult-use cannabis establishments; however, the Act does not completely
address the local impacts of adult-use cannabis establishments on
municipalities, making it appropriate for local regulation of adult-use
cannabis establishments.
      10.   Nothing in this chapter is intended to promote or condone the
production, distribution, or possession of cannabis in violation of any
applicable laws.
      11.   This chapter is to be construed to protect the public over the
interests of adult-use cannabis establishments.
      12.   Adult-use cannabis establishments are a heavily regulated industry
in the State and all licensees are assumed to be fully aware of the law, hence
the City shall not therefore be required to issue warnings before issuing
citations for violations of this chapter.
      13.   This chapter is intended to specify the time, place, and manner
restrictions for operating an adult-use cannabis establishments in the City as
specified under the Act and in this chapter.
      14.   The City Council has determined to allow adult-use cannabis
establishments in the City on the condition that the establishments are
operated in compliance with this chapter rather than banning them in the City
as permitted by the Act. (Ord. 7851, 9-28-2022)
