6-1-6: SIGNS AND CANOPIES OVER PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Indemnification: In consideration of the City permitting the
maintenance of any sign, signboard or rigid canopy over any street, sidewalk,
alley or other public way in the City, each person maintaining each overhanging
sign, signboard or canopy shall indemnify the City for any loss or damage or
liability that may result from the construction or maintenance of such sign,
signboard or canopy. (Ord. 7158, 10-28-2009; amd. Ord. 7327, 10-24-2012, eff.
1-1-2013)
   B.   Construction Standards: All signs and canopies extending over any
street, sidewalk, alley or other public place must be constructed in accordance
with the Building Code and be securely fastened and constructed so that there
will be no danger of the same being dislodged by ordinary winds or falling from
other cause. (1961 Code § 3-29; amd. Ord. 7327, 10-24-2012, eff. 1-1-2013)
   C.   Height Above Walks: The lowest part of any sign, canopy or nonrigid
awning, or any support thereof which extends over any public way shall be at
least eight feet (8') above the level of the walk or public way over which it
extends; but no such sign shall be maintained over any public way used by
vehicles if any part of its support or of the sign is less than fifteen feet
(15') above the level of such public way. (1961 Code § 3-30; amd. Ord. 7327,
10-24-2012, eff. 1-1-2013)
   D.   Inspection: It shall be the duty of the Director of Code Enforcement to
inspect or cause to be inspected, every sign, canopy or awning which extends
over any sidewalk, street, alley or other public way. If any such sign, canopy
or awning is found to be insecurely fastened, or if such sign, canopy or awning
is found to obstruct the view of any motorists or pedestrians of any traffic
sign or signal, he shall report this fact to the owner or occupant of the
premises on which it is fastened. If the condition of the sign is not corrected
to comply with the provisions of this section within ten (10) days after such
notice, it may be removed or torn down by the City on order of the City
Council. (1961 Code § 3-31; amd. Ord. 4089, 4-14-1976; Ord. 7158, 10-28-2009;
Ord. 7327, 10-24-2012, eff. 1-1-2013; Ord. 7664, 8-22-2018)
6-1-7: NAMING OF STREETS, PARKS AND PUBLIC PROPERTIES:
After any street, park or other City owned property is initially named by
appropriate actions of the Corporate Authorities of the City, any subsequent
change of the name of any street, park or other City owned properties shall not
be considered by the Corporate Authorities until and unless a public hearing is
held before the Corporate Authorities of the City at which all interested
persons shall be granted reasonable opportunity to present their views to the
Corporate Authorities of the City. Notice of such a public hearing shall be
provided to the general public in compliance with procedures utilized from time
to time to give notice of a public meeting of the City Council. In addition,
notice of such a public hearing on the question of the change of the name of a
street, park or other City owned properties shall be given to the owners of
record or all real estate which adjoins the street, park or other City owned
property the name of which is proposed to be changed, or is within two hundred
fifty feet (250') of said property. Said notice shall, at a minimum, give the
date, time and place of the public hearing to be held before the Corporate
Authorities, the subject matter of the question to be considered at said public
hearing and the current name of the property affected and the proposals, if
any, for a new name of said property. (Ord. 5358, 7-12-1989; amd. 1999 Code)
6-1-8: STREET AND ALLEY VACATION FEES:
Whenever the city council, pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-91-1,
vacates a street or alley, the final passage of the ordinance shall not be
effective until there is paid to the city an amount equal to the following:
   A.   The fair market value of the property to be vacated; or
   B.   The benefits which will accrue to the property owners to which the
vacated properties will pass; or
   C.   The actual cost incurred by the city in processing the vacation
including, but not limited to, engineering fees, survey fees, cost of producing
the required plat and recording fees.
The city council, in its resolution approving the vacation of a street or
alley, shall determine the costs which are to be paid to the city in each
particular instance. (Ord. 6254, 3-25-1998)
6-1-9: STREET, ALLEY AND SIDEWALK OBSTRUCTIONS:
No contractor, builder or other person shall encumber or obstruct any street,
alley or sidewalk in the city with building or other like materials, including,
but not limited to, dumpsters, without a written permit from the public works
director therefor; nor shall any contractor, builder or other person, except in
cases of necessity, and for a short time only, encumber or obstruct more than
one-third (1/3) of any street or alley, or one-half (1/2) of any sidewalk at
any time; nor shall any such obstruction in any case continue longer than may
be necessary in the diligent erection of such building, or the prompt execution
of the work. The aforementioned written permit shall be issued by the public
works director at his discretion as it is the intent of the city council that
no permits shall be issued under this section if the placing of any obstruction
as mentioned above may cause damage to any public street, alley and/or sidewalk
or if an unreasonable obstruction of same will be created.
The fee for the aforementioned permit shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) and
shall be good for a period of thirty (30) days from the date of its issue. Said
permit may be renewed for good cause shown by the party holding said permit one
time for an additional thirty (30) day period after the original thirty (30)
day period has expired. Should additional time beyond the permit period and
renewal period be needed, a contractor, builder or other person must seek a new
permit and pay the permit fee.
Any obstruction of a street, alley or sidewalk existing without permit may be
removed by the city upon twenty four (24) hours' posted notice. Any contractor,
builder, or other person who creates an obstruction of a street, alley and/or
sidewalk without a permit, with said obstruction having been removed by the
city, shall not be entitled to possession of the property removed by the city
without first having paid to the city all fees for removal and storage of said
property. Anyone who violates any provision of this section shall be subject to
the general penalty found in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 6474, 4-26-2000)
6-1-10: PARKING OF TRAILERS PROHIBITED:
Parking of a trailer of any kind on any city street or public way for a period
in excess of forty eight (48) hours is prohibited. The owner of any trailer in
violation of this section shall be subject to the general penalty as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 6497, 6-28-2000)
6-1-11: SPEED BUMPS PROHIBITED:
It is the policy of the city of Alton that the public streets and alleys of the
city of Alton shall not be intentionally encumbered by the public works
department or any other person or entity with speed bumps, speed humps or any
other similar obstacle intended to impede the normal flow of traffic upon the
streets and alleys of the city of Alton as a means to reduce excessive speed of
vehicles. (Ord. 7286, 10-26-2011)
CHAPTER 2
SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
6-2-1: Construction Standards
6-2-2: Sidewalks Program
6-2-3: Sidewalk Permits
6-2-4: Handicap Accessibility Ramps
6-2-5: Use Of Sidewalks
6-2-6: Prohibited Conditions
6-2-7: Enforcement
6-2-1: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
Sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with details and specifications as
established in the most current edition of "Standard Specifications for Road
and Bridge Construction" adopted by the Illinois Department of Transportation.
(Ord. 6172, 7-9-1997)
6-2-2: SIDEWALKS PROGRAM:
   A.   Program Established: A sidewalks program is hereby established. The
cost of constructing the sidewalk shall be shared equally, twenty five/seventy
five (25/75) up to three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per sidewalk ($750.00
applicant's share/$2,250.00 City's share) between the City and the adjoining
property owner. (Ord. 6172, 7-9-1997)
   B.   Application Process: Notice of the sidewalks program shall be released
to the media. Funds from the gaming account will be utilized to pay for three
(3) (3 column by 5 inch) ads in the Telegraph, plus an ad package to be
arranged with WBGZ Radio Station. Persons who wish to sign up for the sidewalks
program shall apply by postcard within thirty (30) days of the media release.
On the postcard the applicant shall state his or her name, address and phone
number. The applicant shall indicate on the card whether they are requesting a
new or replacement sidewalk and the approximate length of the sidewalk.
Postcards shall be sent to the Department of Public Works and shall be date and
time stamped upon receipt. Applications shall be limited to one per person or
business. The Department of Public Works shall get details from each applicant,
and carefully advise each applicant that one-quarter (1/4) of the total cost of
the sidewalk will be due and payable when final specifications are drawn and
the best bid award has been made. The City's total share of the 2000-2001
sidewalks program shall not exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00).
In the event that applications exceed the funds available, sidewalk
construction shall be funded on a first-come, first-served basis. (Ord. 6463,
3-8-2000)
   C.   Guidelines: The sidewalks program shall be implemented in accordance
with the "Guidelines for Implementation" attached to Ordinance 6005 on file in
the office of the City Clerk and incorporated herein by reference. (Ord. 6172,
7-9-1997)
   D.   Repealer: The Sidewalks Program Ordinance is repealed on March 31,
2001, unless prior to that date the City Council enacts legislation providing
for the continuation of the sidewalks program. (Ord. 6463, 3-8-2000)
6-2-3: SIDEWALK PERMITS:
   A.   Permit To Repair: No person shall remove, repair or in any manner
disturb any sidewalk without first having obtained a permit form the Department
of Public Works specifying the work to be done (and any violation of the terms
of such permit shall render same null and void). (1917 Code, § 1238)
   B.   No Repair Without Permit: It shall also be the duty of the police
officers to see to it that no person shall remove, repair or in any manner
disturb any sidewalk without first having obtained a proper permit from the
Department of Public Works. (1917 Code, § 1241)
6-2-4: HANDICAP ACCESSIBILITY RAMPS:
   A.   Handicap ramps shall only be constructed upon public rights of way in
cases where the structure is preexisting and there is an insufficient setback
to construct the ramp upon private property. New construction or major
rehabilitations shall not be allowed to use public right of way for ramp
construction.
   B.   Handicap ramps and all appurtenances shall be designed and constructed
in accordance with the specifications outlined in the Illinois Environmental
Barriers Act and the Americans With Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines.
   C.   All applicants must show that alteration of the structure for handicap
accessibility would be cost prohibitive and there are no economically viable
alternatives.
   D.   The handicap ramp must leave adequate room for pedestrian movement.
   E.   A to-scale site plan and drawing of the ramp must be submitted to
Building and Housing for review. Furthermore, Building and Housing may request
additional information, as it deems necessary, to properly review the
application. In addition, the applicant shall be subject to all necessary
permits and fees required by Public Works. The applicant shall bear the cost of
all associated expenses for the design and construction of the ramp.
   F.   The City shall retain the right to remove a ramp in the event that the
City requires the use of the public right-of- way for another public purpose.
(Ord. 5700, 9-23-1992)
6-2-5: USE OF SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Private Use: No part of any sidewalk shall be taken for private use by
lowering or cutting down the same next to the building fronting thereon; or by
railing off the same by any iron or other railing, or otherwise shutting off
the public from using the same; but said sidewalk shall be built clear up to
the building on a uniform grade, as hereinbefore provided, unless the City
Council shall otherwise direct. Entrance to cellars and basements, and flights
of stairs or steps may be made, which shall not extend into or on the sidewalks
more than four feet (4') next to the building, and the width of the steps,
stairs or entrances in sidewalks to cellars or basements shall not be more than
five feet (5'); and the same shall be at all times securely protected by the
owner or occupant of the building. Notwithstanding the foregoing, issuance of a
lease for a sidewalk cafe as permitted by title 4, chapter 7, article B of this
Code, which includes any such sidewalk cafe upon a public sidewalk shall be
deemed to be specific authority of the City Council for such operation, within
the meaning of this section. (Ord. 7601, 11-21-2017)
   B.   Goods Displayed On Walk: It shall be unlawful for any person in the
City to place, set or hang out, over or upon any sidewalk, any goods, wares or
merchandise, except within three feet (3') of the building or premises owned or
occupied by him; or to place, erect or suspend any sign, flag, banner, show
case or other fixture projecting into or hanging over any sidewalk exceeding
three feet (3') from the building or premises owned or occupied by him; or to
cause or knowingly permit the same to be done in front of or adjoining any
house or premises owned or occupied by him, under his control. (1917 Code §
1231)
   C.   Draining Water On Walks: It shall be unlawful for any person to suffer
or permit the water falling or draining from the roof of any building owned,
occupied or controlled by him, to spread over the sidewalk in front of the
same. (1917 Code § 1234)
   D.   Crowds Obstructing Walks: When two (2) or more persons shall stand or
crowd together so as to obstruct any sidewalk or thereby prevent the free and
unobstructed passage of other persons over such sidewalk, such persons so
obstructing such walk shall be subject to a penalty as in this Code provided.
(1917 Code § 1236)
6-2-6: PROHIBITED CONDITIONS:
   A.   Nuisance Conditions: Every sidewalk in the City which is so much worn
or out of repair as to endanger the safety of persons passing over the same, is
hereby declared to be a nuisance; and any person who shall hereafter suffer or
permit such nuisance to exist in front of or adjoining premises owned or
occupied by such person shall be subject to a penalty as in this Code provided.
(1917 Code § 1228)
   B.   Injury To Sidewalk: If any person shall break or otherwise injure any
sidewalk, he shall be fined as in this Code provided. (1917 Code § 1239)
   C.   Horse Or Wagon On Walk: No person shall ride, drive, push or draw any
horse, mule, hog, cow or other like animal or any wagon, sled or sleigh on any
sidewalk within the City, unless it be in crossing the same to go into a yard
or lot where no other suitable crossing or means of access is provided. (1917
Code § 1233)
6-2-7: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Duty To Enforce: It shall be the duty of the Department of Public
Works, the Police Department and of any City officers and employees having
police power to enforce the provisions of this Chapter by stopping any work
being done in violation of the terms of this Chapter. (1917 Code, § 1219)
   B.   Report Defects: It shall be the duty of all police officers to report
to the Department of Public Works all defects in sidewalks, and in case of
accident, they shall report the same to the Law Department, together with the
names of any witnesses to such accident, if known to them. (1917 Code, § 1240)
CHAPTER 3
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
6-3-1: Permit Required
6-3-2: Application For Permit
6-3-3: Permit Fee
6-3-4: Bond
6-3-5: Insurance
6-3-6: Time Limit
6-3-7: Cutting Pavement And Excavating
6-3-8: Refilling Of Excavations
6-3-9: Paving, Resurfacing And Restoration
6-3-10: Protective Measures
6-3-11: Sidewalk Excavations By Property Owners
6-3-12: Rules And Regulations
6-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall make or cause to be made any cuts or excavations in, through,
or under any street, sidewalk, alley or public place in the City for any
purpose whatsoever without a permit therefor being obtained from the Director
of Public Works, which permit shall not be issued until the applicant has
complied with the provisions of this Chapter including those provisions
requiring bond and deposit. A separate permit shall be required for each cut or
excavation. This Section shall not be construed to prohibit bona fide emergency
cuts or excavations when essential to the preservation of public health,
safety, or welfare. In such cases, application for permit to cover emergency
cuts or excavations shall be made the first regular work day following the
making of the cut or excavation.
   A.   Required Marking For Cuts Or Excavations By Utility Companies: Utility
companies making cuts or excavations in City streets shall first mark such cut
or excavation at the adjacent curb line with the color code hereinafter set
forth, provided that if the cut or excavation is made on an unimproved street,
then the marking shall be on the extreme edge of the street. The mark shall be
made with a colored paint of such a quality and shall be applied in sufficient
quantity to be visible for a period of at least one year. The following code
colors are hereby designated:
 
Utility Service                    Color
Gas, oil, petroleum                High visibility safety - yellow
Electric                           Safety - red
Communication, telephone telegraph Safety alert - orange
Potable water                      Safety precaution - blue
Sewer                              Safety - green
   B.   Manner Of Marking: Utility companies making cuts or excavations in City
streets during winter months when ice or snow may cover the adjacent curb line,
shall drive a stake, marked with the appropriate colored paint, into the dirt
area behind the adjacent curb line, far enough down as to prevent vandalism,
and avoid accidental injuries. In areas where neither method of marking
provided in
6-3-1A of this Section is available, the utility shall notify the office of
Public Works.
   C.   Penalty: Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this Section
shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($ 1,000.00)
per excavation. (Ord. 5941, 12-21-1994)
6-3-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
All applications for permit under the provisions of this Chapter shall be
signed by the person who or duly authorized agent of an entity which desires to
do the work designated in the application. Such application shall not be
assignable and no person or entity shall allow his or its name to be used to
obtain a permit for any other person or entity. Applications for this purpose
shall be made on forms approved by the Director of Public Works. (Ord. 5941,
12-21-1994)
6-3-3: PERMIT FEE:
   A.   Permit Fee Enumerated: Unless otherwise contractually provided for in a
then-valid franchise between the permit applicant and the City, the following
fees shall be charged for permits issued hereunder for excavation openings for
placement or renewal of facilities and said fees shall be paid to the City
Treasurer:
Open cut street, cross traffic                $20.00 per 15 lineal feet
(up to 3 feet width)
Open cut street, cross traffic                $40.00 per 15 lineal feet
(3 feet to 6 feet width)
Open cut street with traffic                  $20.00 per 20 lineal feet
(up to 3 feet width)
Open cut street with traffic                  $40.00 per 20 lineal feet
(3 feet to 6 feet width)
Open cut alley, cross traffic                 $20.00 per 15 lineal feet
(up to 3 feet width)
Open cut alley, cross traffic                 $40.00 per 15 lineal feet
(3 feet to 6 feet width)
Open cut alley with traffic                   $20.00 per 20 lineal feet
(up to 3 feet width)
Open cut alley with traffic                   $40.00 per 10 lineal feet
(3 feet to 6 feet)
Curb removal                                  $25.00 up to and including
(property line sidewalk)                      70 lineal feet and $0.35 for each
                                              additional lineal foot
Sidewalk excavation                           $25.00 up to and including
(property line sidewalk)                      70 lineal feet and $0.35 for each
                                              additional lineal foot
Removal and replacement of                    $10.00 fee to accompany
sidewalk by property owner                    permit
Open cut in City right of way                 $10.00
(approximately 3 feet by 4 feet)
Directional boring of a utility in the public
right-of-way (said permit fee to include all  $0.75 per foot
boring puts and handholes relating directly
to said directional boring)
 
   B.   Franchise Exceptions: Public utilities having franchises which permit
the deduction from franchise taxes of permit fees and charges shall be issued
permits without charge. Public utilities determined not to have obtained a
permit for excavation in a City street or right of way and paid the required
fee, if any, shall be fined one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per
each unreported excavation. (Ord. 5941, 12-21-1994; amd. Ord. 7759, 6-11-2020)
6-3-4: BOND:
   A.   Unless otherwise contractually provided for in a valid franchise
between the permit applicant and the City, before any permit referred to in
this Chapter shall be issued, the applicant for such permit shall deposit with
the Director of Public Works a performance and maintenance bond, or, in the
alternative, a license and permit bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) which bond shall provide that the permittee shall well and
satisfactorily restore the street opening and guaranteeing said satisfactory
restoration for a period of one year after same is made; provided however, that
any permit issued hereunder exclusively for the installation, improvement, or
replacement of sidewalks shall require the applicant therefor to post the above
described bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in the manner
described above. If such permittee anticipates requesting more than one permit
per year as required by this Section, he may furnish on continuing bond as
aforesaid in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); provided
however, that if the permittee anticipates requesting more than one permit
exclusively for sidewalk work per year as required in this Section, he may
furnish one continuing bond as aforesaid in the penal sum of five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00). If the said ten thousand dollar ($10,000.00) bond is
deemed inadequate by the Director of Public Works, based upon the estimated
cost of restoring the opening or openings, then the Director may require any
reasonable increase in the amount thereof to conform to the said estimated
costs.
   B.   In lieu of the bond required above, an applicant for sidewalk
installation, replacement, or improvements who owns the property on which the
sidewalk is located may deposit the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) with
the City Treasurer as prescribed above, or the bond requirement as outlined in
this Section as amended, subject to the approval of the Director of Public
Works, who will determine the estimated cost of restoration hereunder. The City
may apply such funds so deposited to pay for any costs, fees, or expenses
incurred by the City arising out of the activities of the permittee. One year
after the expiration of any permit for any sidewalk work under this subsection
or if no such work has taken place the permittee under this subsection on
surrender of the permit so issued, the unused portion of such funds deposited
under this subsection shall, on order of the Director of Public Works, be
refunded to the permittee. (Ord. 5941, 12-21-1994)
6-3-5: INSURANCE:
   A.   In addition to the above bond requirement, every permittee shall,
before a permit is issued, furnish the Director of Public Works with a
certificate of insurance showing liability coverage of not less than one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury including one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage. Said certificate of
insurance shall be in substance and form as approved by the Corporation Counsel
and shall indicate that the permittee has contractual liability insurance from
an insurance company satisfactory to the City, naming the City as an additional
insured and indemnifying and holding the City, its agents, employees, and
servants harmless from, on account of, and against all claims, demands, or
suits which may be brought by any person or persons arising out of any acts or
work done pursuant to the award of such permit to the permittee notwithstanding
that said claim, demand, or suit may be the result of negligence of someone
other than the permittee or his subcontractor.
   B.   Lawfully self-insured corporations may deposit a hold harmless
agreement and corporate undertaking in a form approved by the Corporation
Counsel. (Ord. 5941, 12-21-1994)
6-3-6: TIME LIMIT:
Each cut or excavation for which a permit is granted under this Chapter shall
be completed within fourteen (14) days from the date of issuance of the permit.
An extension of time may be granted by the Director of Public Works in
situations where the delay is attributable to causes beyond the control of the
permittee. In the event of lapse of such time limits, a new permit shall be
required before the cut or excavation is made. (Ord. 6067, 4-24-1996)
6-3-7: CUTTING PAVEMENT AND EXCAVATING:
The person making a cut or excavation shall cause the same to be done with the
least possible injury to the street, sidewalk, alley, or public place and shall
place the removed paving material and excavated earth therefrom in such a
manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the public and to permit
uninterrupted passage of water along the gutters. The width of the cut or
excavation shall be according to drawing 2426-3, or its successors, as printed
by IDOT for Class B patches, a copy of which standard shall be available for
copying at the Department of Public Works. (Ord. 5941, 12-21-1994)
6-3-8: REFILLING OF EXCAVATIONS:
Every person making a cut or excavation in, through, or under any street,
sidewalk, alley, or public place in the City shall notify the Director of
Public Works of his intention to commence the refill of such cut or excavation
at least four (4) hours prior to the actual commencing thereof. Utility
companies shall notify the Director of Public Works of their schedule for
backfilling and roadway repairs. Roadway repairs made without notification
shall require re-excavation and replacement with flowable backfill. Refilling
of all cuts or excavations made in any street, sidewalk, alley, or public place
in the City shall be made by one of the following methods:
   A.   Excavations in streets, alleys, and roadways including oil and chip
surfaces shall be clean saw cut the depth of the existing surface.
   B.   Street and roadway cuts shall be widened a minimum of twelve inches
(12") on each side of the excavation before replacing subbase or surface.
   C.   Refill shall be done with clean, unfrozen Grade 8 aggregate, free of
foreign substances such as wood, weeds, clay balls or lumps of dirt. The Grade
8 aggregate is to be no greater than eight inches (8") when compacted over the
repair.
   D.   Flowable fill shall be used from the eight inches (8") of Grade 8
aggregate to fill to the bottom of the concrete subbase. Where concrete subbase
does not exist, flowable fill shall be used to the base of the existing
surface.
   E.   Alternate fill for major excavations, such as Grade 8 aggregate, will
be at the discretion of the Director of Public Works and shall be replaced with
lifts that will not be greater than eight inches (8") when compacted.
   F.   Concrete subbase is to be replaced with the same thickness as existing
subbase with a mixture of 7 bag concrete and shall be pinned or doweled on
twelve inch (12") centers, a minimum of six inches (6") from top of existing
subbase with one inch by eighteen inch (1" x 18") dowels set at a depth of
eight inches (8") to nine inches (9") in existing subbase.
   G.   Excavations made in oil and chip streets and asphalt streets shall be
repaired with hot mix asphalt. During the period of the year when hot mix
asphalt is not available, cold patch asphalt may be used as a temporary repair
until hot mix asphalt is available. Before hot mix can be put down, a tack coat
must be applied to the vertical sides. Excavations made in concrete streets and
roadways shall be replaced with concrete. Excavations made in brick streets and
roadways shall be made with bricks removed from the excavation.
   H.   The finished surface of excavation repairs made with hot mix asphalt
shall be compacted with a roller.
   I.   Public Works shall be notified one hour before the permanent surface is
to be completed. Public Works shall use a straight edge to ensure that the
permanent surface is flush and compacted to match the existing surface around
the completed excavation. (Ord. 6067, 4-24-1996)
6-3-9: PAVING, RESURFACING AND RESTORATION:
The area affected by cut or excavation of the street surface and subsurface
shall be repaired to the condition equal to or better than the surrounding
street surface by the person or utility company causing said excavation for
perpetuity. The area affected shall be rebuilt or overlaid. If failure occurs
on existing patch and the person or utility company initiates the permit
process, the permit fee shall be waived. To encourage prompt response to street
repair problems, Public Works shall notify persons when they are in a
progressive penalty situation. (Ord. 6067, 4-24-1996)
6-3-10: PROTECTIVE MEASURES:
   A.   Every person who shall for any purpose make or cause to be made any
excavation in, upon, under, or adjoining any street, sidewalk, alley, or other
public place, and shall leave any part or portion thereof open, or shall leave
any part or portion thereof obstructed with rubbish, building, or other
material shall cause the same to be enclosed with good, substantial, and
sufficient barriers not less than three feet (3') high and shall cause one or
more warning lights of a type approved by the Director of Public Works to be
securely and conspicuously posted on or near such excavation, building
material, or other obstruction, provided that if such excavation or obstruction
extends more than ten feet (10') but less than fifty feet (50') in length, two
(2) warning lights shall be used with one placed at each end, and provided
further, that one additional light shall be placed for each additional fifty
feet (50') or part thereof. Such light shall be kept burning from sunset to
sunrise.
   B.   No person shall excavate the full width of any street, alley, sidewalk,
or other public place, except when in the opinion of the Director of Public
Works public convenience and necessity will be better served thereby; in such
cases it shall be the duty of the permittee to maintain a substantial walkway
or driveway across such excavation until it is refilled. (Ord. 5941, 12-21-
1994)
6-3-11: SIDEWALK EXCAVATIONS BY PROPERTY OWNERS:
Whenever any property owner, or any person representing him shall have stated
in his application for a permit to excavate through or under any sidewalk that
he desires to repair such sidewalk himself or by his representative, and that
he will guard such excavation or defective sidewalk until such repairs are
made, by barricades and lights as provided in this Chapter, and that such
sidewalk shall be repaired forty eight (48) hours after the excavation through
or under the sidewalk has been completed, then such property owner or his
representative shall have the right to repair such sidewalk provided such
repair is made in accordance with all applicable requirements of the City.
(Ord. 5941, 12-21-1994)
6-3-12: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Director of Public Works, with the approval of the Mayor and Council, may
prescribe such rules and regulations to be followed and performed by any person
engaged in excavating public streets, sidewalks, alleys, and public places as
may be necessary for the safety and convenience of the public and the proper
handling and dispatch of the work; provided, however, that no rules or
regulations shall be contrary to the provisions of this or any other City Code
provisions. (Ord. 5941, 12-21-1994)
CHAPTER 4
NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS
SECTION:
6-4-1: Numbering Required
6-4-2: Assignment Of Numbers
6-4-3: Manner Of Numbering
6-4-4: Failure To Number
6-4-5: Mistake Or Conflict
6-4-1: NUMBERING REQUIRED:
It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of every
building in the City to number it in the manner hereinafter provided. (1917
Code, § 848)
6-4-2: ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS:
   A.   Authority To Change: The numbers heretofore assigned to lots or houses,
except as hereinafter provided, shall remain the numbers of such lots or
houses, respectively, until otherwise changed by the Council. (1917 Code, §
849)
   B.   Assignment: The Supervisor of Housing and Building Inspectors shall
assign, or cause to be assigned, to each lot or house its proper number, and
shall inform the owner, agent or person in possession of such premises as to
the number thereof at any time upon demand.
In assigning such numbers the Supervisor shall assign a number to each lot or
part of lot fronting on any street, avenue or public place of the City as soon
as may be in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter, and shall allow
one number for each twenty five feet (25') of vacant ground, and the record of
such numbering in the books of the Supervisor shall be evidence of the
respective numbers or designations aforesaid. (1917 Code, § 851; amd. Ord.
4439, 6-27-1979; Ord. 5503, 12-19-1990)
6-4-3: MANNER OF NUMBERING:
   A.   How Numbered: The decimal system of numbering houses and premises is
hereby adopted as the system of numbering housing and premises on the streets
in the City. Market Street shall be the dividing or base line for numbering on
all streets running east and west, and the levee, or Front Street, on all
streets running north, or in a northerly direction. The odd numbers shall apply
to the south sides of the streets, and the even numbers to the north sides of
the streets, on all streets running east and west, and the odd numbers shall
apply to the east sides of the streets and the even numbers shall apply to the
west sides of the streets running north from the levee or Front Street, or in a
northerly direction, and the numbering shall be done in accordance with the
following rules:
      1.   On all streets running north from the levee or Front Street, or in a
northerly direction, the numbering shall commence with number one at the levee
or Front Street, and shall increase north at the rate of one hundred (100) for
each block or square, to the City limits.
      2.   On all streets running east and west from Market Street, the
numbering shall commence with number one and shall increase at the rate of one
hundred (100) for each block or square to the eastern limits of the City.
      3.   On all streets running west from Market Street, the numbering shall
commence with number one and shall increase west at the rate of one hundred
(100) for each block or square to the western limits of the City. (1917 Code, §
850)
   B.   Size Of Numbers: Each of the figures of every such number on any
building shall be not less than three inches (3") in length, being so marked as
to be distinctly and easily read; such numbers shall be placed in a conspicuous
place on the side of or above the front door of the building to which the same
are attached. (1917 Code, § 853)
6-4-4: FAILURE TO NUMBER:
Any person being the owner or occupant of any building now erected in the City
who shall neglect or refuse to number any building owned or occupied by him, in
conformity with the provisions of this Chapter, or who shall number such
building without first having obtained from the Supervisor of Housing and
Building Inspectors a number and certificate designating the proper number of
such building, shall be subject to penalty as in this Code provided.
Any owner or occupant of any building erected in the City who shall for thirty
(30) days after the same shall be erected, neglect or refuse to number said
building according to the provisions of this Chapter, or who shall number said
building without first having obtained from the Supervisor a number and a
certificate designating the proper number shall be subject to penalty as in
this Code provided. (1917 Code, § 854; amd. Ord. 4439, 6-27-1979; Ord. 5503,
12-19-1990)
6-4-5: MISTAKE OR CONFLICT:
In all cases where house numbers have been assigned on any street in pursuance
of this Chapter, it shall be the duty of the Supervisor of Housing and Building
Inspectors thereafter to adjust and reassign such numbers as the same may be
required from time to time, and in all cases where there is a mistake or
conflict in numbers, said Supervisor shall direct and make the proper
adjustment of the same. (1917 Code, § 855; amd. Ord. 4439, 6-27-1979; Ord.
5503, 12-19-1990)
CHAPTER 5
PUBLIC PROPERTY USE; PROFESSIONAL FEES
SECTION:
6-5-1: Findings
6-5-2: Definitions
6-5-3: Use Of Public Property
6-5-4: Fee Reimbursement Agreement
6-5-5: Reports To City Council
6-5-1: FINDINGS:
It is hereby found and declared that the preambles to this Ordinance 5804, on
file in the office of the City Clerk, are true and correct and are incorporated
herein as if fully set forth at this point. (Ord. 5804, 8-11-1993)
6-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the terms set forth in this Section shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
FEES, COSTS AND EXPENSES: Any and all professional fees including fees for
accountants, attorneys, engineers and any practitioner of a professional
discipline customarily employed for the activities contemplated by this
Chapter; any and all costs of publication, duplication, documentary
preparation, postage, express charges, transportation or other out-of-pocket
charge incurred and all salaries of employees, officers and agents for services
provided outside of the ordinary course of employment or holding of office
including, but not limited to, attendance at special meetings of the City
Council.
RIGHTS IN PUBLIC PROPERTY: Any right to enter upon, occupy, place personal
property upon or utilize in any manner other than complete possession any real
property or portion thereof owned by the City.
USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY: The granting of possession of any real or personal
property owned by the City to any nongovernmental entity or for-profit
enterprise when such possession shall exceed a period of six (6) months. (Ord.
5804, 8-11-1993)
6-5-3: USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY:
It is the policy of the City Council of the City that the granting of use of
public property and rights in public property is to be encouraged through a
reasonable procedure for the consideration of proposals for such use and
rights. (Ord. 5804, 8-11-1993)
6-5-4: FEE REIMBURSEMENT AGREEMENT:
In order to encourage prompt consideration by the City Council and to minimize
the fiscal impact on other financial resources of the City, it is the policy of
the City to require reimbursement of expenses, costs and fees in connection
with the consideration of proposals for the use of public property and the
granting of rights in public property. In connection with the implementation of
this policy, there is hereby authorized and approved a fee reimbursement
agreement in substantially the form attached as Exhibit A to Ordinance 5804, on
file in the office of the City Clerk, and in connection therewith, the Mayor
and City Clerk are hereby directed, authorized and empowered to:
   A.   Execute and attest said agreement without further action of the City
Council with any individual, partnership, venture, business, corporation or
other entity that seeks to obtain the use of public property or obtain rights
in public property;
   B.   The Mayor shall enter into such agreement with any party who, in
response to a solicitation of the City for proposals for the use of public
property or the granting of rights in public property or any party who submits
a proposal unsolicited to the City for the granting of rights in public
property or use of public property;
   C.   The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to, in his sole
discretion, waive a deposit of fees as required by said agreement upon a
demonstration by the entity of financial responsibility and upon receipt of
adequate documentation evidencing the financial resources sufficient to pay to
the City such fees, costs and expenses as may be incurred by the City in the
analysis and consideration for any proposal for the use of public property of
granting of rights in public property. (Ord. 5804, 8-11-1993)
6-5-5: REPORTS TO CITY COUNCIL:
Upon the execution of any fee reimbursement agreement by the Mayor, the Mayor
shall promptly report the identity of any party entering into such an agreement
to the City Council. An executed original counterpart of said agreement shall
be placed on file with the City Clerk. (Ord. 5804, 8-11-1993)
CHAPTER 6
TREES AND SHRUBBERY
SECTION:
6-6-1: Short Title
6-6-2: Definitions
6-6-3: Authority Of Parks And Recreation Department
6-6-4: Permits Required
6-6-5: Obstruction; Trees Trimmed
6-6-6: Abuse Or Mutilation Of Public Trees
6-6-7: Climbing Spurs
6-6-8: Interference
6-6-9: Protection Of Trees And Shrubs
6-6-10: Placing Materials On Public Property
6-6-11: Stump Removal
6-6-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the TREE ORDINANCE of the city.
(Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with
the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the
plural include the singular and words in the singular number include the plural
number. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory:
PARK DEPARTMENT: The parks and recreation department as established in title 3,
chapter 6 of this code or its authorized representative.
PRINCIPAL THOROUGHFARE: Any street upon which trucks are not prohibited.
PROPERTY OWNER: The person owning such property as shown by the latest tax
collector's books of Madison County, Illinois.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width between property lines of every way or
place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the
public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic.
TREE LAWN: That part of a street or highway, not covered by sidewalk or other
paving, lying between the property line and that portion of the street or
highway usually used for traffic.
TREES AND SHRUBS: Includes all woody vegetation, now or hereafter growing on
any public area, except where otherwise indicated. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-3: AUTHORITY OF PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Authority: The parks and recreation department shall have the authority
and jurisdiction of regulating the planting, maintenance, trimming and removal
of trees and shrubs on streets and other publicly owned property to ensure
safety or preserve the symmetry of such public places.
   B.   Supervision: The parks and recreation department shall have the
authority and it shall be its duty to supervise or inspect all work done under
a permit issued in accordance with the terms of this chapter.
   C.   Condition Of Permit: The parks and recreation department shall have the
authority to affix reasonable conditions to the granting of a permit in
accordance with the terms of this chapter.
   D.   Master Street Tree Plan: The parks and recreation department shall have
the authority to formulate a master street tree plan. The master street tree
plan shall specify the species of tree to be planted on each of the streets or
other public places of the city. From and after the effective date of the
master street tree plan, or any amendment thereof, all planting shall conform
thereto.
      1.   The said parks and recreation department shall consider all existing
and future environmental factors when recommending a specific species for each
of the streets or other public places of the city.
      2.   The said parks and recreation department shall have the authority to
amend or add to the master street tree plan at any time that circumstances make
it advisable.
   E.   Arboricultural Specifications And Standards Of Practice: The parks and
recreation department shall have the authority to promulgate arboricultural
specifications and standards of practice governing the planting, preservation,
trimming, removal, fertilization and bracing of trees and shrubs on the streets
or other public places in the city.
      1.   The parks and recreation department shall promulgate such
aboricultural specifications and standards of practice following approved
principals supported by good judgment and on the basis of existing local
conditions.
      2.   The parks and recreation department shall have the authority to
modify, amend or extend the aboricultural specifications and standards of
practice at any time that experience indicates improved methods or whenever
circumstances make it advisable. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-4: PERMITS REQUIRED:
   A.   Preserve Or Remove: No person shall treat, spray, fertilize, preserve,
trim, remove, cut above or below ground, or otherwise disturb any tree or shrub
in any street or city owned property without first filing an application and
procuring a permit from the parks and recreation department. The person
receiving the permit shall abide by the arboricultural specifications and
standards of practice adopted by the parks and recreation department.
      1.   Application Data: The application required herein shall state the
number and species of trees to be treated, sprayed, fertilized, preserved,
trimmed, removed, cut or otherwise disturbed; the kind of treatment to be
administered; the composition of the spray material to be applied; and such
other information as the parks and recreation department shall find reasonably
necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued.
      2.   Standards Of Issuance: The parks and recreation department shall
issue the permit provided for herein if in their judgment the proposed work is
desirable and the proposed method and workmanship thereof are of a satisfactory
nature. Any permit granted shall contain a definite date of expiration. Any
permit shall be void if its terms are violated.
   B.   Planting: No person shall plant or set out any tree or shrub in any
street or public place of the city without first filing an application and
procuring a permit from the parks and recreation department. The person
receiving the permit shall abide by the arboricultural specifications and
standards of practice and the master street tree plan as adopted by the parks
and recreation department.
      1.   Application Data: The application required herein shall state the
number of trees or shrubs to be set out; the location, grade and species of
each tree or shrub; the method of planting; and such other information as the
parks and recreation department shall find reasonably necessary to a fair
determination of whether a permit should be issued.
      2.   Standards For Issuance: The parks and recreation department shall
issue the permit provided for herein if in their judgment the proposed planting
is desirable and the proposed method thereof is of a satisfactory nature. Any
permit granted shall contain a definite expiration date and any permit shall be
void if its terms are violated. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-5: OBSTRUCTION; TREES TRIMMED:
It shall be the duty of any person owning or occupying real property bordering
on any street upon which property there may be trees or shrubs, to trim such
trees or shrubs in such manner that they will not obstruct or shade the
streetlights, or obstruct the passage of pedestrians on such sidewalks, or
obstruct vision of traffic signs, or obstruct view of any street or alley
intersection, and that the minimum clearance of any overhanging portion thereof
shall be nine feet (9') over sidewalks, twelve feet (12') over all streets
except principal thoroughfares which shall have a clearance of sixteen feet
(16'). (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-6: ABUSE OR MUTILATION OF PUBLIC TREES:
Unless specifically authorized by the parks and recreation department, no
person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or
shrub; attach any rope, wire, nails or other contrivance to any tree or shrub;
allow any gaseous, liquid or solid substance which is harmful to such trees or
shrubs to come in contact with them; or set fire or permit any fire to burn
when such fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree or
shrub. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-7: CLIMBING SPURS:
No spurs or climbers which injure the bark of a tree shall be used as an aid to
climbing such tree except when such tree is to be removed. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-
2003)
6-6-8: INTERFERENCE:
No person shall hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the parks and
recreation department, or any of their authorized representatives, while
engaged in carrying out the execution or enforcement of this chapter; provided
however, that nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit the
pursuit of any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of competent
jurisdiction for the protection of property rights by the owner of any property
within the city. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-9: PROTECTION OF TREES AND SHRUBS:
All trees, shrubs or plants on any street or other publicly owned property near
any excavation or construction of any building or structure shall be guarded
with a good substantial frame or box not less than four feet (4') square and
six feet (6') high, and all building materials, dirt or other debris shall be
kept at least three feet (3') from such trees or shrubs.
No person shall excavate any ditches, tunnels or trenches, or lay and drive
within a radius of ten feet (10') from any public tree or shrub without first
obtaining a written permit from the parks and recreation department. (Ord.
6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-10: PLACING MATERIALS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public area of the
city any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other materials which may impede the
free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any tree or shrub
growing therein, except by written permit of the parks and recreation
department. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
6-6-11: STUMP REMOVAL:
All trees and shrubs removed from any street or public place of the city shall
be cut at least three inches (3") below the ground level, and the soil shall be
replaced and the area leveled. (Ord. 6759, 9-10-2003)
CHAPTER 7
PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS
SECTION:
6-7-1: Rules And Regulations
6-7-2: James H. Killion Park At Salu Amusements
6-7-1: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The following rules and regulations shall be adhered to in all park and
playground areas within the corporate limits of the city. No person shall:
   A.   Write upon or mark or deface in any manner or use in any improper way
any water closet, seat, fence or any property or thing pertaining to or in any
park or recreation area in the city.
   B.   Bring or use any vehicle upon any portion of the park and recreation
areas where such vehicles are prohibited from use.
   C.   Drive faster than the rate of twenty (20) miles per hour on the
roadways in any of said parks and recreation areas. All state laws and city
code provisions applying to vehicles shall apply to vehicles within the said
park and recreation areas.
   D.   Break, cut, mutilate or injure, remove or carry away any tree, plant,
shrub, fence or any property in or upon any park, recreation area, square or
place in the city.
   E.   Use any abusive, threatening, insulting, indecent, profane or obscene
language, calculated to occasion a breach of the peace, nor be guilty of any
indecent act or behavior in the park and recreation areas.
   F.   Deposit, dump, throw or place any coal ashes, dust or rubbish in or
upon any part of the park and recreation areas. Paper, garbage or refuse matter
shall not be so deposited except in receptacles provided for that purpose.
(Ord. 3340, 3-24-1966)
   G.   Bathe in any lake or pond in any of the park and recreation areas
without the permission of the parks and recreation department. (Ord. 3340, 3-
24-1966; amd. Ord. 6756, 8-27-2003)
   H.   Chase, kill, set snare for, catch or attempt to catch any rabbits,
squirrels, birds, or any animal belonging to said park and recreation areas or
kept therein. (Ord. 5530, 3-27-1991)
   I.   Apply any placard or advertisement of any kind in the park and
recreation areas, nor shall any person distribute, cast, throw or place any
handbill, pamphlet, circular, advertisement or notice of any kind, nor post,
stencil or otherwise affix any notice, or bills, advertisement or other papers
upon any structure or thing in or about the park and recreation premises except
upon the express permission of the parks and recreation department. (Ord. 3340,
3-24-1966; amd. Ord. 4333, 7-26-1978; Ord. 6756, 8-27-2003)
   J.   Set up any booth or table for the sale of any article whatever or vend
from a vehicle in any of said park and recreation areas, except when authorized
by the parks and recreation department. (Ord. 3340, 3-24-1966; amd. Ord. 6756,
8-27-2003)
   K.   Foul in any manner in any spring, stream, lake, pond or fountain in any
of the park and recreation areas.
   L.   Play at games of chance or use any gambling device in said park and
recreation areas. (Ord. 3340, 3-24-1966)
   M.   Unless by authority of the parks and recreation department, light,
kindle or use any fire on any of said park and recreation areas except in those
places provided for that purpose. (Ord. 3340, 3-24-1966; amd. Ord. 6756, 8-27-
2003)
   N.   Bring any dog into any of said park and recreation areas, except when
fastened or lead by a cord, string or chain sufficient to properly restrain the
same.
   O.   Enter upon any portion of the park and recreation areas where persons
are prohibited from going as indicated by sign, notice or fence.
   P.   Engage in any sport, game or amusement in said park and recreation
areas except in such portions thereof as may be designated for this purpose.
(Ord. 3340, 3-24-1966)
   Q.   Bring within, sell, give away, or drink any intoxicating liquors in the
park and recreation areas except as a licensee or customer of a Class M or a
Class P-1 license or pursuant to a special event permit all as authorized by
title 4, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 7423, 9-24-2014; amd. Ord. 7611, 12-20-
2017)
   R.   Make, countenance or assist in making any improper noise, riot,
disturbance, breach of the peace or diversion tending to the breach of the
peace in the park and recreation areas, or be guilty of any disorderly conduct
therein, or collect with other persons, in bodies or crowds, for unlawful
purposes, or for any purpose to the annoyance or obstruction or disturbance of
other persons. (Ord. 3340, 3-24-1966)
   S.   Resist any employee or police officer of the Parks and Recreation
Department in the discharge of his duty, or fail or refuse to obey any lawful
command of any such employee or police officer or in any way interfere with or
hinder or prevent any such employee or police officer from discharging his
duty. (Ord. 3340, 3-24-1966; amd. Ord. 6756, 8-27-2003)
   T.   The use and visitation of parks and recreation areas shall be between
sunrise and sunset or upon completion of activities scheduled by the City of
Alton Department of Parks and Recreation, whichever is later.
The use of the parks and recreation areas at hours other than those provided
herein shall be with a special permit issued only by the City of Alton Parks
and Recreation Department.
Parking of any vehicle is prohibited in all parks and recreation areas from the
time of closing as set forth herein until sunrise. (Ord. 6983, 12-20-2006)
   U.   Operate any motor powered vehicle of any type in any portion of the
park, recreation or playground areas of the City except upon those streets,
paths or other specifically designated areas upon which the rules and
regulations of the Parks and Recreation Department expressly authorize the
operation of said motor driven vehicles. (Ord. 4522, 6-11-1980; amd. Ord. 6756,
8-27-2003)
   V.   Bring or use a snowmobile or all-terrain vehicle upon any portion of
park and recreation areas. (Ord. 4641, 9-23-1981)
   W.   Fish in any City park at any time except as permitted in Moore Park
Lake and only in accordance with fishing regulations established herein.
      1.   Fishing shall be by pole and line only and only from the bank of the
lake. (Ord. 5530, 3-27-1991)
      2.   Fishing shall be allowed only in areas specifically designated and
marked by the Parks and Recreation Department employees.
      3.   No person shall fish before sunrise or after sunset, exact times to
be determined by Parks and Recreation Department employees each day. (Ord.
5530, 3-27-1991; amd. Ord. 6756, 8-27-2003)
      4.   Fishing shall be permitted only for those persons who have a valid
fishing license issued by the State of Illinois, except fishing licenses shall
not be required of persons under sixteen (16) years of age or over sixty four
(64) years of age.
      5.   No person shall fish through ice on the lake or when any ice is
present on any portion of the lake.
      6.   No person shall clean any fish in any part of the Gordon F. Moore
Park.
      7.   No person shall take more than a total of twenty five (25) bluegill
or redear fish from the lake per day.
      8.   No person shall take more than six (6) channel cat from the lake per
day. (Ord. 5530, 3-27-1991)
      9.   No person shall take more than one bass fish of length in excess of
fifteen inches (15") per day and no person shall take more than three (3) bass
per day of any size in accordance with IDNR-2006. (Ord. 6983, 12-20-2006)
   X.   Swim, dive or wade in the lake at Gordon Moore Park.
   Y.   Operate or use a boat, with or without a motor, at Gordon Moore Park.
(Ord. 7028, 10-10-2007)
   Z.   Use bicycles, skateboards, rollerblades, roller skates or similar
devices in or upon the amphitheater area and its related improvements in Alton
Riverfront Park or in or upon any City owned fountain or improvements related
thereto. (Ord. 7191, 4-28-2010)
   AA.   It shall be unlawful for any person not specifically authorized by the
Alton Marina to be present on the riprap stone area from the east end of the
riprap stone wall of the Alton Marina running parallel with the launch ramp
connecting to the south end of riprap stone to the wall that runs parallel with
the river connecting to the west end riprap stone wall that runs parallel with
the city park/amphitheater connecting to the north end of the riprap stone wall
running parallel with the Alton Marina parking lot which connects to the east
riprap stone wall. The areas of limited access shall be clearly marked by the
management of the Alton Marina. (Ord. 7292, 12-21-2011)
   BB.   It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to allow the dog to
enter or remain in Hellrung Park or James H. Killion Park At Salu, whether
restrained or unrestrained. Any dog found in Hellrung Park or James H. Killion
Park At Salu may be taken by police or the animal control officer and impounded
in accordance with section
7-12-6 of this code. This section shall not apply to any specially trained
service dog while in the service of a handicapped person. (Ord. 7403, 5-14-
2014)
6-7-2: JAMES H. KILLION PARK AT SALU AMUSEMENTS:
Any person desiring to produce, present, conduct or offer for gain or profit
any of the entertainments, exhibitions or performances as set forth in title 4,
chapter 2 of this code shall make application to the mayor in writing setting
out the full name of the applicant, description of the kind and class of
entertainment he intends to offer, and the place at which it is desired to
present such entertainment. Upon the payment by such applicant to the city
treasurer of the license fee hereinafter specified for the production or
presentation of, the city clerk shall issue to such applicant a license
authorizing him to conduct, produce, present or offer the class of
entertainment specified in such license at the place described in such
application and for the period of time specified in such license; providing
however, that if the place at which it is desired to offer such entertainment
be not fit or proper place and not conducted or maintained in accordance with
the provisions of this code governing or controlling such places, or if the
entertainment desired to be produced be of an immoral or dangerous character,
the mayor may refuse to approve such application and no license shall be issued
by the city clerk, except upon the approval of the application therefor by the
mayor; provided however, that no such license shall be issued for the
presentation, production or conducting of a carnival at or on the site commonly
known and referred to as James H. Killion Park At Salu, which park is bounded
by the following streets:
   Humbert Street
   Locust Street
   Salu Street
   Washington Avenue
With regard to the above James H. Killion Park At Salu exclusion, the mayor is
hereby empowered to determine what activities shall constitute a carnival,
however, it is the express intention of said exclusion that the following types
of amusements are not to be considered carnivals: (Ord. 2733, 6-13-1958; amd.
Ord. 6983, 12-20-2006)
   A.   Those put on for the raising of funds for a charitable institution.
   B.   Those put on by an employer for the benefit of employees of any company
or business.
   C.   Those put on for the raising of funds for the furtherance of city
playground or park activities. (Ord. 2733, 6-13-1958)
CHAPTER 8
CEMETERY
SECTION:
6-8-1: Deed Accepted
6-8-2: Maintenance Of Cemetery
6-8-1: DEED ACCEPTED:
The City accepts a certain deed dated February 27, 1950, by the Board of
Trustees of the Alton Cemetery, a corporation, to the City of Alton conveying
the legal title to the City Cemetery or burying grounds of the City as the same
are more specifically set out and described and subject to the provisions
therein contained. A copy of said deed shall be and remain on file in the
office of the City Clerk, and shall be incorporated herein by reference. (Ord.
2347, 4-12-1950)
6-8-2: MAINTENANCE OF CEMETERY:
The Alton Cemetery, a corporation, shall assume the care, upkeep and
maintenance of said Cemetery in accordance with the provisions of said deed
until changed by general ordinance with the concurrence of the Park and
Recreation Commission. (Ord. 2347, 4-12-1950; amd. 1999 Code)
CHAPTER 9
CULVERTS
SECTION:
6-9-1: Definitions
6-9-2: Maintenance
6-9-3: Personal Liability
6-9-4: Liens
6-9-5: Duties
6-9-6: Size Of Culverts
6-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Chapter, have the
meaning ascribed to them in this Section, except where the content clearly
indicates a different meaning:
BENEFITED PROPERTY: That parcel of real property originally benefited or
improved by the installation of a culvert.
CULVERT: A storm sewer or storm drain crossing under a roadway, walkway or
embankment.
OWNER OF THE BENEFITED PROPERTY: Whoever from time to time shall be the record
owner or owners of the benefited property. In the event of multiple owners,
notice to one shall be sufficient notice for purposes of Section
6-9-4 of this Chapter; and as to Section
6-9-3 of this Chapter, if the owners hold their interests as joint tenants,
each owner shall be deemed jointly and severally liable and if the owners hold
their interests as tenants in common each owner may be liable for his or her
respective fractional share of the costs and resulting judgment.
REASONABLE TIME: A period of time not less than ten (10) days nor more than
forty five (45) days unless emergency conditions or other good cause can be
shown. (Ord. 4355, 10-11-1978)
6-9-2: MAINTENANCE:
In the event a culvert is constructed by or on behalf of a private property
owner and is designed to benefit a particular parcel of private property the
owner of the benefited property shall be responsible for the maintenance and
repair of the respective culvert serving the benefited property. (Ord. 4355,
10-11-1978)
6-9-3: PERSONAL LIABILITY:
If the Director of Public Works determines that, in his opinion, maintenance or
repair is necessary with regard to a particular culvert, he may demand by
written notice that the owner of the benefited property accomplish such
maintenance or repair within a reasonable time after such written notice. If
the owner of the benefited property fails to accomplish such maintenance or
repair within a reasonable time after such written notice, the Director of
Public Works may apply to the Circuit Court of the State of Illinois for
judgment authorizing the City to accomplish the necessary maintenance and
repair of the particular culvert and the Court may so order; and further, the
Court shall enter judgment against the owner of the benefited property in favor
of the City for the costs of accomplishing the necessary maintenance or repair
of the particular culvert, together with the costs of suit. (Ord. 4355, 10-11-
1978)
6-9-4: LIENS:
If the Director of Public Works determines that, in his opinion, maintenance or
repair is necessary with regard to a particular culvert, he may demand by
written notice that the owner of the benefited property accomplish such
maintenance or repair within a reasonable time. If the owner of the benefited
property fails to accomplish such maintenance or repair within a reasonable
time after such written notice, the Director of Public Works may accomplish
such necessary maintenance or repair of the particular culvert and the City may
thereafter file a lien in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Madison
County, Illinois, setting forth therein a description of the benefited property
served by the particular culvert, the amount of money the City expended in
accomplishing said maintenance or repair, and the date or dates when such cost
and expense was incurred by the City. This lien shall be superior to all other
liens and encumbrances excepting tax liens as provided for by statute. (Ord.
4355, 10-11-1978)
6-9-5: DUTIES:
No owner of the benefited property shall refuse or neglect to accomplish the
necessary maintenance or repair of the particular culvert serving said
benefited property when demanded so to do by the Director of Public Works, as
provided for in Sections
6-9-3 and
6-9-4 of this Chapter. The person or persons responsible for the maintenance
and repair of a culvert may, with the prior written permission of the Director
of Public Works, eliminate said culvert, returning the land to a natural
drainage condition by establishing a drainage ditch, rather than maintain or
repair the respective culvert. In the event the Director of Public Works
refuses to grant such permission after requested to do so, in writing, the City
will assume responsibility for the maintenance and repair of the respective
culvert. (Ord. 4355, 10-11-1978)
6-9-6: SIZE OF CULVERTS:
Sizes of culverts shall be determined by the Director of Public Works, but in
normal installations shall have a minimum of twelve inches (12") in diameter.
(Ord. 6057, 3-27-1996)
CHAPTER 10
SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL
SECTION:
6-10-1: Definitions
6-10-2: Connection To Public Sewer Required
6-10-3: Permit Requirements
6-10-4: Rates And Charges
6-10-4-1: Delinquent Payments; Penalty
6-10-4-2: Notice Of Liability
6-10-5: Connections

6-10-5-2: Separate Connections Required

6-10-5-4: Connection To Public Sewer
6-10-5-5: Connections From Existing Establishments
6-10-5-6: Installation Or Repair Prior To Street Improvement
6-10-5-7: Time For Compliance
6-10-5-8: Neglect Or Failure To Install Or Extend Services
6-10-5-9: Discharge Into; Connection To Storm Drains
6-10-5-10: Connection Of Surface Drains
6-10-5-11: Grease, Oil And Sand Interceptors
6-10-5-12: New Connections To Combined Sewer System
6-10-5-13: Disconnection Of Inflow Sources On Combined Sewer System
6-10-5-14: Prohibited Materials
6-10-6: Discharges To System
6-10-6-1: Unsanitary Discharge
6-10-6-2: Discharge Into Watercourses
6-10-7: Industrial Wastes
6-10-8: Privies And Private Systems
6-10-8-1: Privies Prohibited
6-10-8-2: Private Sewage Disposal
