be guided by a guide dog when walking on the streets, highways or sidewalks,
shall not be considered as evidence of contributory negligence. (Ord. 3378, 10-
12-1966)
8-4-6: DRIVERS TO EXERCISE DUE CARE:
Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this chapter, every driver of a
vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any
roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall
exercise proper precaution upon any child or confused or incapacitated person
upon a roadway. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-4-7: SOLICITING:
Soliciting contributions from the occupant of any vehicle shall be allowed in
the city, subject to the following terms and conditions:
   A.   Only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a full
stop;
   B.   The soliciting agency must be registered with the attorney general as a
charitable organization as provided by "an act to regulate solicitation and
collection of funds for charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof,
and making an appropriation therefor", approved July 26, 1963, as amended;
   C.   The soliciting agency must be engaged in a statewide fundraising
activity;
   D.   The soliciting agency shall be liable for any injuries to any person or
property during the solicitation which is causally related to an act of
ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent;
   E.   Any person engaged in the act of solicitation shall be sixteen (16)
years of age or more and shall be wearing a high visibility vest;
   F.   The soliciting agency will also fully indemnify the city from any
claims, injuries, expenses or judgments that may arise from the solicitation
activity; (Ord. 5808, 8-25-1993)
   G.   The soliciting agency shall carry liability insurance in the minimum
amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) covering soliciting agency and
naming the city of Alton as an additional insured and the soliciting agency
shall file a certified copy of said insurance policy with the city treasurer;
(Ord. 6682, 10-23-2002)
   H.   The soliciting agency shall pay a twenty five dollar ($25.00) permit
fee to the city treasurer for each fundraising activity which is contemplated.
(Ord. 5808, 8-25-1993)
CHAPTER 5
BICYCLES
SECTION:
8-5-1: Definitions
8-5-2: Traffic Laws And Signals
8-5-3: Riding Restrictions
8-5-4: Designated Bicycle Routes, Trails, Lanes, Paths
8-5-5: Bicycle Equipment
8-5-6: Penalty
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
BICYCLE: A lightweight device propelled mostly by human peddle power upon which
a person may ride, having two (2) or three (3) wheels. References to "BICYCLE"
in this chapter are intended to include tricycles and tandem cycles for two or
more persons.
BICYCLE CROSSING: A point of crossing at a roadway designated and marked for
the purpose of orderly crossing of vehicular traffic lanes similar to and under
the same restrictions normally imposed within the context of a pedestrian
crosswalk.
BICYCLE LANE: A portion of a roadway which has been designated for preferential
or exclusive use of bicycles. It is distinguished from the portion of the
roadway for motor vehicular traffic by a painted stripe, curb or other similar
device.
BICYCLE ROUTE, BICYCLE WAY, BICYCLE TRAIL BIKEWAY, OR SHARED ROADWAY: Any road,
street, path or way which in some manner is specifically designated as being
open to bicycle travel but is to be shared with other transportation modes.
BICYCLE PATH: A separate path which is for the exclusive use of bicycles,
walkers and runners. Where such trail or path forms part of a highway, it is
separated from the roadway for motor vehicular traffic by an open space or
barrier. (Ord. 3974, 3-26-1975; amd. Ord. 7956, 9-25-2024)
8-5-2: TRAFFIC LAWS AND SIGNALS:
   A.   Laws Applicable To Bicycle Riders: Every person riding a bicycle upon a
roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the
duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this State
declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic ordinances
of this City applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special
regulations in this Chapter and except as to those provisions of laws and
ordinances which by their nature can have no application.
   B.   Traffic-Control Signals:
      1.   Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of
official traffic-control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to
vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
      2.   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or
left or "U" turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the
direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle
to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the
regulations applicable to pedestrians. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-5-3: RIDING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Riding On Bicycles: A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other
than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto, nor shall any
bicycle be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it
is designed and equipped.
   B.   Riding On Roadways And Bicycle Paths:
      1.   Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near
to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when
passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction.
      2.   Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two
(2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive
use of bicycles.
      3.   Where a useable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a
roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway.
   C.   Riding On Sidewalks:
      1.   No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business
district.
      2.   The City Council may from time to time, by ordinance, prohibit the
riding of bicycles on certain sidewalks and/or roadways by any person and when
signs are in place pursuant to such ordinance or ordinances, no person shall
disobey same.
      3.   Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person
shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal
before overtaking and passing such pedestrian.
   D.   Speed: No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is
reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing.
   E.   Emerging From Alley Or Driveway: The operator of a bicycle emerging
from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the
sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right of way to all
pedestrians approaching on said sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway
shall yield the right of way to all vehicles approaching on said roadway.
   F.   Carrying Articles: No person operating a bicycle shall carry any
package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one
hand upon the handlebars.
   G.   Parking: No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon
the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the
bicycle or against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the
least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-5-4: DESIGNATED BICYCLE ROUTES, TRAILS, LANES, PATHS:
   A.   State Street Trail
      State Street from East Broadway to Elm Street.
   B.   Alton Heritage Trail
      Starting at the intersection of Elm and State Streets, follow Elm Street
east until it crosses Rt 67 and intersects with Central Avenue. Then follow
Central Avene south until it intersects with Grove Street. Go on Grove to
Liberty Street then south on Liberty to 15th Street. Then go one block on 15th
to Henry Street. Go South on Henry Street all the way to cross East Broadway as
well as Landmarks Blvd and continue until it intersects with the MCT Confluence
Trail.
   C.   Riverview Park Loop
      Along Bluff Street from State Street to Riverview Drive and continuing on
Park Avenue adjacent to Riverview Park to the intersection with Angle Street.
Thence on Angle Street to Foulds Avenue, thence along Foulds Avenue to turn
north on Lohr Street behind Irving School to intersect with Bluff Street.
   D.   River Trails Connector
      Beginning at the intersection of Jefferson and State Streets and
progressing along Jefferson to Mack Street, thence on Mack Street to McInerney
Street, thence on McInerney Street to Grand Avenue unimproved right of way.
      Beginning at the Grand Avenue right of way on McInerney Street go south
to an intersection with the Sam Vadalebene Bicycle Trail adjacent to the
McAdams Highway. (This portion marked and maintained as a restricted Bicycle
Path but allowing use by authorized vehicles.)
      Starting at the intersection of Jefferson Street and State Street
continuing to its intersection with 9th Street. Then continuing along 9th
Street until intersecting with Market Street, Then continuing along Market
Street south until it intersects with Lincoln-Douglus Park at East Broadway.
   E.   Cross Town Connector
      Starting at the intersection of 6th and Market, follow 6th Street until
it intersects with Henry Street.
   F.   Bell Street Connector
      Starting at the intersection of Bell Street and 9th Street, proceed south
to Fourth Street and follow Fourth west to State Street.
   G.   River Front Trail
      On W Broadway from Piasa to the Vadalebene Trailhead
   H.   College & Rt 140
      Starting at the intersection of Washington Avenue and College Avenue
proceeding easterly therefrom along College Avenue to its intersection with
Illinois Route 140; continuing easterly on Illinois Route 140 to the entrance
to Gordon F. Moore Park. (Ord. 7402, 5-14- 2014; amd. Ord. 7956, 9-25-2024)
8-5-5: BICYCLE EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on
the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least
five hundred feet (500') to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a
type which shall be visible from all distances from fifty feet (50') to three
hundred feet (300') to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of
headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a
distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear may be used in addition to the
red reflector.
   B.   No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or
other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least one
hundred feet (100'), except that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall
any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle.
   C.   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the
operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. (Ord.
3378, 10-12-1966)
8-5-6: PENALTY:
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by
impounding of such person's bicycle for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days
or by any combination thereof. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966; amd. Ord. 4255, 11-23-
1977)
CHAPTER 6
INOPERABLE, ABANDONED AND WRECKED VEHICLES
SECTION:
8-6-1: Definitions
8-6-2: Interpretation Of Provisions
8-6-3: Prohibited Conditions
8-6-4: Abatement Of Nuisance
8-6-5: Junk Vehicle Facility
8-6-6: Procedures On Abandoned, Wrecked Vehicles
8-6-7: Sale Of Unclaimed Vehicles
8-6-8: Liability
8-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
ABANDONED VEHICLE: All motor vehicles or other vehicles in a state of disrepair
rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition or which is
unlicensed; or any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved from
the street or used for seven (7) consecutive days or more and is apparently
deserted.
ANTIQUE VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle or other vehicle twenty five (25) years of
age or older.
HIGHWAY: Any street, alley or public way within the city.
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at
least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or
on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its
own motor power, or which is unlicensed, but shall not include:
   A.   A motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being
driven under its own power in order to perform ordinary service or repair
operations;
   B.   Any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in use;
   C.   A motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in the
wrecking or junking of motor vehicles.
JUNK VEHICLE FACILITY: A place of business where motor vehicles, in excess of
fifty (50), are being stacked, disassembled, salvaged or otherwise reduced to a
state in which they no longer can be returned to an operable state, and where
the length of time the motor vehicle is stored at the facility is in excess of
thirty (30) days. (Ord. 6581, 6-13-2001)
8-6-2: INTERPRETATION OF PROVISIONS:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit the power of the city to
abate a nuisance where the circumstances creating the nuisance include the
maintenance of a motor vehicle on public or private property. (Ord. 5286, 9-28-
1988)
8-6-3: PROHIBITED CONDITIONS:
   A.   Inoperable Motor Vehicles: All inoperable motor vehicles in view of the
general public, whether on public or private property within the city, are
hereby declared nuisances. (Ord. 5286, 9-28-1988)
   B.   Abandoned Vehicles: The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle
or any part thereof on any highway in the city is unlawful and subject to
penalties as set forth in this code. The abandonment of a motor vehicle or
other vehicle or any part thereof on private or public property, other than a
highway, in view of the general public, anywhere in this city is unlawful
except on property of the owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle. A motor
vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof so abandoned on private property
may be authorized for removal by or upon the order of the chief of police,
after a waiting period of seven (7) days or more has expired. (Ord. 3609, 7-9-
1970)
8-6-4: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE:
   A.   Notice: A person is required to dispose of any inoperable motor vehicle
(s) or parts thereof under his or her control within seven (7) days after
written notice is issued by the building and housing inspector or from the
chief of police or any member of his department designated by him, commanding
disposition of the inoperable motor vehicle(s).
   B.   Permission Required: A person shall not deposit on any public or
private roadway, alley, driveway, parking area, or other place within the city
limits, any inoperable vehicle or part thereof without first obtaining
permission of the owner, occupancy or agent of the private property, and the
building and housing inspector or the police department of the city. (Ord.
5368, 8-9-1989; amd. Ord. 5503, 12-19-1990)
   C.   Disposal; Removal: If a person fails to dispose of any inoperable motor
vehicle(s) or parts thereof under his control within seven (7) days from the
issuance of the municipal notice, the police department may remove said
inoperable vehicles or parts thereof. (Ord. 5286, 9-28-1988)
   D.   Penalty: Any person who fails to dispose of an inoperable motor vehicle
(s) or parts thereof or an abandoned motor vehicle(s) under his control within
the period of time delineated in the notice served pursuant to subsection A of
this section, shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. Each day such offense continues shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord.
5286, 9-28-1988; amd. 1999 Code)
8-6-5: JUNK VEHICLE FACILITY:
The owner or operator of a junk vehicle facility shall each be required to
abide by the following regulations: (Ord. 5480, 10-24-1990)
   A.   The junk vehicle facility shall be screened from public view by a solid
fence of good repair that has a minimum height of ten feet (10') when said
facility is adjacent to a conservation zoning district, a residential zoning
district or a designated state or federal highway. Said fence shall be
constructed of accepted fencing material and maintained in a uniform, sightly
and nonoffensive manner. No forms of signage shall be allowed to be placed upon
said fence, except for that legally allowed to identify the enterprise located
upon the premises. (Ord. 5817, 10-27-1993)
   B.   Motor vehicles shall not be stacked more than two (2) high. In no case
shall salvaged and/or stored materials be arranged in a manner to be made
visible above the fence or landscaping.
   C.   Emergency vehicle access lanes shall be maintained throughout the junk
vehicle facility with a minimum of fifteen feet (15').
   D.   There shall be no storage of hazardous materials within the junk
vehicle facility. (Ord. 5480, 10-24-1990)
8-6-6: PROCEDURES ON ABANDONED, WRECKED VEHICLES:
   A.   Notify Police Department: When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed
motor vehicle or other vehicle comes into the temporary possession or custody
of a person in this state, not the owner of the vehicle such person shall
immediately notify the police department when the vehicle is within the
corporate limits of the city. Upon receipt of such notification, the chief of
police shall authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the
abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing
service will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents, maintain a record
of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person
legally entitled to possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as provided
in this chapter.
   B.   Removal:
      1.   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a highway in
this city ten (10) hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be
authorized by order of the chief of police.
      2.   When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially
dismantled motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because
of its position in relation to the highway or its physical appearance is
causing the impeding of traffic, its immediate removal from the highway by a
towing service may be authorized by order of the chief of the police
department.
      3.   When a vehicle removed from either public or private property is
authorized by order of the Chief of Police, the owner of the vehicle will be
responsible for all towing costs.
   C.   Records Kept: When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be
towed away, the Police Department shall keep and maintain a record of the
vehicle towed, listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade
name, manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and
license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall also
include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location towed to,
reason for towing and the name of the officer authorizing the tow.
   D.   Owner Unknown:
      1.   When the Police Department does not know the identity of the
registered owner or other legally entitled person, they will cause the motor
vehicle registration records of the State of Illinois to be searched by a
directed communication to the Secretary of State for the purpose of obtaining
the required ownership information.
      2.   The Police Department will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of
the Illinois State Police to be searched by a directed communication to the
Illinois State Police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the
Illinois State Police files are searched with negative results, the information
contained in the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be
searched by the Illinois State Police. The information determined from these
record searches will be used by the Police Department in sending a notification
by certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising where the
vehicle is held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth public sale
information.
      3.   When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the
possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the
registration files of this State or from the registration files of a foreign
state, if applicable, the Police Department shall notify the Illinois State
Police for the purpose of identifying the vehicle's owner or other person
legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by
the Illinois State Police will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement
agency having custody of the vehicle for notification of owner. (Ord. 3609, 7-
9-1970)
8-6-7: SALE OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
   A.   Sale At Public Auction: Any time before a motor vehicle or other
vehicle is sold at public sale or disposed of as provided herein, the owner or
other person legally entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by
presenting to the Police Department proof of ownership or proof of the right to
possession of the vehicle. No vehicle shall be released to the owner or other
person under this Section until all towing and storage charges have been paid.
   B.   Notice Of Sale: Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor
vehicle or other vehicle, seven (7) years of age or newer, remains unclaimed by
the registered owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a
period of thirty (30) days after notice has been given as provided herein, the
Police Department having possession of the vehicle shall cause it to be sold at
public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale
shall be posted in a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the
sale on the premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10)
days prior to the sale, the Police Department shall cause a notice of the time
and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail to the registered owner or
other person known by the Police Deportment or towing service to be legally
entitled to the possession of the vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete
description of the vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any
legally entitled person to reclaim the vehicle.
In those instances where the certified notification specified herein has been
returned by the postal authorities to the Police Department due to the
addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from the
registration records of this State, the sending of a second certified notice
will not be required.
   C.   Sale Without Notice: When the identity of the registered owner or other
person legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed
vehicle of seven (7) years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means
provided for in this Chapter, the vehicle may be sold as provided herein or
disposed of in the manner authorized by this Chapter without notice to the
registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of the
vehicle.
When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is impounded as
specified by this Chapter, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of ten (10)
days for the purpose of determining ownership, the contacting of the registered
owner by the U.S. mail, public service or in person for a determination of
disposition; and, an examination of the Illinois State Police stolen motor
vehicle files for theft and wanted information. At the expiration of the ten
(10) day period, without the benefit of disposition being received from the
registered owner, the Chief of Police will authorize the disposal of the
vehicle as junk only.
A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle is excluded
from this Chapter.
   D.   Report Maintained: When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody
of the Police Department is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally
entitled person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise
disposed of as provided in this Chapter, a report of the transaction will be
maintained by the Police Department for a period of one year from the date of
the sale or disposal.
   E.   Proceeds Of Sale: When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of
the Municipality is authorized to be towed away by the Chief of Police and
disposed of as set forth in this Chapter, the proceeds of the public sale or
disposition after the deduction of towing, storage and processing charges shall
be deposited in the Municipal Treasury. (Ord. 3609, 7-9-1970)
8-6-8: LIABILITY:
Any police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in any section brought by the
registered owner, former registered owner or his legal representatives, or any
other person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other
vehicle when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by
this Chapter. (Ord. 3609, 7-9-1970)
CHAPTER 7
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION
SECTION:
8-7-1: Windows And Mirrors
8-7-2: Lights
8-7-3: Horns And Warning Devices
8-7-4: Tires
8-7-5: Brakes
8-7-6: Mufflers, Prevention Of Noise
8-7-7: Dimension Of Vehicles Restricted
8-7-8: Volunteer Firefighter Vehicles
8-7-9: Prohibited Conditions
8-7-1: WINDOWS AND MIRRORS:
   A.   Clear Vision: It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which is
loaded or in such a condition that the operator does not have clear vision of
all parts of the roadway essential to the safe operation of the vehicle.
   B.   Mirrors: Any vehicle that is so constructed or in such condition as to
obstruct the operator's view of the roadway to the rear of such vehicle shall
be equipped with a mirror so located that it will afford such operator a view
of the roadway behind him for a distance of two hundred feet (200').
   C.   Windshields And Wipers:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to
operate such motor vehicle upon any street with any sign, poster or other
nontransparent material attached to the windshield, sidewings, side or rear
windows of such motor vehicle which obstructs the operator's clear view of the
street.
      2.   The windshield on every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a
device for cleaning rain, snow, or other moisture from the windshield, and such
device shall be so constructed and maintained as to be subject to the control
and operation of the operator of such vehicle. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-7-2: LIGHTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon any street
unless such vehicle is equipped with such lamp equipment as required by and in
such condition as is prescribed by State law. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-7-3: HORNS AND WARNING DEVICES:
Every motor vehicle when operated upon any street of the City shall be equipped
with a horn in good working order and capable of emitting sound audible under
normal conditions from a distance not less than two hundred feet (200') but no
horn or other warning device shall emit an unreasonably loud or harsh sound or
whistle.
No vehicle equipped with a gong, siren, bell, whistle, or explosive type of
warning signal, except fire apparatus, fire patrol vehicles, ambulances,
motorbuses and emergency vehicles of any governmental agency shall be operated
upon the streets. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-7-4: TIRES:
   A.   Generally: All freight-carrying motor vehicles operating upon the
public streets and alleys of the City shall have tires of rubber or other
material of equal resiliency; provided, that solid tires shall be considered
defective and the use thereof shall not be permitted if the rubber or other
material has been worn or otherwise reduced to a thickness of less than three-
quarters of an inch (3/4"), or if such tires have been so worn or otherwise
damaged as to cause pounding on the pavement. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
   B.   Studded Tires: No motor vehicle shall be operated upon the streets or
alleys of the City which shall be equipped with studded tires; provided,
however, this prohibition shall not be applicable between October 1 of any year
and until May 1 of the following year on single tire vehicles with a rated
capacity of not more than ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross vehicle weight on
which there are wheel-wells or other items of a similarly protective nature,
whether permanently or temporarily attached thereto. (Ord. 3461, 12-13-1967)
8-7-5: BRAKES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle upon any
street, unless such motor vehicle is equipped with such brake equipment as
required by and in such condition as prescribed by State law. (Ord. 3378, 10-
12-1966)
8-7-6: MUFFLERS, PREVENTION OF NOISE:
   A.   Unnecessary Noise: It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle which
makes unusually loud or unnecessary noise. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
   B.   Mufflers: Every motor vehicle driven or operated upon a street or
highway of this City shall at all times be equipped with an adequate muffler or
exhaust system in constant operation and properly maintained to prevent any
excessive or unusual noise. No such muffler or exhaust system shall be equipped
with a cutout, bypass or similar device. No person shall modify the exhaust
system of a motor vehicle in a manner which will amplify or increase the noise
of such vehicle above that emitted by the muffler originally installed on the
vehicle, and such original muffler shall comply with all the requirements of
this Section. (Ord. 4521, 5-14-1980)
8-7-7: DIMENSION OF VEHICLES RESTRICTED:
   A.   Length Of Vehicles:
      1.   No vehicle, unladen or with load, shall exceed a length of forty two
feet (42') extreme overall dimension.
      2.   No truck tractor and semi-trailer, unladen or with load, shall
exceed a length of fifty five feet (55') overall dimension, except that such
combination, when specially designed to transport motor vehicles may have a
length of sixty feet (60') extreme overall dimension. No other combination of
vehicles, unladen or with load, shall exceed a length of sixty feet (60')
extreme overall dimension.
      3.   Length limitation shall not apply to vehicles operated in the day
time when transporting poles, pipe, machinery or other objects of a structural
nature which cannot readily be dismembered, nor to such vehicle transporting
such objects operated at night time by a public utility when required for
emergency repair of public service facilities or properties or when operated
under special permit as provided in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-301,
but in respect to such night transportation every such vehicle and the load
thereon shall be equipped with a sufficient number of clearance lamps on both
sides and marker lamps upon the extreme ends of any projecting load to clearly
mark the dimension of such load. Neither shall the length limitations apply to
a combination of vehicles consisting of a towing vehicle and a disabled vehicle
or vehicles when engaged in removing the disabled vehicle or vehicles from the
highway to the nearest repair station.
      4.   The load upon any vehicle operated alone, or the load upon the front
vehicle of a combination of vehicles, shall not extend more than three feet
(3') beyond the front wheels of such vehicle or the front bumper of such
vehicle if it is equipped with such a bumper.
   B.   Projecting Loads: No passenger-type vehicle shall be operated on any
highway with any load carrier thereon extending beyond the line of the fenders
on the left side of such vehicle nor extending more than six inches (6") beyond
the line of the fenders on the right side thereof.
Any vehicle having a load projecting more than four feet (4') beyond the rear
of the body of such vehicle during the period from sunrise to sunset must have
firmly attached to the end of the projecting load, in such a way as to be seen
by persons approaching from either side at the rear of such vehicle, a red
cloth not less than sixteen inches (16") square, and during the period from
sunset to sunrise, must have a lighted red lamp or lantern plainly visible from
a distance of at least five hundred feet (500') to the side and rear, firmly
attached to the rear end of such projecting load. Such lighted red lamp or
lantern shall be in addition to any other light required to be carried by
vehicles under any law of the State or any ordinance of the City in regard to
vehicles. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-7-8: VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTER VEHICLES:
Any motor vehicle owned or usually operated by a volunteer firefighter may be
equipped with not to exceed two (2) lamps which shall emit a blue light without
glare. One such lamp may be mounted on the rear of any such vehicle. Except
that a flashing blue light may be used only when such fireman is responding to
a fire call. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-7-9: PROHIBITED CONDITIONS:
   A.   Gas And Smoke: It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits
dense smoke or such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the
health of persons or as to endanger the drivers of other vehicles.
   B.   Spilling Loads: No vehicle shall be so loaded that any part of its load
spills or drops on any street or alley in the City.
   C.   Unattended Motor Vehicles: No person driving or in charge of a motor
vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine,
locking the ignition and removing the key, or when standing upon any
perceptible grade without effectively setting the brake thereon and turning the
front wheels to the curb or side of the street. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
CHAPTER 8
ENFORCEMENT, VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
SECTION:
8-8-1: Enforcement By Police Officers And Firefighters
8-8-2: Unlawful Acts
8-8-3: Accidents
8-8-4: Penalty For Violations
8-8-5: Traffic Citations
8-8-6: Disposition Of Records, Fines And Forfeitures
8-8-7: Audit Of Records And Reports (Rep. by Ord. 7299, 2-22-2012)
8-8-8: Prohibited Acts
8-8-9: Police Authorized To Relocate Vehicles
8-8-10: Authority To Impound Vehicles
8-8-11: Impoundment Of Motor Vehicles
8-8-12: Sale Of Unclaimed Motor Vehicles
8-8-1: ENFORCEMENT BY POLICE OFFICERS AND FIREFIGHTERS:
   A.   Police Officers:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to
enforce all street traffic laws of this city and all of the state vehicle laws
applicable to street traffic in this city.
      2.   Members of the police department are hereby authorized to direct all
traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws; provided
that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to
safeguard pedestrians, members of the police department may direct traffic as
conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws.
(Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966; amd. 1999 Code)
      3.   Police officers as used in this chapter when pertaining to illegal
parking shall include sworn police officers, parking control officers or police
cadets of the city of Alton. (Ord. 7299, 2-22-2012)
   B.   Firefighters: Members of the fire department, when at the scene of a
fire, may direct or assist police in directing traffic thereat or in the
immediate vicinity. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966; amd. 1999 Code)
8-8-2: UNLAWFUL ACTS:
   A.   Persons Under Influence Of Intoxicating Liquor Or Narcotic Drugs: It
shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle on any street in
the city who is a habitual user of narcotic drugs or who is under the influence
of intoxicating liquor. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
   B.   Reckless Driving: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any
vehicle with a wilful or wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property
within the city. (Ord. 4656, 11-25-1981)
   C.   Drag Racing: It shall be unlawful for any person to compete in "drag
racing" in any motor vehicle on any street within the city. For the purpose of
this subsection, "drag racing" means the act of two (2) or more individuals
competing or racing on any street in a situation in which one of the motor
vehicles is beside or to the rear of a motor vehicle operated by a competing
driver and the one driver attempts to prevent the competing driver from passing
or overtaking him, or one or more individuals compete in a race against time on
any street in this city. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-8-3: ACCIDENTS:
   A.   Immediate Notice Of Accident: The driver of a vehicle involved in an
accident on a public way, resulting in injury to or death of any person or
total damage to all property to an apparent extent of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) or more, shall immediately by the quickest means of communication,
give notice of such accident to the police department if such accident occurs
within this city.
   B.   Written Report: The driver of a vehicle which is in any manner involved
in an accident on a public way, resulting in bodily injury to or death of any
person or total damage to all property to an apparent extent of two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) or more shall, within twenty four (24) hours after such
accident, forward a written report of such accident to the police department.
The provisions of this section shall not be applicable when the accident has
been investigated at the scene by a police officer while such driver was
present thereat. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966; amd. Ord. 7299, 2-22-2012)
   C.   Driver Unable To Report:
      1.   Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically incapable of giving
an immediate notice of an accident as required in subsection A of this section,
and there was another occupant in the vehicle at the time of the accident
capable of doing so, such occupant shall make or cause to be given the notice
not given by the driver.
      2.   Whenever the driver is physically incapable of making a written
report of an accident as required in subsection B of this section, and such
driver is not the owner of the vehicle, then the owner of the vehicle involved
in such accident shall within twenty four (24) hours after the accident make
such report not made by the driver. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-8-4: PENALTY FOR VIOLATIONS:
   A.   General: Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every
person convicted of a violation of any provision of this title shall be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 3978, 3-26-1975; amd. Ord. 4255, 11-23-1977; 1999
Code)
   B.   Parking: Any person accused of a violation of an ordinance prohibiting
parking or stopping a vehicle in a designated area or restricting the length of
time a vehicle may be parked there, may settle and compromise the claim against
him or her for such illegal act by paying to the city the sum specified below
for each alleged offense:
 
Overtime parking (if paid within 30 days)                         $ 20.00
Overtime parking (if paid after 30 days)                          50.00
                                                                  
Illegal parking (if paid within 30 days)                          20.00
Illegal parking (if paid after 30 days)                           50.00
                                                                  
Parking in a parking place reserved for a handicapped person or a
disabled veteran without appropriate handicapped parking decal or 250.00
handicapped registration plates
 
Should the chief of police or his designee determine that a citation for
parking in a parking place reserved for a handicapped person or a disabled
veteran without appropriate handicapped parking decal or handicapped
registration plates has been issued to a person or vehicle when the person or
vehicle had a valid handicapped parking decal or handicapped parking
registration plates that was not properly displayed, the police chief or his
designee shall have the discretion to dismiss the parking citation but only if
the accused shall voluntarily pay twenty dollars ($20.00) for failure to
properly display a handicapped parking decal or handicapped registration plates
as required by subsection
8-3-4C of this title.
Parking citation violations may be paid at the office of the city treasurer,
the Alton police department or electronically as permitted and directed on the
city of Alton website. A receipt shall be prepared for all payments so
received. All such payments shall be deposited by the city treasurer and shall
accrue to the general fund of the city of Alton.
This subsection shall not apply to persons parking a vehicle so as to obstruct
the entrance or exit of any place where police or fire department apparatus or
other emergency equipment is kept or housed, or so as to block an emergency
entrance in a hospital. Nor shall this subsection apply to any person charged
with parking a vehicle so as to entirely obstruct traffic in any street or
alley or another person's driveway, or parking in such a way as to reduce
traffic on an arterial street to one-way traffic only; nor to any person who
refuses to move a vehicle illegally parked at the request of any member of the
city of Alton police or fire department.
   C.   Illegal Parking:
      1.   Citation On: Whenever any motor vehicle with or without a driver is
found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by any
ordinance of this city or by state law, the police officer, or parking control
officer or police cadet of the city of Alton finding such vehicle in violation
shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed
on the vehicle which may identify its user or owner and shall conspicuously
affix to such vehicle a parking citation on a form to be provided by the Alton
police department.
      2.   Responsibility In Reference To Illegal Parking: The fact that a
motor vehicle which is illegally parked or stopped is registered in a name of a
person shall be considered prima facie proof that such person was in control of
such motor vehicle at the time of such parking or stopping. When a motor
vehicle which is illegally parked or stopped is registered in the name of a
person that person shall be responsible for any penalties imposed for such
illegal parking or stopping of such a motor vehicle whether in the possession
of the registered owner or in the possession of his bailees, lessees, or
customers.
      3.   Failure To Comply With Citation: The violator of the restrictions on
stopping, standing or parking under the traffic laws or ordinances established
within the city of Alton shall be required to comply with the citation issued
by payment of the penalties as set forth in this section within sixty (60) days
of the date of issuance of the citation. If the owner or violator fails to pay
the penalty for the citation issued within sixty (60) days of the date of
issuance, the chief of police shall cause to be sent to the registered owner of
the motor vehicle to which the parking citation was affixed, a notice informing
him or her of the parking violation and warning that in the event the penalties
are not paid to the city of Alton within fourteen (14) days of the aforesaid
notice, an ordinance violation complaint shall be filed with the circuit court
of Madison County, Illinois, charging the ordinance violation offense of
"failure to comply with parking citation". The circuit court shall thereafter
issue a summons or a warrant for the ordinance violation complaint directed to
the defendant named in said ordinance violation complaint. (Ord. 7299, 2-22-
2012)
8-8-5: TRAFFIC CITATIONS:
   A.   Citations Issued: For offenses under this title, police officers, after
taking the name, address and operator's license number of the offender, the
registration number of the vehicle involved, and other pertinent information as
may be necessary, may issue a traffic violation citation notifying the offender
to appear in court at the time designated for hearing such cases. Such officer
may sign a complaint for the issuance of a warrant if the offender does not
appear at the time and place so specified. A police officer may, in the
exercise of his discretion, make an immediate arrest of the offender when
deemed necessary to protect the public health and safety.
   B.   Forms And Records: The chief of police shall be responsible for the
issuance of books of traffic citation forms to individual members of the police
department. Said books shall include serially numbered sets of citations in the
form prescribed by the mayor. The chief of police shall require a written
receipt for every book so issued and shall maintain a record of every such book
and each set of citations contained therein.
   C.   When Copy Of Citation Deemed Lawful Complaint: In the event the form of
citation provided under subsection A of this section, includes information and
is sworn to as required under the general laws of this state in respect to a
complaint charging commission of the offense alleged in said citation to have
been committed, then such citation when filed with a court having jurisdiction,
shall be deemed to be a lawful complaint for the purpose of prosecution under
this chapter.
   D.   Failure To Obey Citation:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to appear in answer to a
traffic citation regardless of the disposition of the charge for which such
citation was originally issued.
      2.   In the event any person fails to comply with a traffic citation
given to such person or attached to a vehicle, or fails to make appearance
pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the proper court within the
time permitted by ordinance, the chief of police shall secure and issue a
warrant for his arrest. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-8-6: DISPOSITION OF RECORDS, FINES AND FORFEITURES:
   A.   Records Of Citations, Warrants And Complaints:
      1.   Every police officer upon issuing a traffic citation to an alleged
violator of any provision of the motor vehicle laws of this state or of any
traffic ordinances of this city, shall deposit the original and a duplicate
copy of the citation with his immediate superior officer, who shall cause the
original to be delivered to the proper court of this city and said duplicate
copy to the central records section of the police department. The second
duplicate copy of the citation shall be retained in the traffic citation book
and shall be delivered by such superior officer to the chief of police together
with such book when all traffic citations therein have been issued.
      2.   Upon the filing of such original citation in the proper court as
aforesaid, said citation may be disposed of only by trial in said court or by
other official action by a judge of said court, including forfeiture of bail or
by payment of a fine to said court.
      3.   The chief of police shall require the return to him of each traffic
citation and all copies thereof, except that copy required to be retained in
the book as provided herein, which has been spoiled or upon which any entry has
been made and has not been issued to an alleged violator.
      4.   The chief of police shall also maintain or cause to be maintained in
connection with every traffic citation issued by a member of the police
department a record of the disposition of the charge by the proper court of
this city.
      5.   The chief of police shall also maintain or cause to be maintained a
record of all warrants issued by the court or by any other court on said
traffic violation charges and which are delivered to the police department for
service, and of the final disposition of all such warrants.
      6.   Except as provided in subsection A1 of this section, it shall be
unlawful and official misconduct for any member of the police department or
other officer or public employee to dispose of, alter or deface a traffic
citation or any copy thereof, of the record or the issuance or disposition of
any traffic citation, complaint or warrant in a manner other than as required
in this section.
   B.   Fines And Forfeitures: All fines or forfeitures collected upon
conviction or upon forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter and all fines and forfeitures collected
for violation of any of the provisions of the state motor vehicle act, when
said violations are prosecuted by the city, shall be paid into the city
treasury and deposited in the general fund. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966)
8-8-7: AUDIT OF RECORDS AND REPORTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 7299, 2-22-2012)
8-8-8: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Illegal Cancellation Of Citations: It shall be unlawful for any person
to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic citation in any manner
other than as provided by this chapter; provided, however, that this section
shall not be construed as to prohibit the chief of police or his designee
specified in writing from voiding for good cause traffic citations issued for
parking violations provided a record of any such tickets voided and the reasons
therefor is maintained. (Ord. 3378, 10-12-1966; amd. Ord. 7299, 2-22-2012)
   B.   Official Misconduct: Failure, refusal or neglect on the part of any
judicial or other officer or employee receiving or having custody of any such
fine or forfeiture, either before or after a deposit with the city treasurer to
comply with the foregoing provisions of this section shall constitute
misconduct in office and shall be grounds for removal therefrom. (Ord. 3378,
10-12-1966)
8-8-9: POLICE AUTHORIZED TO RELOCATE VEHICLES:
In the event of any emergency necessitating the removal of any vehicle upon any
street or highway, members of the police department are authorized to remove or
relocate any such vehicle from one location to any other location. (Ord. 3378,
10-12-1966)
8-8-10: AUTHORITY TO IMPOUND VEHICLES:
   A.   Members of the city of Alton police department are hereby authorized to
remove or cause to be removed, any motor vehicle from a street or highway to a
place of safety or to a motor vehicle storage facility approved by the city of
Alton or otherwise maintained by the city of Alton under the circumstances
hereinafter enumerated and to impound such motor vehicle until all fees and
charges as provided in this chapter have been paid, satisfied or challenged as
provided for by this chapter.
      1.   When any motor vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct,
railroad track or right of way, or causeway, or in any tunnel where such motor
vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic.
      2.   When a motor vehicle upon a highway is so disabled as to constitute
an obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the motor
vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to
be unable to provide for its removal or designate a responsible licensed driver
to assume custody of the motor vehicle and cause its safe removal.
      3.   When any motor vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so
parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the
normal movement of traffic, or an obstruction to any private driveway.
      4.   When any abandoned motor vehicle is found on any street or highway,
a vehicle shall be deemed abandoned when: a) in such state of disrepair as to
be incapable of being driven, or b) not used or moved for more than five (5)
consecutive days and is apparently deserted, or c) is left unattended and
becomes by reason of fire, snow or any happening or occurrence, a hazard to
public safety and convenience.
      5.   Whenever a motor vehicle is left parked and unattended on a street
or on any other properly designated public facility, which street or other
facility has been designated by city ordinance as an area in which parking is
prohibited, and which no parking prohibition is properly posted including
designation as a "towing zone", the members of the police department are hereby
authorized to cause such motor vehicle to be removed from said street or other
public facility by a towing service and impounded.
      6.   When any motor vehicle, operated with the express or implied
permission of the owner or owners of record, is used in connection with the
following violations, it shall be subject to seizure, removal and impoundment
by order of a member of the police department of the city of Alton, and the
owner or owners of record of said motor vehicle shall thereafter be liable to
the city of Alton for a level 1 administrative fee, as provided for in this
chapter, together with any towing and storage fees incurred, as provided by
this chapter.
         a.   Possession or delivery of a controlled substance or drug
paraphernalia as defined by the controlled substances act, 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 570/201 et seq., the cannabis control act, 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., or the drug paraphernalia act of the state of
Illinois, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/2 so long as the offense charged
is a class A misdemeanor or is a more serious offense as defined by the
Illinois criminal code.
         b.   Any weapons offense as defined in article 24 of chapter 720 of
the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
         c.   Driving under the influence (DUI) of alcohol, drugs or
intoxicating compounds as defined by the state of Illinois in section 5/11-501
of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501.
         d.   The offense of the commission of prostitution as defined in
section 5/11-14 of the criminal code, solicitation of a sexual act as defined
in section 5/11-14.1 of such code, soliciting for a prostitute as defined in
section 5/11-15 of such code, soliciting for a juvenile prostitute as defined
in section 5/11-18 of such code, patronizing a juvenile prostitute as defined
in section 5/11-18.1 of such code, or pandering as defined in section 5/11-16
of such code of a prostitute as defined by the criminal code of the state of
Illinois.
         e.   Driving with suspended or revoked driver's license as defined in
section 5/6-303 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
6-303 except and unless the driver's license was suspended solely as a result
of violation of vehicle emission regulations as required by 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/13C-55(a)(2).
         f.   Fleeing or attempting to elude a police officer as defined in
section 5/11-204 or 11-204.1 of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-204 and 204.1.
         g.   Leaving the scene of a personal injury or property damage
accident as defined in sections 5/11-401, 5/11-402 and 5/11-403 of the Illinois
vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-401, 402 and 403.
         h.   Violation of any outstanding order of protection as defined in
750 Illinois Compiled Statutes 60/103 or domestic battery offense as defined in
720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-3.2.
         i.   Any and all arrests for felony offenses as defined by the state
of Illinois criminal code or by the criminal code of the United States of
America.
      7.   When any motor vehicle, operated with the express or implied
permission of the owner or owners of record, is used in connection with the
following violations, it shall be subject to seizure, removal and impoundment
by order of a member of the police department of the city of Alton, and the
owner or owners of record of said motor vehicle shall be liable to the city of
Alton for a level 2 administrative fee, as provided for in this chapter,
together with any towing and storage fees incurred, as provided by this
chapter.
         a.   Any custodial arrest of a suspect for a misdemeanor as defined by
the Illinois criminal code and not included in those offenses enumerated in
subsection A6 of this section.
         b.   Any custodial arrest of a suspect for a traffic violation as
defined by the Illinois vehicle code or by this code and not included in those
offenses enumerated in subsection A6 of this section.
         c.   Any custodial arrest of a suspect on an outstanding misdemeanor
warrant for arrest issued by any court of competent jurisdiction and not
included in those offenses enumerated in subsection A6 of this section.
      8.   When any motor vehicle, operated with the express or implied
permission of the owner or owners of record is subject to removal, seizure or
impoundment by order of a member of the police department of the city of Alton
for any reason not enumerated in subsection A6 or A7 of this section, the owner
or owners of record of said motor vehicle shall be liable to the city for a
level 3 administrative fee, as provided for in this chapter, together with any
towing and storage fees incurred, as provided in this chapter.
   B.   Whenever a member of the police department of the city of Alton causes
a motor vehicle to be removed, towed or impounded as authorized by this code,
the police department of the city of Alton shall use due diligence to ascertain
the name and address of the owner or owners of record thereof and shall give or
cause to be given notice in writing to such owner or owners of record of the
fact of such removal, towing and impoundment and the reasons therefor and of
the place to which such motor vehicle had been removed, towed or impounded.
   C.   Whenever a member of the police department of the city of Alton causes
a motor vehicle to be removed, towed or impounded as authorized by this
section, and the police department of the city of Alton is unable after due
diligence to ascertain the name and address of the owner or owners of record,
or for any other reason is unable to give the written notice to the owner or
owners of record as provided herein, and in the event the motor vehicle is not
returned to the owner within a period of three (3) business days following its
removal, towing or impoundment, then, and in that event, the police department
of the city of Alton shall send or cause to be sent a written report of such
removal, towing or impoundment by mail to the secretary of state of the state
of Illinois. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle,
the date, time and place from which the motor vehicle was removed, the reasons
for such removal and the name of the towing agent and place where the motor
vehicle is impounded.
   D.   A member of the police department of the city of Alton who shall be
authorized by this code to cause a motor vehicle to be seized, removed, towed
and/or impounded shall not be required to exercise that authority. A member of
the police department may, in his or her discretion, permit an owner or an
authorized agent of an owner, to assume custody and control of the motor
vehicle if a licensed driver under circumstances determined in the judgment of
the member of the police department to be reasonably safe and appropriate.
(Ord. 7164, 12-9-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-8-11: IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
   A.   Definitions: The following terms shall be defined as hereinafter set
forth for the purpose of this chapter:
    BUSINESS DAY: Any day in which the offices of city hall are open to the
public for a minimum of seven (7) hours.
   LEVEL 1 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE: Means and shall be five hundred dollars
($500.00).
   LEVEL 2 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE: Means and shall be two hundred dollars
($200.00).
   LEVEL 3 ADMINISTRATIVE FEE: Means and shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00).
   MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self-propelled, including, but not
limited to, automobiles, trucks, vans, motorcycles and motor scooters.
   OWNER OF RECORD: The record title holder or holders of a motor vehicle as
registered with the secretary of state of the state of Illinois, or if not
registered in Illinois, the particular state in which the motor vehicle is
registered. If the motor vehicle is not required by law to be registered, the
owner of record shall be the legal owner as determined by law following
reasonable due diligence to determine the owner by authorities of the city of
Alton.
   B.   Removal Of Impounded Vehicle: Before the owner of record or person
entitled to possession of any impounded motor vehicle shall be permitted to
remove the same, he or she shall furnish documentation of the following:
      1.   His or her true identity.
      2.   Ownership of the motor vehicle.
      3.   His or her right of possession of the motor vehicle.
      4.   Proof of registration of licensing of the motor vehicle with the
appropriate state authorities.
      5.   Proof of insurance for the operation of the motor vehicle in
accordance with the laws of the state of Illinois.
      6.   Proof of a valid driver's license held by the person who shall drive
the motor vehicle from the impoundment area.
   C.   Administrative Fee: Before the owner of record or other person entitled
to possession of any motor vehicle impounded by authority of the police
department of the city of Alton, an administrative fee shall be paid to the
city of Alton. The administrative fee shall be a "level 1 administrative fee",
a "level 2 administrative fee" or a "level 3 administrative fee" as defined by
this section and by section
8-8-10 of this chapter. The appropriate fee shall be paid at the city of Alton
police department prior to the release of the motor vehicle as partial
reimbursement to the city of Alton police department in compensation for the
time and resources spent by the department regarding the seizure, impoundment
and release of said motor vehicles. The appropriate fees are to be paid by the
registered owner or other authorized person seeking the vehicle's release,
regardless of whether the registered owner of said motor vehicle or any other
authorized person was driving the motor vehicle prior to the circumstances
which gave rise to the impoundment of the motor vehicle by the city of Alton
police department.
   D.   Documentation: It shall be the duty of the towing or storage company in
possession of the impounded motor vehicle to obtain documentation issued by the
city of Alton police department confirming compliance with the foregoing
requirements prior to releasing the motor vehicle and to retain photocopies of
that documentation in their files for a period of not less than six (6) months
following the release of each respective motor vehicle. The foregoing
information shall be made available by the towing or storage company to the
authorities of the city of Alton police department for inspection and copying
upon request. The towing or storage company is prohibited from releasing any
motor vehicle they may tow pursuant to the direction of the city of Alton
police department until and unless the towing or storage company obtains the
documentation as aforesaid.
   E.   Towing Fee: The towing or storage company shall be entitled to receive
a fee from the owner or person entitled to possession of any such motor vehicle
prior to the release of the motor vehicle. The fee shall be to cover the cost
of removing said motor vehicle and, in addition thereto, the cost of storage of
said motor vehicle for each day or fraction thereof that said motor vehicle
shall have remained stored.
   F.   Violation Fee: The foregoing fees shall be in addition to any fees
levied or assessed against the owner or operator of said motor vehicle by
reason of violation of any ordinance, statute or warrant which may have
resulted from such violation that may have been the basis of or associated with
the impoundment of the motor vehicle.
   G.   Impoundment Of Vehicle: Whenever a police officer of the city of Alton
has reason to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to seizure, removal and
impoundment pursuant to this code, the state of Illinois or federal law, the
police officer shall provide for the removal of the motor vehicle to a facility
approved by the city of Alton. At the time of the seizure, removal and
impoundment of a motor vehicle, the police officer shall attempt to notify any
person identifying himself or herself as the owner of the respective motor
vehicle or the person who is found to be in control of the motor vehicle at
that time, if present, of the fact of the seizure of the motor vehicle and of
the right of the owner of the motor vehicle to request an administrative
hearing in accordance with the provisions of this section.
   H.   Administrative Hearing: At the time a motor vehicle is seized, removed
or impounded or within five (5) business days after a motor vehicle is seized,
removed and impounded by order or direction of a police officer of the city of
Alton, the city of Alton shall notify by personal service or by certified mail
the owner or owners of record of the owner's right to request an administrative
hearing to challenge whether violation of this chapter has occurred or to
contest the administrative fee imposed in connection with the seizure or
impoundment of the motor vehicle. The owner of record or his or her attorney
seeking a hearing must file a written request for a hearing with the office of
the chief of police of the city of Alton no later than ten (10) business days
after the aforesaid notice was mailed or personally served, whichever first
occurred. Upon the request of a hearing, in writing filed with the office of
the chief of police of the city of Alton within the aforesaid time allowed, a
hearing date must be scheduled no more than twenty (20) business days
thereafter. The person seeking a hearing shall have the burden of proof
establishing that a request for an administrative hearing was timely filed with
the office of the chief of police. Any interested person shall be given a
reasonable opportunity to be heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence
shall not apply at the hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. The
hearing may be continued once commenced to a subsequent time and date certain.
The chief of police shall serve as a hearing officer, or he may designate
another individual to serve as a hearing officer on a case by case basis. No
person involved in the particular seizure, removal or impoundment decision or
process may serve as a hearing officer.
If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the
evidence presented that the motor vehicle was properly subject to seizure,
removal and impoundment by order of a member of the city of Alton police
department, then the hearing officer shall enter a written order finding the
owner or owners of record of the respective motor vehicle civilly liable to the
city of Alton for the applicable administrative fee as provided by this
chapter.
If, after a hearing, the hearing officer does not determine by a preponderance
of the evidence that the motor vehicle was properly subject to seizure and
impoundment by order of a member of the city of Alton police department, then
the hearing officer shall enter a written finding for the record owner and
grant such relief as may be appropriate, including waiver of all or a portion
of the administrative fee and the return of the motor vehicle to the record
owner.
If the owner or owners of record request a hearing but fail to appear at the
hearing, or if the owner or owners of record fail to request a hearing in
writing in a timely manner, the owner or owners of record shall be deemed to
have waived his or her rights to an administrative hearing and the hearing
officer may enter a default order in favor of the city of Alton in the amount
of the appropriate administrative fee.
The owner or owners of record may elect to pay the administrative fee deemed
necessary to redeem the motor vehicle without constituting a waiver of the
right of the owner or owners of record to request an administrative hearing in
writing and in a timely manner as provided by this chapter and upon payment of
the appropriate administrative fee, together with any towing and storage fees
incurred, the motor vehicle shall be returned to the owner or owners of record
without further bond. The action of the Alton police department shall be
subject to administrative review as provided herein.
The final written decision of the city of Alton police chief or his designated
hearing officer shall constitute a final administrative order and be subject to
judicial review under the provisions of the administrative review act of the
state of Illinois.
   I.   Disposition Of Impounded Vehicles: An administrative fee imposed
pursuant to this chapter shall constitute a debt due and owing the city of
Alton. A motor vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter shall remain
impounded until:
      1.   The administrative fee is paid in full to the city of Alton and all
applicable towing and storage fees are paid to the towing agent and all of the
requirements of subsection B of this section have been satisfied; or
      2.   The motor vehicle is deemed abandoned, in which case the motor
vehicle shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition
of abandoned motor vehicles; and
      3.   Any motor vehicle that is not properly redeemed by the record owner
or owners within thirty (30) days after the expiration of the appropriate time
during which the owner or owners of record may seek a further administrative or
judicial review of the city's actions in causing a motor vehicle to be seized,
towed and impounded under this chapter, may be disposed of as an unclaimed
motor vehicle as provided by law; provided, however, that where proceedings
have been instituted under state or federal drug asset forfeiture laws, the
subject motor vehicle may not be disposed of by the city of Alton except as
consistent with those proceedings. (Ord. 7164, 12-9-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-8-12: SALE OF UNCLAIMED MOTOR VEHICLES:
Whenever any motor vehicle so impounded as aforesaid shall remain unclaimed by
the owner or other person legally entitled to possession thereof for a period
of thirty (30) days from and after notice shall have been given, the police
department shall sell such motor vehicle at public auction to the highest
bidder for cash, the time and place of such sale to be published at least once
in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, not less than ten (10) nor
more than fifteen (15) days before the date of such sale. The police department
shall cause a notice of such sale to be mailed to the secretary of state, said
notice to contain a full description of every motor vehicle to be sold and the
time and place of sale, provided any such motor vehicle not sold at the first
sale may be offered for sale and sold at subsequent dates without further
notice. The proceeds of such sale after paying all liens and deducting all
reasonable charges and expenses, including the fees and charges herein provided
and the expenses of advertising and conducting the sale, shall be paid to the
city treasurer.
No member of the police department, nor any other employee of the city,
directly or indirectly, shall purchase or participate in the bidding for or the
purchase of any vehicle offered for sale as aforesaid. (Ord. 7164, 12-9-2009,
eff. 1-1-2010)
CHAPTER 9
NEIGHBORHOOD VEHICLE REGISTRATIONS
SECTION:
8-9-1: Findings
8-9-2: Definitions
8-9-3: Requirements For Use
8-9-4: Operation Under The Influence
8-9-5: License Required
8-9-6: Insurance
8-9-7: Local Permit Required
8-9-8: Authorization
8-9-1: FINDINGS:
After full and careful consideration of the volume, speed and character of
traffic on the streets, roads, highways and alleys of the city of Alton, the
city council of the city of Alton does hereby determine and find that the
public safety will not be jeopardized by the authorization of the operation of
neighborhood vehicles. Further, the city council of the city of Alton does
hereby determine and find that neighborhood vehicles may safely travel on or
across the streets, roads, highways and alleys of the city of Alton. (Ord.
7187, 3-24-2010)
8-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
A "neighborhood vehicle" means a self-propelled, electronically powered four
(4) wheeled motor vehicle (or a self-propelled gasoline powered 4 wheel motor
vehicle with an engine displacement under 1,200 cubic centimeters), which is
capable of attaining in one mile a speed of more than twenty (20) miles per
hour, but not more than twenty five (25) miles per hour, and which conforms to
federal regulations under title 49 CFR part 157.500. (Ord. 7187, 3-24-2010)
8-9-3: REQUIREMENTS FOR USE:
No neighborhood vehicle may be operated on any streets, roads, highways and
alleys in the city of Alton unless, at a minimum, it has the following: brakes,
a steering apparatus, tires, a rearview mirror, red reflectorized warning
devices in front and rear, a slow moving emblem (as required of other vehicles
in section 12-709 of the Illinois motor vehicle code 1 ) on the rear of the
neighborhood vehicle, a headlight that emits a white light visible from a
distance of five hundred feet (500') to the front, a taillamp that emits a red
light visible from at least one hundred feet (100') from the rear, brake
lights, and turn signals. When operated on streets, roads, highways and alleys,
neighborhood vehicle shall have its headlight and taillamps lighted as required
by section 12-201 of the Illinois motor vehicle code 2 . (Ord. 7187, 3-24-2010)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/12-709.
2 1. 625 ILCS 5/12-201.
8-9-4: OPERATION UNDER THE INFLUENCE:
A person who drives or is in actual physical control of a neighborhood vehicle
on any street, road, highway or alley of the city of Alton while under the
influence of alcohol or drugs is subject to sections 11-500 through 11-502 of
the Illinois motor vehicle code 1 . (Ord. 7187, 3-24-2010)
 
Notes
1 2. 625 ILCS 5/11-500 – 5/11-502.
8-9-5: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate a neighborhood vehicle upon any street, road, highway
or alley in the city of Alton unless he or she has a valid Illinois driver's
license issued in his or her name by the secretary of state of the state of
Illinois. (Ord. 7187, 3-24-2010)
8-9-6: INSURANCE:
No person shall operate a neighborhood vehicle upon any street, road, highway
or alley in the city of Alton unless he or she has complied with the minimum
liability insurance requirements imposed upon a vehicle operator by the
statutes of the state of Illinois and has proof of such minimum liability
insurance coverage on or in his or her possession at all times while operating
said neighborhood vehicle. (Ord. 7187, 3-24-2010)
8-9-7: LOCAL PERMIT REQUIRED:
No neighborhood vehicle may be operated on any street, road, highway or alley
in the city of Alton unless such neighborhood vehicle has a valid permit for
operation of that neighborhood vehicle issued by the city of Alton. Permits
shall be issued by the chief of police of the city of Alton. The chief of
police of the city of Alton is hereby authorized and directed to prepare an
application form, which shall be required as a part of the process to initiate
a request for a permit. Upon submission of a completed application for permit,
a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) payable to the city of Alton shall be collected
by the chief of police before the application is processed. The fee shall be
nonrefundable and shall apply to each neighborhood vehicle. The chief of police
shall cause an inspection of each neighborhood vehicle to assure compliance
with the various provisions of this chapter. If the chief of police or his
designee is satisfied that the application is properly completed, the fee
received, and the inspection discloses compliance with each provision of this
chapter, the chief of police shall issue a permit on a form to be determined by
the chief of police. The permit must be permanently affixed to the neighborhood
vehicle for which it is applicable. Regardless of the day of issuance, a permit
shall be valid for the remainder of a calendar year. A new application, fee and
inspection shall be required for operation of a neighborhood vehicle with
regard to any subsequent calendar year. (Ord. 7187, 3-24-2010)
8-9-8: AUTHORIZATION:
The operation of neighborhood vehicles upon the streets, roads, highways and
alleys of the city of Alton is hereby allowed, so long as the operation of
neighborhood vehicles is in full compliance with this chapter. The public works
department of the city of Alton is hereby authorized and directed to erect
appropriate signage in relation to the adoption of this chapter.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the operation of a neighborhood vehicle shall be
permitted only on or across streets, roads, highways and alleys of the city of
Alton as specifically identified and enumerated as follows:
Belle Street between Third and Seventh Streets.
State Street between Broadway and Fourth Streets.
Sugar Alley between Piasa and State Streets.
William Street between Broadway and Fourth Streets.
Third Street between Piasa and State Streets.
Fourth Street between Piasa and William Streets.
Fifth Street between Piasa and Belle Streets.
Sixth Street between Piasa and Belle Streets.
Seventh Street between Piasa and Belle Streets.
The operation of a neighborhood vehicle on or across any streets, roads,
highways and alleys of the city of Alton not specifically identified and
enumerated herein is hereby prohibited and shall constitute a violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 7187, 3-24-2010)

not for profit corporation whose main purpose is to upgrade and improve current

shall be waived with regard to any properties owned by or contracted to be
improved by Piasa Area Habitat for Humanity. With the exception of the waiver
of the fees, Piasa Area Habitat for Humanity shall in all other respects be
required to comply with the provisions of this chapter and to obtain
appropriate permits.

for profit corporation whose main purpose is to upgrade and improve current
housing stock and to provide better housing for lower income people within the
City of Alton, the building permit fees required by this section shall be
waived with regard to any properties owned by or contracted to be improved by
Christmas in April. With the exception of the waiving of the fees, Christmas in
April shall in all other respects be required to comply with the provisions of
this chapter and to obtain all appropriate permits.
